DOC.HEAD: Precede: RICHLAND, Wash.
Watkins Acknowledges High Radiation Emissions from Atomic Weapons Plant
DOC.TEXT: Energy Secretary James Watkins said Wednesday a nuclear weapons plant in the Pacific Northwest released enough radiation in the 1940s to pose a serious health hazard to nearby residents. It was the first time the government has acknowledged that radiation emissions from the Hanford Nuclear Reservation were high enough to cause illnesses, incluuding cancer, in people living nearby. Watkins, speaking in advance of a study on the Richland, Wash., plant to be released Thursday, said, ``The implications of the report are serious.'' Watkins said the report is expected to ``contain estimates of potentially large doses'' of radiation from the Hanford plant from 1944 to 1947. ``When I say high I mean significantly high _ 3,000 rads, thousands of rads,'' he said. A rad is a measure of radiation exposure to human tissue. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission requires that facilities it licenses limit yearly radiation exposure from airborne emissions to 15 thousandths of a rad. He said between 350,000 and 400,000 curies of radioactive material was released in one episode in 1945. A curie is the amount of radiation emitted in one second by 1,400 pounds of enriched uranium. The study being released Thursday is the first part of a five-year, $15 million study that is the first major research into accidental and intentional release of massive amounts of radiation that drifted from Hanford into ten nearby Washington and Oregon counties. The report will cover emissions, but not the health effects of the radiation, said Angela Beers, spokeswoman for the panel of 18 non-government scientists and experts that directed the review. But a parallel study under way at the Centers for Disease Control will use the exposure estimates to try to document cases of thyroid disease among Hanford area residents, she said. Watkins said at his press conference that the main source of worrisome exposure was radioiodine, the same isotope that caused radiation sickness in some residents who lived near the Soviet Union's nuclear power plant at Chernobyl when radiation was released in a 1986 accident. A number of people who lived across the Columbia River from Hanford's nine reactors claimed the 1940s emissions caused cancer and thyroid-related illnesses. ``I don't want you to think we do this today,'' Watkins said. ``We are not casual about this today. But we do have to go back and look at what happened to people. We don't know who was at the right spot at the wrong time ... We have to learn lessons out of this and be sensitive to the human beings who were there at the time.'' The Hanford Environmental Dose Reconstruction Project uses computer models to estimate how much radiation escaped when plutonium was produced at the 560-square-mile nuclear plant. Scientists will use the first-phase estimates to test and refine computer models over the next two years, during the second phase, said John Till, a South Carolina nuclear scientist and the panel's chairman. Radioactive iodine was produced when spent reactor fuel rods were chemicall dissolved to produce weapons-grade plutonium and uranium. When it concentrates in the thyroid gland, iodine-131 can cause cancer and other diseases. Judith Jurji, president of the Hanford Downwinders Coalition, said she and five members of her family have hypothyroidism, which causes sluggishness and puffiness. Her father and two uncles worked at Hanford from 1949 to 1956. However, it would be very difficult to prove a long-term illness was caused by exposure more than 40 years ago and law prohibits lawsuits against the government, said Jim Thomas of the Spokane-based Hanford Education Action League. Researchers studied air emissions from 1944 to 1947 and contaminated cooling water emissions into the Columbia River from 1964 to 1967, in part because those were years of highest radiation releases and the best documented, Ms. Beers said. Weapons-grade plutonium was produced at the plant from 1943 until 1988, but radiation emissions steadily decreased over the last 30 years. The Energy Department is paying for the study but has no supervisory authority.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Wins With `Cheers,' `Cosby,' `Seinfeld' Reruns, `Blossom' Pilot
DOC.TEXT: Summer replacement series gave television viewers some alternatives during the July Fourth holiday week, but reruns got the top ratings. Networks ``put the dogs on,'' said David Marans, a senior researcher for the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency. ``These are shows that will not be on the fall schedule. Almost without exception the public has not liked these shows.'' According to A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings released Tuesday, the four half-hours of NBC's top-rated Thursday night lineup won the week's highest ratings. It was the first time since February that NBC had the top four shows. A ``Cheers'' rerun was No. 1; a repeat of ``The Cosby Show'' was second; the pilot episode of ``Blossom,'' a potential midseason entry, was third; and a repeat of ``The Seinfeld Chronicles'' pilot was fourth. Marans said ratings for ``Blossom'' were boosted by having ``Cosby'' precede it, just as the top-rated ``Cheers'' episode pulled up the ``Seinfeld'' ratings. ``Those shows were all weaker than the repeats that went on before them,'' Marans said. ``The networks have got to be very disappointed.'' ``Blossom'' turned in the best performance for an NBC pilot so far this summer, the network said. The comedy stars Mayim Bialyk, who plays a 13-year-old coming of age in Los Angeles. The second highest-rated summer sitcom was ABC's ``Dad's a Dog,'' which stars David Steinberg. It opened in 21st place. Overall, NBC was the No. 1 network for the eighth consecutive week with a 9.0 average, but was barely ahead of ABC, which had an 8.9 average. CBS was third with a 7.6 average. The Fox Broadcasting Co. had a 6.0 average. A rating point represents 921,000 households. NBC has won 39 of the past 42 weeks, but Marans said NBC's losses and ABC's gains will have the two networks closely battling for first place in the weeks ahead. Rounding out the top 10 shows were CBS' ``Designing Women'' and ``60 Minutes'' at fifth and sixth, NBC's ``Empty Nest'' at No. 7, NBC's ``Golden Girls'' and CBS' ``Murphy Brown'' tied for eighth, and ABC's ``Roseanne'' and Fox's ``Married ... with Children'' tied for 10th. Fox had two other shows in the top 20, ``In Living Color'' at No. 15 and ``Cops'' at 17. In the evening news broadcasts, ABC continued its domination with an 8.4 rating. CBS was second with a 7.4 rating and NBC was third with a 6.9.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Dealer Waits `For Business to Come to Me'
DOC.TEXT: Dressed in expensive gold jewelry and designer casual wear, a man being arraigned on drug possession charges says he made up to $90,000 over three years in Washington's illegal narcotics trade. ``I can go out here, stand on a corner and wait for business to come to me, you know,'' the man who identified himself only as Archie, a 21-year-old District of Columbia resident, said Tuesday. ``I work for somebody, but I don't have anybody standing over me. I just have to give the people what they want, take their money, make sure it gets back to where it belongs and get my cut,'' he said. Archie said he made ``between $75,000 to $90,000 over three years.'' The lure of making large sums of money in a short period of time is the main reason why many poor, black urban males in the nation's capital participate in the underground drug trade, according to a study released by the Rand Corp. on Tuesday. The report was based on information gathered among 186 Washington, D.C., men aged 18-40 who said they had been involved in drug activity and were on probation. It said the average street-level operative is a poor, urban black male who makes a median income of $24,000 annually from narcotics sales. Archie, who is black and who lives in a poorer section of Washington, fits the statistical profile. He said he viewed the charges facing him in D.C. Superior Court as part of the cost of plying his illegal trade. ``I don't have no supervisor. I don't have no overhead and I don't have no hassles. The only thing I got to worry about is being picked up by the law,'' he said. ``This is my fifth arrest, but I've never been convicted and this just interrupts what I do.'' Archie's lawyer, Angela Burns, confirmed that her client had been arrested five times in the past three years on drug and weapons charges but had no convictions. The Rand report also used information supplied by the city government about the 24,000 people arrested for selling or possessing drugs from 1985 through 1987, and a survey of 387 boys aged 15 to 18. The report estimated that in 1987, an estimated 24,000 district residents were selling drugs on the street. For the three in eight who were dealing drugs every day, the median monthly earnings were $2,000, or $30 an hour _ tax-free _ after expenses. That compares with the $7 an hour from the legitimate jobs that 75 percent of the probationers reported holding. The study found that dealers active at least two days a week face a 22 percent chance of going to prison, a 7 percent chance of severe injury and a 1.4 percent chance of being killed _ a fatality rate 100 times that of the general work force. Given those risks, ``long periods of steady earnings are unlikely to be common,'' the report said. The estimated median income of street-level drug dealers was higher than the average $12,898 earned by retail trade workers in 1987-88, according to the city government. Construction workers made $24,879, on average, while service industry workers made $26,545. The average annual salary for all private sector workers was $25,857, while government employees made $32,118. But those workers are subject to federal and local income tax withholding. Economist Peter Reuter, the chief author of the Rand study, said, ``The creation of considerably higher paying legitimate jobs probably wouldn't get us very far. Dealers would still have smaller total incomes than they can earn now by supplementing their regular wages with drug selling. Also, many of them have expensive drug habits.'' Reuter said in an interview that, while most street-level sales were by blacks, the availability of drugs in Washington affects not just the city's predominantly black population but white suburbanites as well. While a typical city street dealer's earnings aren't enough to finance flashy cars and lavish lifestyles, it is the image of such luxuries that draw many young men into selling drugs, he said.

DOC.HEAD: For One Day at Least, England is No. 1
DOC.TEXT: Its stadiums are shabby, its fans remain rowdy and it still can't produce a tennis player good enough to get past the second round at Wimbledon. Forget all that. England was back on top of the sports heap Tuesday, at least from its own island vantage point. Fans could fill themselves with pride along with beer at the local pub as, within 4{ hours on a typically cloudy summer day, two events restored the nation so long associated with the downside of sport to No. 1. First, the European soccer federation voted to readmit English clubs into two of its three continental tournaments next year. The clubs were banned in 1985 when 39 people died in a rampage by English fans through a Belgian stadium. ``We Are Back!'' read the inch-high headline on the Evening Standard, London's afternoon newspaper. Sports Minister Colin Moynihan hailed it as ``the dawning of a new era.'' Then, just as the country was drinking in that dram of good news came a double shot: England won a cricket series on home soil for the first time in five years. BBC-TV interrupted its news headlines to announce the victory. The excitement was understandable. England gave the game to the world but in recent years the world has caught up, and the last time the English won a home-field Test series _ a string of major international matches each lasting five days _ was against Australia in 1985. They defeated Sri Lanka at home in 1988, but that was something like the Oakland Athletics beating the Toledo Mud Hens. Tuesday's events heightened an already giddy feeling around English sports. The national soccer team did much better than expected at the World Cup, reaching the semifinals before losing in a shootout to West Germany, the eventual champion. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher wants to have the players over for tea, an invitation that would have been unthinkable just a month ago, given the national humiliation brought upon her country by rowdy fans. English race-car driver Nigel Mansell is a favorite at this weekend's British Grand Prix Formula 1 event, and next week Nick Faldo of England, probably the best golfer in the world, has a chance to add the British Open to his U.S. Masters titles from the last two years. But all is not as rosy as an English garden. Soccer authorities still don't know how they will meet new stadium safety rules imposed after 95 deaths in a crush of fans at a game last year. The government remains red-faced over the expulsion of more than 300 English soccer fans from Italy after fights in Sardinia, Rimini and Turin. And the tennis! The land of Fred Perry and Virginia Wade failed to get a player into the third round of the men's or women's singles at Wimbledon again this year, and British bookies laid odds before the tournament of 1,000-to-1 against a home-grown men's champion and 2,000-1 against a women's winner. The odds against an alien landing on earth this century are 100-1. Those bookies may hum ``God Save the Queen'' as they figure the hunches, but they don't let the tune cloud their minds. When The European soccer federation announced its decision on readmission, William Hill, one of the country's biggest bookmakers, offered 7-1 against an English club winning a European trophy next season.

DOC.HEAD: US Weighs Giving American Know-How To Soviets
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administratation says the most useful thing it can do now for the Soviet Union, rather than send cold, hard cash, is to give it a few lessons in good old American know-how. Sending experts abroad to help needy countries, known as ``technical assistance'' in foreign-policy jargon, has been a centerpiece of the U.S. foreign aid program for years. And now it is a feature of the new spirit of cooperation between the superpowers. Some allies, including West Germany and France, hoped the United States and other industrial democracies would go much further _ and agree at the economic summit in Houston to fashion a coordinated package of direct assistance to the reeling Soviet economy. President Bush, among others, resisted. The dispute was blunted, for the time being, when the seven summit partners agreed instead Tuesday to organize a quick study of the Soviet Union's needs. Meanwhile, the summit leaders gave Gorbachev a warm endorsement and pledged to ``help in practical ways those countries that choose freedom.'' And a tentative draft of the communique to be issued at the close of the summit today said ``Prospects for fundamental and long-term economic aid could improve if the Soviet Union comes to a substantial change in resources from military to civilian production, and ends the support to those states which create regional conflict.'' The Western leaders called for group of international financial institutions, under International Monetary Fund supervision, to conduct the Soviet study and complete it by year's end. But the World Bank, part of that group, immediately pronounced the deadline unrealistic, saying ``a study of this nature would take a long time _ a year or so.'' In the interim, for the United States to extend even technical assistance is a gesture that is downright revolutionary, when measured by the standards of just 8{ years ago. After the Polish government's crackdown, with Soviet acquiescence, on the Solidarity labor union in December 1981, the Western allies were debating how severely to punish the Soviets economically. Now the debate is focused on how much the Kremlin should be rewarded for its change of heart under Mikhail Gorbachev's stewardship. Bush and Gorbachev set in motion the concept of U.S. technical assistance at the Malta summit seven months ago. Officials now say an acceleration of that cooperation may be possible. Technical assistance can cover a variety of different endeavors. In Panama, it means helping the government form a new police force. In Nicaragua, U.S. experts are helping to implement the government's economic policy. In El Salvador, American advisers are trying to upgrade the country's woefully deficient judicial system. The U.S. position on the Soviet Union is that direct aid would merely be wasted by a system plagued by gross inefficiencies. Baker said on Tuesday the biggest favor the West could do for the Soviets would be to offer its advice to help Gorbachev achieve his goal of streamlining the Soviet economy. A number of private experts agree with that approach. Some ideas which are at various stages of discussion include helping the Soviets devise a consumer price index and a stock market in a transition to a market economy. Leon Aron of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group, said the United States is uniquely positioned among the allies to offer advice on these areas to a country as large as the Soviet Union because of the scale of the U.S. economy. Aron rejected the suggestion of some European nations that direct financial aid to the Soviet Union is feasible. He said that because of systemic inefficiencies, there is $8 billion worth of imported equipment languishing unopened in Soviet ports. ``A blank check is wasted,'' he said. Ed A. Hewitt of the Brookings Institution said U.S. experts could aid the Soviets in overcoming such problems as getting food to the market place. About a third of all Soviet food rots before reaching the dinner table because of inadequate transportation or storage facilities, he said. Both Hewitt and Richard Feinberg, executive vice president of the Overseas Development Council, strongly support a major role for the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in helping the Soviets. Financial stabilization and structural changes are sorely needed in the Soviet Union and are precisely the areas the bank and the fund have been set up to deal with, Feinberg said. The IMF makes loans to developing countries providing they agree to undertake measures that it believes are necessary to put them on a sounder economic footing. Feinberg says that among the IMF's success stories are Turkey, Mexico, Bolivia and Chile. Critics argue that IMF policies have impoverished some countries. The Soviets are not now in a position to benefit from the fund or the bank because they are not members of either institution. But they have indicated a desire to join, and the Bush administration reportedly is weighing options on the subject. There are other ways the United States could help the Soviets short of direct assistance. As an example, if the Kremlins drop barriers to emigration, the United States could waive the so-called Jackson-Vanik amendment, thereby permitting normal trade between the two countries. That step, in turn, could be followed by U.S. trade credits and the easing of high technology exports. The Soviets may act on the emigration question in September. Will direct U.S. aid ever be in the cards? ``I don't think you should ever say never,'' Baker said Tuesday. ``Things can change.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate to Act on Crime Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Vote expected by 1 p.m. EDT; will be led
DOC.TEXT: Gun groups and their critics are already gearing up for a fight in the House as the Senate prepares to approve a major anti-crime bill with curbs on nine kinds of semiautomatic assault rifles. ``We are certainly going to lobby to keep the House crime bill free of gun control, and when they get to a conference committee we are going to try to strip the gun provisions out of the Senate bill,'' National Rifle Association lobbyist James Baker said Tuesday. The Senate planned to vote today on its crime package, which would ban the import or domestic manufacture of nine semiautomatic weapons. The measure also calls for capital punishment for 34 federal offenses ranging from presidential assassination to treason. Before voting on the measure, the Senate first must wrap up one loose end involving provisions designed to combat savings and loan fraud. Debate over other specific provisions of the bill, however, was completed last month and the measure is not expected to have trouble winning approval. The bill also would limit death row appeals with an eye toward ending delays of a decade or more in carrying out executions. But states would have to provide free lawyers to carry out the appeals. Other provisions would toughen the nation's money-laundering laws, increase aid for local law enforcement, strengthen federal investigative agencies, expand funding for ``boot camp'' prisons and create a ``police corps'' scholarship program for peace officers. And the bill calls for penalties for using and dealing in the new drug ``ice'' and adds steroids to the list of controlled substances. The House Judiciary Committee is working on its own version of comprehensive crime legislation. That measure does not contain major firearms provisions, but the House panel already has approved a firearms bill that is awaiting floor action. It could easily be combined with the crime measure, congressional aides said. The House gun bill would outlaw domestic semiautomatic weapons that fail to meet the ``sporting purposes'' test under which a number of firearms manufactured overseas are now kept out of the country. The NRA, traditionally an influential force on Capitol Hill, was beaten repeatedly in the Senate as it sought over the last two months to strip firearms provisions out of the crime bill. Sponsors credited lobbying by police organizations. The Washington-based group Handgun Control Inc. had also been pushing hard to maintain the curbs on semiautomatic weapons. The Senate bill at one time was part of President Bush's anti-crime package. But over the last year it has virtually been rewritten on Capitol Hill, and the administration now lacks enthusiasm for it. The campaign for curbs on semiautomatic assault rifles began after a 1989 Stockton, Calif., schoolyard massacre by a man carrying a semiautomatic version of an AK-47 rifle. Banned for import or domestic manufacture under the bill would be: Norinco, Mitchell and Poly Technologies Avtomat Kalashnikovs (including the AK-47); Action Arms Israeli Military Industries Uzi and Galil; Beretta AR-70 (SC-70); Colt AR-15 and CAR-15; Fabrique Nationale FN-FAL, FN-LAR and FNC; MAC-10 and MAC-11; Steyr AUG; INTRATEC TEC-9 and the Street Sweeper and the Striker.

DOC.HEAD: Celebrities Bid Goodbye to Restaurateur
DOC.TEXT: Linda Ronstadt sang ``Ave Maria,'' former ``Hill Street Blues'' co-star Betty Thomas read from Scriptures and actor John Candy was a pallbearer at the funeral of restaurateur Frank Casado. Casado, owner of the Lucy's El Adobe, a hangout for politicians and celebrities, died Thursday after an eight-month battle with lung cancer. He was 66. ``His restaurant was more than a place to eat. It was a place to meet, a place of stability,'' former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said in his eulogy during Tuesday's funeral Mass. ``He was one of the pioneers of the awakening of Mexican-Americans in the city and state,'' Brown told 400 mourners at St. Vibiana's Cathedral. A mariachi band played at a graveside service that followed at Calvary Cemetery.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Makes Progress in Telescope, Space Shuttle
With PM-Hubble Contractor Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NASA rejected a bidder on the Hubble Space Telescope that planned tests to detect focusing flaws and instead picked a company that proposed no such tests and made mirrors with a fuzzy view of the universe, a space agency official says. Eastman Kodak Co., in its effort to win the contract to build the Hubble mirrors, proposed a ``final assembly testing'' of the telescope optics, NASA Deputy Administrator James R. Thompson told a Senate panel Tuesday. NASA, however, gave the contract to Perkin-Elmer Corp., now Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., which did not plan the fully assembled tests, and the agency chose not to order the tests because they were so expensive, Thompson said. The Hubble Telescope, now in orbit, is disabled because of a focusing flaw that might have been found by tests proposed in the Kodak bid. ``In retrospect, perhaps an all-systems test could have been done or should have been done,'' Thompson told the science and space subcommittee. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration declined to say why Perkin-Elmer was selected for the Hubble contract, but NASA spokesman Bill Sheehan said ``Perkin-Elmer had, on balance, more strength.'' Perkin-Elmer's experience in building spy satellites may have been a factor, other sources said. The Danbury, Conn., firm's winning bid in 1977 was for $63.4 million, but the total value of the contract swelled through cost overruns and changes to $451 million. Almost $20 million of that was paid by NASA as award fees, which are given based on performance evaluation. Stephen Beale, a NASA procurement officer, said an additional $4.3 million in award fees for the company are under consideration. Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., who chaired the hearing, charged that NASA's recent problems with a crippled telescope and a space shuttle fleet grounded by hydrogen leaks may be related to an agency ``mindset to reject any pessimistic news.'' Gore said Congress was ``no longer going to be satisfied'' with what he called ``NASA's proclivity to shoot the messenger and not give credence to troublesome studies.'' He said the agency, for instance, rejected some studies predicting that within the next decade there could be another accident like the Challenge explosion that killed seven astronauts in 1986. Thompson, in a heated exchange, called the charge unfair. He said NASA recognized that there are risks in space flight and that another space shuttle could be lost eventually. ``If you fly 100 times and I tell you that we're not going to lose another one, that wouldn't pass the sanity test,'' said Thompson. ``If we fly 100 more, we may lose another one.'' But he added: ``I think the chance is very, very low with the team we have in place.'' Meanwhile, Hubble Space Telescope experts told a news conference that they have moved closer to determining which of two mirrors on the observatory spacecraft had been cut to the wrong prescription. ``All of the evidence is beginning to point toward the primary mirror and not the secondary mirror,'' said Ed Weiler, chief project scientist for the Hubble. The telescope has two mirrors, a 94-inch primary and a 12-inch secondary, that are suspects in the focusing flaw that has handicapped Hubble. Experts are working to determine which mirror is flawed. This will help make corrective optics for a replacement camera that will be installed by 1993. If the primary mirror is at fault, Weiler said, it will be easier to correct than if the problem was in the secondary mirror. The secondary mirror reflects light from the primary mirror into the telescope's instruments.

DOC.HEAD: Former Governor Sentenced to Prison
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr., whose crimes included extorting more than half a million dollars from a coal operator, has been sentenced to five years and 10 months in prison and fined $170,000. Moore, 67, appeared stoic during his sentencing Tuesday on five corruption charges. He was ordered to report to a federal prison in Petersburg, Va., on July 31. ``Arch Moore is a criminal,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Joe Savage said before sentencing. ``If there is one thing missing from that man, it's remorse.'' Moore pleaded guilty to charges of mail fraud, extortion, obstruction of justice and filing false income tax returns during his 1984 and 1988 campaigns and during his third term, from 1985-89. U.S. District Judge Walter Hoffman on Monday had refused to let Moore withdraw his guilty pleas. Moore had argued he was coerced by federal prosecutors. Moore, a Republican who also was a U.S. congressman for 12 years, refused to comment on the sentence. An appeal is pending, defense attorney William Hundley said. Moore's corruption involved campaign-funding violations, not raids on the treasury, Hundley said. ``I submit he served well and honorably,'' Hundley added. U.S. Attorney Michael Carey said Moore likely will serve at least 2{ years before being considered for parole. Moore served as governor from 1969 to 1977 and again from 1985 to 1989, longer than any governor in the state's history. He was only the second Republican since 1933 to govern West Virginia, where Democrats outnumber Republicans by a 2-to-1 margin. Moore pleaded guilty May 8 to extorting $573,000 from coal operator H. Paul Kizer of Beckley in return for a $2.1 million refund from the state's Black Lung Fund, which provides benefits to coal miners. Moore also pleaded guilty to trying to block a federal grand jury investigation into corruption in his administration and allegations he used illegal cash contributions in his 1988 campaign. He also admitted filing false income tax returns in 1984 and 1985 and defrauding the state of his salary and benefits by funneling $100,000 in illegal cash payments into his 1984 campaign to buy votes. Hoffman sentenced Moore to five years on the extortion charge, six months on mail fraud and two years each on the tax fraud counts. All are to be served concurrently. Moore also got 10 months for the obstruction of justice charge, which carries a mandatory prison term. Moore could have gotten 36 years in prison and fines of $1.25 million. Moore is not the first West Virginia governor to be convicted on federal charfes. Democrat W.W. ``Wally'' Barron, who served from 1961 to 1965, was convicted of bribing the foreman of a jury that acquitted him of bribery in 1968. He served three years and four months of a 12-year sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Media Target of Houston's Salesmanship
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While the world's spotlight remains trained on the deliberations of seven Western leaders here, the city of Houston is plying the news media for its share of attention. About 4,000 reporters are in town for the economic summit, and civic leaders have spared no effort to put them in a good mood about the city. Already, favorable stories about Houston's rebounding economy have brought calls from interested Japanese and European corporations, Mayor Kathy Whitmire said Tuesday. ``We specifically asked for the opportunity to host the economic summit because we wanted the chance to focus the worldwide attention on what is happening here in Houston,'' Whitmire said Tuesday. ``We felt that there ought to be some way that we can take advantage of your presence here,'' she said. Boosters have invested hundreds of thousands of dollars to present the credentialed reporters with free food, alcohol, T-shirts, tote bags and even toothpaste. That's become the standard formula for any city playing host to pre-eminent news events like summits, political conventions or sports extravaganzas. Houstonians make no secret of their motives. ``Frankly, the people from Washington told us early on that the media attitude at previous summits was affected by the preparation and presentation of the food,'' said Ben Love, a retired bank chairman who helped organize the media center. But Houston was miffed when the three television networks turned a cold shoulder to hot Houston and chose not to broadcast their news shows from the summit, a snub that was front-page news locally. And when Whitmire and some pillars of the community staged a 9 a.m. summit news conference Tuesday in an auditorium that can hold more than 1,000 people, 50 civic boosters outnumbered the handful of reporters. ``I've heard ... you (reporters) stay up pretty late at night and maybe don't get up so early in the morning,'' Love said. ``This may be some confirmation of that.'' No matter. The tiny turnout wasn't cause for concern. ``When I see 10 or 11 television cameras across the back of the room, I'm very much aware of the potential they have for reaching very large numbers of people,'' Whitmire said. ``You don't have to have large numbers to impress me.'' Past summit cities have found fame to be fleeting and the economic impact of the event to be overrated. But Houston was undeterred. A group of business and city leaders raised more than $10 million to host the summit. About $250,000 is being spent on a ``food pavilion'' _ buffet tables available to reporters 24 hours a day. Whitmire says it's been a smart investment. ``I don't think I could put a dollar figure on the value of the international attention that this community is receiving,'' she said. ``I think it certainly will be many times over the amount that's been invested. I can assure you of that.'' However, not everyone was thrilled about the summit. Houston City Councilman John Goodner told reporters Tuesday, ``I've had about all the honor of this I can stand.'' ``In light of all the things that are going on, how difficult it is to transverse this city, I would hope the next time that President Bush or any other president wants to honor us, I hope he honors Dallas,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Twice in Two Weeks; Is Summitry Wearing Thin?
DOC.TEXT: Anthems played, flags unfurled, videotape rolled. And then the leaders of the Western world shook hands _ yet again. If the small talk was running thin, it didn't show. President Bush and several other summit leaders had been through all the pomp and ceremony less than a week ago. That was at the NATO gathering in London. For the four European leaders here, Houston was the third time in three weeks that they've lined up for group photographs, attended state banquets and pondered weighty communiques. Britain's Margaret Thatcher, West Germany's Helmut Kohl, Italy's Giulio Andreotti and France's Francois Mitterrand began the long summer of summitry in the Irish capital, Dublin, with a European Community summit at the end of June. Only Japan's Toshiki Kaifu added a fresh face in Houston. Economic summits were once a highlight of the year, a rare chance to hobnob with allied peers and walk the world stage. But with the upheaval in Eastern Europe and accelerating moves toward closer unity among the West Europeans, summits have become almost routine. During the Bush administration there have already been two summits of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The European Community, holding regular ``emergency summits,'' has virtually doubled its regular six-monthly meetings. The dynamics are changing. But in the view of some analysts, the lack of novelty doesn't diminish the significance. ``I think summits are more important now,'' said Robert Hormats, a vice president of Goldman Sachs International, who from 1975 to 1982 was the U.S. economic ``sherpa,'' the aide who prepares the president's agenda for summits. ``During the Cold War period, security concerns bound us together in the West,'' he said. ``Now these will no longer be as strong and you need something to bind _ and these will be economic issues if they are managed correctly.'' Hormats also sees summits as a discipline against insularity and, for an economically less dominant United States, an important forum for wielding influence through consensus. ``It keeps them all constructively engaged in the global system because they know if they are not, someone will raise the point when they next meet _ it's a collective peer pressure exercise,'' he said. It has also become a lot less formal behind the closed doors, according to aides to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. She should know. She's the Western world's longest serving leader and Houston was her 12th economic summit. In the beginning she routinely turned up at summits in combative moods and often became the center of a dispute, particularly with her fellow Europeans. ``But over the years she has come to recognize the value of summits,'' said an aide, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The leaders do get to know each other and now it's become easier. It has also become a lot less predictable.'' But what do they actually do, apart from talk? C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Washington-based Institute for International Economics and a former senior U.S. Treasury official, said that in the 1980s the economic summits drifted into general political issues and became ``a lot less action-oriented.'' ``In my view they deteriorated enormously,'' said Bergsten. ``I really hope and think there's a chance that this first one of the 90s will go back ... to make some headway on a few concrete issues,'' he added, citing farm subsidies, free trade and Soviet aid. But Hormats, like many observers, thinks the summits could use a lot fewer words, ceremonials, photo opportunities and the blow-by-blow briefings that officials give to the hundreds of reporters who gather round. ``It would be a lot better if they changed these laundry-list communiques ... covering every conceivable issue,'' Hormats said. ``And in my view, these summits will have come of age when there doesn't need to be so much hoopla.'' Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the leaders, comfortable with one another, hashed out most of the issues themselves _ rather than relying on aides. ``The issues they've dealt with in this summit have been real and dealt with by the heads at the table in a more direct way than any I've ever seen,'' said Fitzwater, who has been to five economic summits. For the summiteers, there's no relief in sight. The European Community has already scheduled an extra meeting in October. NATO has invited President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to speak, perhaps this year. And a really big summit _ a mass gathering of the 35 nations of East and West in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe _ is expected before year's end.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Maureen Johnson, of the AP's London bureau, covers British politics and is a veteran reporter of Western summits.

DOC.HEAD: Most Cosmetic Surgery for Military Retirees, Dependents Halted
DOC.TEXT: Most cosmetic surgery to improve the appearance of military dependents, retirees and their dependents will be halted at military hospitals under a new Defense Department policy. But such procedures will not be totally barred for active-duty military personnel, a Pentagon spokeswoman said Tuesday. Such operations will be conducted ``only on a very limited basis,'' said spokeswoman Susan Hansen. ``It will be done on the lowest priority and there must be no other requirement for the surgical theater at the time.'' The Pentagon reviewed its policy on procedures such as facelifts, breast enlargements and liposuctions after receiving an inquiry from Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the House Appropriations defense subcommittee. In April, the San Diego Tribune reported that the San Diego Naval Hospital _ one of four Navy hospitals with an extensive plastic surgery department _ had performed 544 cosmetic procedures in the past two years, and that Air Force and Army hospitals performed similar cosmetic surgeries. Pentagon officials have argued that it is important for military surgeons to perform such procedures as part of their training. But following a review of the legislative history of the policy, Defense Department officials decided that ``a better interpretation'' of the legislation governing such procedures was needed, Ms. Hansen said. ``Consequently, facelifts and other procedures relating to the aging process and any procedure performed for personal, non-therapeutic reasons to improve the appearance will not be provided for active-duty dependents or retirees and their dependents using appropriated funds,'' a Pentagon statement said. Surgeries for the correction of a congenital abnormality, reconstructive surgery following an injury or surgical or therapeutic trauma, and post-mastectomy breast reconstruction will be allowed, the statement added. Ms. Hansen said the military services will develop procedures ``to assure that surgical residents and staff can meet the requirements'' of certification by their the medical specialty boards. The new regulations are expected to be identical to those procedures covered under the Civilian Health and Medical Program for the Uniformed Services, the insurance program known as CHAMPUS that allows service members and their dependents to receive health care in private facilities, Ms. Hansen said. CHAMPUS doesn't cover purely cosmetic surgery.

DOC.HEAD: Caterer Makes Makes Summit Easy to Stomach
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Forget about the thornier negotiations between the economic summit partners. Jackson Hicks, master caterer, knows what real pressure is. Pressure is serving lunch to the most powerful leaders in the Western world. No dropped trays. No splashy food. No hard-to-eat entrees. Nothing that might embarrass a president, or hinder a negotiation, or interrupt a profound thought. ``I've enjoyed taking care of many important people in my career _ kings, queens, presidents, movie stars, businessmen,'' Hicks said. ``But nothing was more challenging and exciting than taking care of those world leaders.'' Hicks, 43, might be considered the man who catered the summit. His Houston company put on 13 meals and parties, from a 5,000-person media festival to a working lunch for the leaders. He's averaged less than two hours of sleep a night through the summit, which ends today with a party to thank Houston hosted by President Bush and catered by Hicks. ``We're used to pressure, but this has been a very intense thing because of who these people are and because of the short window of time,'' Hicks said. ``Everything's been on scheduled and come off without a hitch'' _ except for one flat tire on the way to a spouses' dinner, where Barbara Bush was host. It hasn't been easy. Intense security measures, especially when moving around the Rice University campus, has doubled preparation times, Hicks said. And Tuesday, his 170 workers served three working luncheons at once. ``You have to make the food simple, not flashy, and not difficult to eat. You want to be unobtrusive. They can't carry on an important conversation if they're trying to crack a lobster open,'' he said. ``This isn't the time to bring out some flaming desert on the shoulders of a team of waiters.'' Hicks thinks the White House tapped him for the job because of his company's reputation and experience _ he's catered at the 1988 Winter Olympics, last year's Super Bowl, major Texas celebrations and previous dinners for Bush. It didn't hurt, too, that many of his regular clients are personal friends of the Bush family. Hicks, a tall man with gray hair curling to his shoulders, was a wine buyer for the exclusive Neiman-Marcus retail chain before striking out on his own in 1981. His cooks, bartenders and waiters all worked the same frenzied hours as he did. They prepared 4,000 gulf oysters, 562 pounds of beef fajitas, 1,000 bobwhite quail, 10,000 live crawfish and 200 pounds of venison sausage. He won't discuss what his food budget was, and until Tuesday, couldn't even tell others he was working on the summit, let alone what he planned to serve, for security reasons. Hicks served lots of grilled beef and chicken and tea sandwiches. Fresh fruits and vegetables were popular with the Western leaders, as were cold menus on hot Houston afternoons, he said. While the issues on the tables of the Rice University meeting rooms were intensely argued, Hicks came away impressed at how friendly the leaders seemed to each other. ``Many of these people have known each other for a long time. They just seemed relaxed with one another. The pictures and ceremonies appeared formal, but inside, they weren't formal,'' Hicks said. ``I was very impressed with the graciousness and warmth to one another.''

DOC.HEAD: Gunfire, Roadblocks Make Nicaraguan Capital Scene of Chaos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with soldiers hurt outside radio station, UPDATES death toll to 4. Picks up 6th pvs, `The presidents ...' ^LaserPhoto NY19, MGA1,2,3,4
DOC.TEXT: Central American presidents called for foreign support of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro on Tuesday as a Sandinista-led strike turned Managua into a chaos of gunfire and roadblocks. The wave of strikes that began last week has put the heaviest pressure yet on the 10-week-old, U.S.-backed administration. Mrs. Chamorro called out the army late Monday to restore order. Both the army and police are controlled by the leftist Sandinistas, who ruled until April 25 and remain the largest single political force in Nicaragua. Gunfire died down Tuesday morning, but by afternoon scattered shooting resumed between Sandinistas and Chamorro supporters, who included leaders of the disbanded Contra rebels. In once incident, one Sandinista soldier was shot and wounded and another beaten Tuesday afternoon outside a radio station being used as a headquarters by armed civilians opposed to the general strike. The soldiers were passing by the pro-administration Radio Corporation building in eastern Managua when they were attacked, and the wounded soldier was taken to the hospital. The Sandinista opposition blames the Contras for the fighting, which the Nicaraguan Human Rights Commission said had clamed four lives and left at least 84 people injured sinced the strike began on June 26. The violence began on Friday. The presidents of Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica and Honduras issued a joint communique Tuesday ``calling on the international community to lend its valuable assistance to the Nicaraguan government in its search for a solution to the crisis it is undergoing.'' Honduran government spokesman Martin Baide gave The Associated Press a copy of the declaration, which he said was being simultaneously released in the other Central American countries. Asked whether the United States was providing any technical or intelligence assistance to Mrs. Chamorro, Secretary of State James A. Baker III would not talk about any specifics. ``We've been very helpful to Mrs. Chamorro in the past,'' said Baker, speaking at a news conference in Houston, where he was attending the summit of the seven largest industrial democracies. ``And it goes without saying that we would want to be helpful in securing democracy in Nicaragua ... so we would want to be helpful.'' Sandinista radio stations Radio Sandino and Radio Ya charged Tuesday that Contra leaders were directing armed groups of urban commandos. Reporters identified leaders of the Contras _ the rebels supported by the United States while the Sandinistas were in power _ among the armed groups. The Contras have been turning in their weapons under supervision of the United Nations and the Organization of American States, and Mrs. Chamorro has declared their nine-year resistance at an end. Police and soldiers tore down roadblocks in Managua and cleaned up after street bonfires Tuesday, but strikers still occupied government ministries and state-owned businesses in the city of about 1 million people. Strike sympathizers built even more roadblocks to replace those taken down. Whether the army and police will back Mrs. Chamorro's new government or let the strike widen is considered crucial in the outcome of the walkouts, now in their second week. ``We mustn't repress the people,'' one policeman said. The Sandinistas lost the presidential election to Mrs. Chamorro on Feb. 25, ending 10 years of revolutionary rule of this country of 3.7 million residents. The U.S. economic embargo, which helped create shortages even in basic foodstuffs, contributed to their defeat. Mrs. Chamorro won with the backing of a 14-party coalition that ranged from far right to Communist, and had little more in common than a distaste for the Sandinistas. The U.S. trade sanctions and a long war against the U.S.-supported Contra rebels devastated the economy before Mrs. Chamorro took office, and her reconstruction efforts have stirred resentment and opposition. Sandinista-led unions called the strike to protest what they said were massive firings of government workers and to demand a voice in government economic policy, which they say favors the wealthy under the new government. Labor leaders say 90,000 people are taking part in the strike. Mrs. Chamorro's government declared the action illegal last week, claiming it was politically motivated. Gunfire spread from eastern Managua's working-class neighborhoods to the central section at the offices Radio Corporation. The armed civilians who barricaded themselves there said they were protecting the station from Sandinistas who wanted to burn it. They said they tended up to 20 wounded in the radio station but there had been no deaths. Many pro-Sandinista groups at the roadblocks carry Soviet-bloc AK-47 assault rifles, standard issue in the Sandinista army. Thousands of AK-47s were distributed to Sandinista sympathizers after the February election defeat. Government demands for return of the weapons were largely ignored. Strikers have taken over most government ministries and many state-run enterprises. The international airport is closed by an air controllers' strike and water has been cut to parts of the city. Electrical service was restored Tuesday but workers said they would start selective cuts around the city. Postal workers and telephone operators are on strike, leaving the relatively few Nicaraguans with direct-dial capacity the only ones who can communicate outside the country. Driving was difficult in some areas, impossible in others, because of barricades. Hundreds of factories and businesses shut down Monday because employees could not get to work. Some walked to their jobs. ``I will have to walk several kilometers to my job,'' said Marta Gonzalez, a household maid. ``If I don't work, I don't eat.'' Former President Daniel Ortega said any effort to end the strike by force would invite ``generalized chaos.'' He demanded a resumption of negotiations, suspended by the government over the weekend because it said union leaders wanted to discuss political, not economic issues.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Campaign to Focus on Government's Prosecution
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Harold Ford is going after prosecutors, not politicians, as the eight-term congressman runs his second re-election campaign under federal indictment. Tennessee's only black member of Congress, Democrat Ford contends he is a victim of Justice Department lawyers with a taste for prosecuting black leaders. ``They don't have the funds to investigate the savings and loan industry, but they have the funds to investigate me twice,'' Ford said in an interview. ``I'm going to put the prosecutors on trial during this campaign.'' Ford was indicted on bank and mail fraud charges in 1987 and was on trial for 11 weeks in U.S. District Court in Memphis. A mistrial was declared in April when jurors said they were unable to reach a verdict. Prosecutors say a second trial will be held but no date has been set. Ford and his backers liken his legal troubles to government investigations of Washington Mayor Marion Barry, Rep. William Gray, D-Pa., New York Mayor David Dinkins and other prominent black politicians. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has taken up that argument on Ford's behalf, as has Jesse Jackson. ``It's not just these leaders on trial,'' Jackson said at a recent rally in Memphis. ``It's the Justice Department on trial.'' Ford, 45, is a strong favorite for re-election. He faces state Rep. Pam Gaia and perennial candidate Mark Flanagan in the Aug. 2 Democratic primary. Aaron Davis, a 79-year-old political newcomer, will represent the Republicans in November. Isaac Richmond, an independent Ford already has defeated several times, also is running. Ford said his legal troubles have done little to undermine his political standing but the financial and emotional toll has been high. ``They won't be able to hurt me politically, but financially, this has been a drain,'' he said. ``It's been very difficult.'' Ford is accused of taking payoffs disguised as loans from former bankers Jake and C.H. Butcher Jr., who in 1983 set off the largest banking collapse in Tennessee history. Ford said he expects his legal expenses to approach $2 million. Since his indictment, Ford has used about $350,000 in political contributions for his legal defense, campaign records show. Ford also has raised more than $380,000 through a legal defense fund called ``Trust Ford.'' The Republicans have not made a serious run for Ford's seat since 1976 when he defeated a popular city councilman with 61 percent of the vote. In 1988, while under indictment, he drew no Republican opposition and collected 80 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary and in the general election. Ford is the most prominent member of a large family that has long been active in Memphis politics. His brother, John, is a state senator who also is running this year for county tax collector. Another brother, James, is a city councilman. Ford directs a political organization that can turn out the vote on Election Day. Many of his followers, especially those who are poor and black, are fiercely loyal. His complaints of Justice Department bias will play well with the voters, said the Rev. Samuel Kyles, a Ford supporter and longtime Memphis civil rights leader. ``They'll respond to it because it is so clear,'' Kyles said. Ford's district, which includes most of Memphis, is 58 percent black. Black registered voters slightly outnumber whites citywide. A champion of traditional Democratic causes, Ford has a reputation for helping constituents with their personal problems, whether they are dealing with federal agencies or local government. Ford, who was indicted in Knoxville in primarily white eastern Tennessee, claims he was ``judicially kidnapped.'' He says he would not have been charged by a grand jury in Memphis. Prosecutors contend Ford has so inflamed his followers that finding an impartial jury for a second trial may be impossible unless it is moved out of Memphis. Ford is widely considered a likely candidate for mayor of Memphis if he can get the bank fraud indictment behind him. He says he was preparing to announce a bid for mayor when he was indicted.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 11 Members of Medellin Cocaine Cartel
DOC.TEXT: Police delivered a major blow to the Medellin cocaine cartel Tuesday, arresting 11 of its members in a northeastern town and seizing arms including more than 3{ tons of dynamite, officials said. Among those arrested was the personal physician of Pablo Escobar, the cartel's leader, according to a national police report read over the RCN radio network. The suspected cartel members were arrested in the town of Puerto Triunfo, about 75 miles east of Bogota, the police report said. It said police also captured one of Escobar's relatives, Hernan Dario Quintero, who reportedly supplied dynamite and weapons to gunment hired to carry out the cartel's bombing and assassination campaigns. The report added that police seized several Soviet-made AK-47 automatic rifles, revolvers, 7,700 pounds of dynamite, sophisticated communications equipment and documents that could lead to Escobar's capture. RCN did not give details about the other alleged cartel members arrested in the raid. The national police press office did not answer calls by The Associated Press late Tuesday seeking more information. Escobar, who has been blamed for the murder of hundreds of Colombians, remains at large despite a massive manhunt to find him. The government and drug traffickers have been locked in a war since August, when traffickers were blamed for the assassination of a popular presidential candidate. Bombings and assassinations blamed on drug thugs have since claimed several hundred lives, while the government has pressed on with its effort to capture and extradite drug suspects to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Are Gotten Rid of More Easily Than Pollution
DOC.TEXT: Tatana Maresova has sworn off meat as long as she is breast-feeding. From the newspapers, now free of censorship, she knows meat is often contaminated with harmful substances. Emissions from chemical plants, coal-burning industry and two-cylinder cars guzzling a mixture of oil and gasoline have polluted the air, made much of the country's water unfit to drink and seeped into the food chain. Heavy industry was the measure of success during Communism rule, when leaders did not concern themselves with environmental protection. Czechoslovakia has soem of the worst environmental damage in the East bloc. Marcela Peskova worries about the store-bought milk she gives her two daughters. ``I know they get pollutants, but without it they couldn't grow,'' she says, casting an anxious glance at Kristina, 5, and Pavlina 4. Both mothers routinely boil the water their family drinks and try to buy bottled mineral water for the babies. ``More than 50 percent of the water is not suitable for drinking,'' says Josef Vavrousek, the man in charge of environmental matters in the new government. ``More than half the population is drinking damaging water.'' Vavrousek is trying to assess the damage caused by heavy industry and devise a viable program for solving environmental problems. How long could that take? ``I think all my life,'' he says, only half joking. But he believes it is possible to ``make very important improvements in two, three or five years.'' The first freely elected government in four decades has been dubbed the ``government of national sacrifice'' by President Vaclav Havel. While it wants to clean up the environment, it also has the unpopular task of closing down money-losing industry and making the economy more responsive to the laws of supply and demand. ``If the economy is not improved, the environment can't be either,'' Vavrousek said. For the mothers raising their children in polluted Prague or the heavily industrialized regions of northern Bohemia and Moravia, pollution is a fact of life. The Lidova Demokracie daily recently quoted experts as saying the milk of women between 18 and 34 is contaminated by PCBs, DDT, and other toxic materials. The newspaper quoted a veterinarian as saying that under the Communists, experts had tried to inform the government about PCB contamination of meat, but the problems were disregarded. In the health field, a re-evaluation is under way now that the Communists are out. ``Everything is in a state of upheaval,'' said Dr. Alena Chyska, head of the Department for the Care and Development of the New Generation in the Health Ministry. Ms. Chyska said birth defects and other health problems appeared more common in heavily polluted areas, where children were also more likely to contract respiratory-related illnesses and allergies. Until conditions improve, residents of Prague and other polluted areas must rely largely on their own resources to protect their health. ``If I had money, I would buy a country place,'' said Ms. Peskova. Ms. Maresova is luckier. Her parents live in the countryside. Her 6-month-old baby Michal was born with respiratory problems, but his health improved after several months at her parents' place in the mountains in Slovakia. Her parents now raise vegetables in their garden. ``With the baby, we need uncontaminated food,'' Maresova explained, as her 7-year-old son Tomas fidgeted next to her on the park bench. Did she miss taking some precautions with her first-born because media discussion of enviromental problems was taboo under the Communists? ``When my first child was growing up, really important information seemed to seep through,'' she says. Vavrousek's No. 1 priority is to improve the quality of water and food, first of all seeing that there is a good distribution of bottled water. But muzzling sulphur-belching factories with filters won't be easy. It is costly and requires technology not available in Czechoslovakia. Plenty of Western companies have offered to help plug the pollution hemorrhage. ``We've gotten hundreds of offers,'' Vavrousek said in an interview in the offices he has occupied for just eight weeks. ``But we have two problems. We don't have the experience to decipher the options, or the money to buy it.''

DOC.HEAD: Bailout Officials to Try to Seize S&Ls Before Failures
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan bailout officials are shifting strategy and trying to save taxpayers' money by closing troubled thrifts just before, rather than after, the institutions fail. The board of the Resolution Trust Corp. voted 4-0 Tuesday to adopt the ``accelerated resolutions program.'' It will become the ``preferred course of action'' for handling failing thrifts, RTC Chairman L. William Seidman said. Officials estimate they could use the program for between 155 and 180 of the 260 S&Ls expected to fail over the next year. They plan to see how it works with 10 institutions over the summer. Previously, the trust corporation's tactic has been to seize an insolvent institution, appoint a government managing agent to rein in any highflying practices and sell the S&L to whoever offers to accept the least amount of government aid. The problem is that the last step was coming months, sometimes more than a year, after the initial seizure. In the meantime, longtime depositors and key employees were fleeing the institution, reducing its value as an ongoing business. Under the new program, the agency hopes it will be able to spend fewer taxpayer dollars by finding a buyer before an institution is stigmatized as failed. The method is similar to how the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. handles commercial banks in trouble. Rather than publicly advertise for bids, the RTC will solicit proposals for still-open, but weak, S&Ls from a list of about 3,500 investors who have expressed an interest in acquiring failed institutions. When a buyer is selected, the institution will be closed and immediately reopened, relieving the new owners of legal claims against the old institution. The old shareholders will lose their investment. The old managers will keep or lose their jobs depending on whether they played a part in causing the institution to fail. Generally, if no buyer is found within 90 days, the institution will be seized by the government. ``This is a program designed to sell institutions in the most efficient and quickest manner possible ... with the least possible deterioration in value,'' Seidman said. Private analysts cautiously endorsed the strategy, although they noted that the RTC has yet to deal with nearly 250 institutions that failed previously. It has handled more than 200 failed thrifts in its first 11 months. ``I think in principle it's a good idea. The only question is whether they are so overloaded now with all the clearly insolvent institutions,'' said Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution, a liberal-oriented Washington think tank. ``You're going to be using scarce resources for (marginally insolvent) thrifts ahead of other institutions that are clearly in much worse shape,'' he said. However, Litan said taxpayers might save money by bailing out an institution on the edge of insolvency, when its owners may be most tempted to gamble. A deeply insolvent S&L under government control often is not in danger of further deterioration, he said. ``If you're in the government, the thing to do is not to focus on past losses but to focus on how to prevent future losses from occurring,'' he said. Auburn University economist James Barth said the program might be a better way of handling the loans, real estate and other assets of a failed thrift. In the conventional S&L bailouts so far, the government has been stuck with about half of the assets, which it hopes to sell later. Officials hope that in accelerated resolution deals, the new owner rather than the government will get most of the assets. ``The RTC has so many assets it has to try new and different things to get those assets back into the private sector,'' Barth said. ``If they're not careful, they're going to wind up with the world's largest troubled savings and loan and it's going to be called the Resolution Trust Corp.''

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Bradley Ad Could Boost Donor List
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey Sen. Bill Bradley is mixing policy with politics in a new TV campaign ad that encourages people to pick up the phone and let the Democratic candidate know where they stand. Political consultants say the ad, which began running this week, is a smart way to get constituents involved and could help the two-term Democrat identify potential donors to be solicited for campaign contributions. The ad, running on cable television in New Jersey, invites viewers to call a toll-free number to register their views on Bradley's proposal to ban leaded gasoline, or to request a brochure on the dangers of lead poisoning. Democratic consultant Gary Nordlinger said constituents who call the number and leave their names and addresses could be added to a ``fund-raising file'' for the senator's re-election id. During the 30-second commercial, Bradley doesn't appeal for votes or money _ only for opinions on his proposed Lead Ban Act of 1990. In the ad, Bradley is seated in a kitchen and tells viewers: ``An alarming number of children all over New Jersey have high levels of toxic lead in their blood. I first recognized this was a serious health hazard when I wrote the law to ban the use of lead in new drinking water systems. ``Now I think we should ban the sale of leaded gasoline immediately. What do you think? Should we?'' Viewers are invited to call an 800-number to register support or opposition to the proposed ban by pushing the appropriate number on their phone. Opponents and supporters alike are asked to leave mailing information on the tape if they want a brochure on lead poisoning. GOP political consultant Jim Weber called the ad a ``smart tactic'' that allows the incumbent senator to make a smooth transition into campaign activity. The ad could attract support from ``ticket splitters and middle of the road folks,'' Weber said. ``It's an interactive measure which to me is quite clever,'' said Democratic consultant Peter Hart. Bradley aides said the ad was not designed with fundraising in mind. The senator is heavily favored for re-election and has raised more than $10.1 million. ``We have no plans to use this information to generate money,'' said campaign spokesman Bob McHugh. ``What this is about is protecting kids in New Jersey.'' Bradley's GOP opponent, Christine Todd Whitman, called the ad and accompanying brochure a self-promotional gimmick. ``Bill Bradley's attempt to promote awareness of this issue is sleight of hand at best and manipulation at its worst,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Activist Remembered by Homeless, Celebrities
DOC.TEXT: The gathering and message at Mitch Snyder's funeral were like those that marked his life _ a mass of homeless people with a few celebrities sprinkled in, all getting a hefty dose of social gospel. ``Mitch loved the poor with an unquenchable and sustained fire,'' antiwar priest Phillip Berrigan said Tuesday of the militant advocate for the homeless. ``Now all of us must do as Mitch did, work to end injustice.'' Snyder, 46, was found hanged last week in the shelter he helped create, an apparent suicide. A note found nearby spoke of problems in his relationship with his longtime companion, Carol Fennelly. But the celebrities, politicians and activists who remembered him before 3,000 people at a tearful two-hour, outdoor funeral chose to concentrate on his commitment to the downtrodden and his political activism. ``He found people to be beautiful and worthwhile that everybody else seems to have written off,'' said singer-actress Cher, who spent several holidays serving food at feasts for the homeless organized by Snyder. ``It must truly be, `Love thy neighbor as thyself,' and ... Mitch lived that.'' ``He leaves us here to tell the story that America's dream is incomplete,'' civil rights leader Jesse Jackson said in a eulogy. `Until the hungry are fed and the homeless are housed. ... we will not surrender _ the work continues.'' Snyder was cremated after the services outside his 1,200-bed shelter and a protest march to Washington's city hall behind the horse-drawn carriage bearing his casket. His remains will be kept inside the shelter along with the ashes of homeless people, many of them anonymous, who died on the streets of the capitals. At the government building, Snyder's followers from the Community for Creative Non-Violence blocked doors to protest the city council's decision last month to scale back a law guaranteeing shelter to all who need it. Thirty-seven people were charged with unlawful entry and released without bail, police said. Snyder ``was a politician, he lived it, he dressed it,'' said Fennelly, his companion and shelter co-founder. ``For those of you here today who are a little uncomfortable with the political aspect ... that was Mitch.'' Speakers at the service played down Snyder's personal problems. ``How he died ... really does not matter,'' Jackson said. ``How he lived is all that matters. He left on his terms, an authentic suffering servant.'' ``We get weak sometimes and we blame it on our friends, the ones we love,'' said comedian and social activist Dick Gregory. ``Every now and then, us men get weak moments. Sometimes we make it through and sometimes we don't.'' Mayor Marion Barry, often the target of Snyder's criticism over spending on the homeless, said, ``Some try to figure out how Mitch died, why Mitch died. I'd rather concentrate on how Mitch lived.'' Actor Martin Sheen, who played Snyder in a television movie about Snyder's 1984 hunger strike that gained the downtown shelter building, said Snyder ``embodied one of the favorite sayings of Robert Kennedy: That one man with courage is a majority.''

DOC.HEAD: Summit Leaders Struggle to Break Deadlock on Farm Subsidies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 8 grafs to give wording of possible compromise on agriculture issue, picks up 5th graf pvs, The dispute over ...
DOC.TEXT: Summit leaders struggled to break a deadlock in a U.S.-European fight over billions of dollars in farm subsidies with indications early Wednesday morning that negotiators were closing in on a possible agreement. Officials close to the negotiations, who spoke on conditition that they not be named, said the language being discussed would provide for cuts in farm subsidies in each of the three areas singled out by the United States. The language being considered would call for ``substantial, progressive reductions'' in subsidies in the areas of export subsidies, internal price supports and barriers to imports. The United States had insisted that all three areas be covered in an agreement, a position that had been opposed by the European Community. However, the draft language also made reference to the European Community's more general approach which would measure a country's total trade subsidies and then work to reduce that level, thus giving each side bargaining space in upcoming talks later this month in Geneva. One source said that while this was the language being considered for inclusion in the final communique to be read by President Bush later Wednesday, negotiators had by no means resolved the issue. ``They are going through the proposal line by line,'' the source said. ``There is still much time left in the evening.'' Before the trade negotiators began their late night discussions, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said it was uncertain whether the United States would achieve its goal of language committing countries to across-the-board reductions. ``The farm subsidy question is still an open one,'' Fitzwater said. The dispute over farm subsidies and to a lesser extent discussion over Soviet aid required the leaders to spend an extra 90 minutes in their afternoon meeting. In addition to Bush, leaders from Britain, Japan, West Germany, Canada, France, Italy and a representative from the European Community were participating in the talks. If the economic summit fails to achieve strong language on the farm subsidy issue, it would be a significant setback for the Bush administration, which sees resolution of the issue as critical to getting global trade talks back on track. While the United States for three years has been trying to get a commitment to eliminate the $245 billion rich countries spend to subsidize farmers, the European Community has been opposed, contending that 3 million of its farmers could lose their jobs. The 12 nations of the EC have a total of 10 million farmers compared with 2 million in the United States. The European Community has insisted that it was willing to reduce the aggregate total of farm subsidies, but did not want to commit to cutbacks in each separate area sought by the United States. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher submitted a compromise proposal in an effort to bridge the gap but it was rejected by the United States as unacceptable, officials said, even though it attracted considerable support from other European countries. Britain, which has few small-scale farmers, is the most willing of the Europeans to compromise with the United States and sought to mediate in the summit talks. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said the delegations would continue discussing the farm dispute late into the night. He described the debate on agriculture as a ``vigorous discussion'' among all the countries involved. President Bush's battle to eliminate farm subsidies worldwide over the next decade had appeared to receive a boost on Monday when West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl signaled his willingness to accept a U.S.-backed proposal as a starting point for negotiations. U.S. officials expressed hope that remaining differences could be resolved so that the summit countries would be able to give guidance to their trade negotiators in Geneva. Resolving the farm question is seen as critical to successful completion of a nearly four-year effort to overhaul the global trading system. That effort, known as the Uruguay Round for the country where the talks were launched, is being conducted by the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The United States, which has posted six consecutive years of trade deficits topping $100 billion, has a lot riding on the effort. By removing trade barriers, the administration believes a new GATT pact would greatly expand export opportunities for American businesses and farmers, thus lowering the U.S. trade deficit. The basis for possible compromise in Houston revolved around a recent outline for a final agreement issued by Aart de Zeeuw of the Netherlands, the chairman of the GATT agricultural negotiating group. That proposal calls for significant reductions in subsidies for exports, in domestic support payments to farmers and the removal of barriers to agricultural imports. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl expressed support for the de Zeeuw proposal on Monday, giving hope to the Americans that they might be able to convince other European countries to compromise on the issue. But European Community officials, who have been lobbied hard by Americans in Houston, said that while Kohl's comments were significant they did not mean that the other 11 EC countries would go along. The issue of what position to take was certain to be discussed next Monday at a meeting of the community's foreign ministers in Brussels. Bush had declared that the trade issue was his top priority going into the annual economic summit and he argued the point forcefully during private one-on-one meetings as well as the group sessions with his summit partners. The administration pressed the point that the best thing the world's richest countries could do for the developing world was expand trade opportunities, especially in agriculture, the chief export in most of the developing world. Developing countries now lose billions of dollars in sales each year because of $245 billion being spent annually to subsidize farmers by rich countries. U.S. subsidies cost taxpayers and consumers $75 billion annually. The administration believes it can persuade Congress to eliminate the farm supports over time if other countries do so as well since U.S. farmers are among the most efficient in the world. Congress is currently considering a 1990 farm bill which would continue America's farm subsidies. Asked Tuesday if lawmakers might be willing to cut the subsidies if the Houston summit reaches agreement on the issue, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said, ``It is unlikely that Congress would develop a farm program based on some future circumstance that has certainly not yet arrived or not expected to arrive.''

DOC.HEAD: FBI Director's Wife Traveled Free on Government Planes
DOC.TEXT: FBI Director William S. Sessions took his wife on 17 business trips aboard government aircraft but she paid for only one flight, according to a congressional study. The General Accounting Office said its survey of trips aboard government aircraft by Sessions and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh underscores the need for a travel policy covering federal officials and their spouses. ``We continue to believe that a government-wide policy is needed to clarify under what circumstances spouses should be permitted to accompany government officials to official functions aboard government aircraft,'' said the GAO report issued Tuesday. The study of 39 trips aboard government aircraft by Thornburgh and 36 by Sessions between Aug. 11, 1988, and July 31, 1989, was requested by Rep. Bob Wise, D-W.Va. It found that Alice Sessions accompanied her husband on 17 trips to such destinations as San Francisco, New Orleans, Key West, Fla., and Williamsburg, Va. FBI spokesman Robert Davenport said Mrs. Sessions did not pay for the flights, except one, because her husband was traveling on official business. Mrs. Sessions paid $280 for one flight when the couple extended a trip to take care of personal business in San Antonio, Texas, Davenport said. Thornburgh's wife, Ginny, accompanied her husband on six official trips during the period surveyed. In April, five months after the GAO began its inquiry, Thornburgh reimbursed the Justice Department $2,128 to cover the six trips plus two others she took on government aircraft. Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian said Mrs. Thornburgh was not required to pay for her flights, but did so out of ``an abundance of caution.'' Thornburgh also paid the government $1,032 to cover personal trips that he and his family took aboard the aircraft, which were seized from convicted criminals. GAO did not question the propriety of the trips but said the government should examine its travel policy to determine when it is appropriate for officials to take their spouses on official business. The government should consider ``what constitutes an `official purpose' or `official function''' and when it's appropriate for spouses to fly for free, GAO said. In a letter to the Justice Department, Wise criticized the agency for its failure to adopt a travel policy after it had assured him last fall that one was being drafted. Eramian said a policy will be adopted, adding: ``It would have been silly to put something together until we saw what the GAO recommendations were.''
