The GAO also said the Justice Department failed to compare the cost of using the seized aircraft to transport Sessions and Thornburgh with the cost of leasing private aircraft. The watchdog arm of Congress acknowledged that the Justice Department had legitimate concerns about the security of Thornburgh and Sessions. But GAO said ``our analysis indicates that private aircraft services available through lease, charter, or rental arrangements could satisfy the principal security and related concerns better than regularly scheduled airlines.'' The Justice Department did its own analysis after the GAO study began and concluded that it was saving $500,000 a year by using seized aircraft instead of leasing commercial planes. ``If we had leased an aircraft and spent an extra half million a year, we would have received a larger dose of criticism,'' Eramian said.

DOC.HEAD: Textron's $17.9 Million Settlement Lands Windfall for `Whistleblower'
DOC.TEXT: A record-setting fraud settlement by a major government contractor means a $2.7 million windfall for the helicopter company employee who blew the whistle. Robert C. Ballew, 43, of Fort Worth, Texas, sounded like a lottery winner after the Justice Department announced Tuesday that Textron Lycoming agreed to pay the government $17.9 million. The settlement is the largest ever reached under the Justice Department's ``whistleblower'' lawsuit program. The payment to the government, which has already been made, settles a fraud investigation focusing on the Stratford, Conn.-based company's problem-plagued Coast Guard helicopter engines. It translates into a $2.7 million windfall for Ballew _ 15 percent of the total. ``I think anybody would be happy to have the money,'' Ballew said. ``I've still got a lot of bills to pay, kids to send to school; I could sure use the money.'' Ballew was a procurement official with Aerospatiale Helicopter Corp., a French firm that makes the Coast Guard's Dolphin helicopter, when the problems with the engines turned up. He said he decided to sue in May 1988 when he became concerned that he could be jailed because of the chronic engine problems. It was a decision that cost him his job. ``We tried to get the problem cured where I worked,'' he said. ``It seems like they couldn't do enough. When that happened it put me in risk of going to jail.'' Textron was under investigation for providing engines that failed to meet their operating specifications and for fraudulently billing the Coast Guard for repair work, according to the Justice Department. The twin-engine helicopters are used in search-and-rescue and drug interdiction missions. Former Coast Guard Commandant Paul Yost once referred to the engine as ``a lemon.'' A separate investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board turned up 154 ``failures'' of the LTS-101 engine, manufactured by Textron's Lycoming Williamsport, Pa., plant. An NTSB computer list indicated that at least 11 deaths may have been directly related to engine failure, and published reports have placed the estimate as high as 14. The Justice Department's ``whistleblower'' lawsuit program encourages individuals with inside information to sue when fraud or other abuses appear likely. If the evidence is promising, as it was in this case, the government then takes over the case and guarantees the whistleblower a percentage of any settlement. Ballew sued both Textron and his own company. Aerospatiale later was dropped from the investigation for lack of evidence, according to the Justice Department. Investigators said Textron supplied the Coast Guard an engine that was in the shop after an average of only 600 hours of flying time. Specifications called for the engine to put in 2,400 hours in the air between overhauls. Textron issued a statement admitting no wrongdoing but saying it planned to provide a thorough maintenance program and already had made improvements in the engine. Textron also agreed to maintain the engines and supply parts for the next six years and be paid a fee based on the engine flying time. That provision could save the Coast Guard an estimated $60 million, according to the Justice Department. Ballew said he was laid off after filing the suit and has found another job in the aerospace industry. He declined to name his new employer. Does Ballew have plans to spend his fortune? ``What I intend to do is quietly sit at home with my wife and kids,'' he said. The settlement, he said, ``says that maybe my judgment wasn't flawed. That what I saw, what I have been trained to check for and ask questions about, was right.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate OKs Rights Package for Own Staff _ No Court Enforcement
DOC.TEXT: Senate employees would get comprehensive guarantees against job discrimination for the first time under a measure approved by the Senate as it launched its debate on a major civil rights bill. But the plan added to the bill Tuesday would stop short of allowing Senate employees to go to court for enforcement of their rights, prompting complaints that it was out of keeping with the spirit of civil rights. ``It's an appeal to the worst of plantation mentality on Capitol Hill,'' Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa., said in urging a stronger version. Senate employees have traditionally been exempted from fair-hiring and other civil rights guarantees. The Senate itself would handle civil rights complaints from its employees under the plan, sponsored by Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky. But it would guarantee them rights under three laws passed over the last 25 years and two currently pending, including the bill now under debate. Provisions of the bill _ which tops the congressional agenda of civil rights forces _ range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to a prohibition against discriminatory seniority systems. The Bush administration, however, has been sharply critical of a provision that would force employers either to end discriminatory practices or prove in court that they were justified by business necessity. The provision would effectively negate a Supreme Court ruling last year in a case involving hiring practices at a salmon cannery in Alaska. The court held that anyone filing such a suit must prove that the discriminatory practice in question was not a business necessity. Critics of the bill say its so-called ``disparate impact'' provisions responding to the ruling would prompt employers to use racial and ethnic hiring quotas to head off lawsuits. Administration officials and Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., the bill's chief sponsor, have been searching for a compromise that would spare President Bush having to veto a civil rights bill and give supporters some of their goals. The negotiations have turned into a fight over shadings of legal definitions, and no visible progress was made Tuesday. White House chief of staff John H. Sununu said in a letter to Kennedy: ``Basically, I continue to fear language that causes more problems than it solves, or language with unintended consequences that would stimulate a quota-based defensive position.'' Kennedy issued a statement saying that ``negotiations are continuing but so far the administration's proposals have not been satisfactory.'' ``Last year's decisions by the Supreme Court have seriously jeopardized the right of millions of women and minorities to equal job opportunity,'' he said. ``Congress should restore the full strength of the antidiscrimination law, not restore them only part way.'' Earlier, Kennedy unveiled a fresh compromise proposal, saying it ``is a mockery of civil rights ... for opponents of this legislation to raise the false hue and cry of quotas.'' But Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, said the plan would ``force business people to proportionately hire, just to save their skins'' and avoid lawsuits. The latest round of modifications were refinements of highly technical language in the bill. For example, the revised version would force those filing suits to single out specific objectionable practices rather than target groups of practices. The new version would change the definition of business necessity from ``essential'' to effective job performance to ``bears a substantial and demonstrable relationship'' to effective job performance.

DOC.HEAD: Study: By 1991, AIDS Fifth Leading Cause of Death Among Young Women
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: AIDS is rapidly rising through the ranks of killers of American women of childbearing age and by next year will probably be the fifth leading cause of death among them, scientists reported today. The AIDS death rate is dramatically higher among young black women than whites, and the disease is far more prevalent in the Northeast than in other regions, the scientists said in the Journal of the American Medical Association. AIDS already claims more black women ages 15 to 44 in New York state and New Jersey than any other health problem, wrote the researchers at the federal Centers for Disease Control. ``We've known how serious the problem is in New Jersey,'' Christine Grand, deputy state health commissioner, said by telephone Tuesday from Trenton. ``However, even those working in the field are shocked to see how high the standing is vis-a-vis all causes of death.'' Nationwide, among women ages 15 to 44, deaths from AIDS soared from 18 in 1980 to 1,430 in 1988, the most recent year for which statistics are available, the researchers said. The death rate quadrupled between 1985 and 1988, when AIDS accounted for 3 percent of all deaths of women in that age group, the researchers said. The report elaborates on CDC findings released in November indicating AIDS had become the eighth leading cause of death among American women of childbearing age. Among all U.S. women ages 15 to 44, the leading causes of death are, in order: cancer, injuries, heart disease, homicide, suicide, strokes and related diseases, liver disease, AIDS, diabetes, flu and pneumonia. ``If current trends continue, AIDS can be expected to become one of the five leading causes of death by 1991'' among women of childbearing age, the researchers said. Because women who have the AIDS virus are the major source of infection for infants, the trends portend disaster for thousands of children, CDC researchers wrote. ``As the number of pediatric cases increases, the medical and social costs will be staggering,'' the report said. Each baby born in poverty who is infected with the virus costs Medicaid $18,000 to $42,000 annually, it said. The disease killed 40.7 black women per 100,000 in New Jersey and 29.5 per 100,000 in New York in 1987, the most recent year for which regional statistics are available, said lead author Susan Y. Chu, a CDC epidemiologist. ``That to me is remarkable, because it exceeds the rates of heart disease and cancer, as well as accidents,'' she said by telephone from Atlanta. Among all women, the AIDS death rates were 9.4 per 100,000 in New Jersey and 9.3 per 100,000 in New York. Nationally, the death rate for black women _ 10.3 per 100,000 _ was nine times the death rate for white women, the researchers said. Regionally, women in the Northeast overall died of AIDS at a rate of 5.3 per 100,000 population, 26 times the rate in the Midwest, the researchers said. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. Three-quarters of women with AIDS-virus infections get them from using intravenous drugs or having sex with intravenous drug users, Ms. Chu said. In 1989, there were 2,825 new cases of AIDS among women of reproductive age, the researchers said. Dr. Howard Minkoff, professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn, said the findings are overwhelming and worrisome. Even more troubling, he said in a telephone interview, is the attitude of white, middle-class Americans whose reaction to such reports is, ``It's still not us.'' Minkoff said 2,000 women infected with the AIDS virus will bear infected babies in the United States this year.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador Returning to Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: The last U.S. ambassador to Cambodia, John Gunther Dean, said today he plans to return to Phnom Penh to help heal the wounds of 20 years of conflict. Dean, now retired from government service, was ambassador when the Khmer Rouge defeated the U.S.-backed Phnom Penh government in 1975. Vietnam drop the Khmer Rouge from power in late 1978 and installed a pro-Hanoi regime. Clutching an American flag, Dean and his staff were evacuated by helicopters April 12, 1975 as the Khmer Rouge closed in on the capital. Dean, who is to fly to Phnom Penh on Thursday and stay about a week, said he would try to arrange a Thai educational exchange and look into the possibility of hotel construction by an Indian company to promote tourism. ``What I can do is to help Cambodia and the people of Cambodia find ways to bring them out of isolation and into cooperation with the rest of the world,'' Dean said in an interview. ``I believe that the time of healing of wounds from 20 years of conflict should be seized,'' he said. Fighting continues between the government of Prime Minister Hun Sen and a three-member guerrilla group that includes the Khmer Rouge, who are supported by China. The two other non-communist groups are backed by the United States. Dean said he was making the trip on behalf of the Bangkok-based Asian Institute of Technology, a highly regarded international institution which trains Asian students in a variety of scientific and technical fields. Following the 1975 Khmer Rouge victory, Cambodia's educated class was virtually eradicated by the ultra-radical communists. The United States has no diplomatic ties with the Vietnam-backed Phnom Penh government and Americans are barred from doing business in the country. During Khmer Rouge rule, hundreds of thousands of Cambodia's 8 million people died from executions, famine and civil unrest. Dean favored a negotiated settlement of the 1970-75 war and clashed with then Secretary of State Henry Kissinger on U.S. policy towards Cambodia. He later served as ambassador to Denmark, Lebanon, Thailand and India. Dean currently resides in France and Switzerland.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Says Report Wrong, Blood Supply Safe
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0461 to fix cycle designation
DOC.TEXT: The American Red Cross disputes a report that it improperly failed to report on AIDS cases possibly transmitted through blood transfusions and federal authorities acknowledge there is no such reporting requirement. Red Cross spokesman Bud Good responded Tuesday in a prepared statement to a report that the Red Cross failed to notify federal authorities about 228 cases in which patients may have gotten AIDS through contaminated blood transfusions. ``The Red Cross has not failed to comply with FDA requirements to report transfusion-associated AIDS cases for the simple reason that there are no such requirements,'' Good said. A low-level FDA report on an inspection of Red Cross' national headquarters in Washington between April 26 and May 25 found that none of the cases had been reported to the agency ``as required.'' But top FDA officials acknowledged Tuesday that the inspection report, which was disclosed in Tuesday's editions of The Philadelphia Inquirer, was incorrect and that there is no federal requirement for the Red Cross to report possible transfusion-related AIDS cases to the FDA. Physicians are supposed to report AIDS cases to the federal Centers of Disease Control. The lower-level FDA inspection report that started the flap said the Red Cross lacks procedures for reviewing and tracking transfusion associated AIDS cases. FDA headquarters said in a statement late in the day that the agency ``will pursue these matters and work to remedy any problems'' raised by the inspection report. However, the FDA said it had reviewed about 50 of the most recent 228 cases of possible transfusion-related AIDS and found that nearly all involved transfusions before AIDS antibody testing began in 1985. ``In the course of the inspection, there was no evidence that any blood that tested positive after 1985 was improperly released,'' the FDA said. The FDA also said that past record-keeping problems of the Red Cross ``do not show an imminent hazard to the blood supply.''

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Says Jail Taught Him Lesson About Legal World
LaserPhoto FA1
DOC.TEXT: A television reporter who spent two weeks in jail for refusing to reveal a confidential source says he will return to the police beat a more informed journalist. Brian Karem was freed Tuesday after the source released him from his vow of confidentiality. ``The First Amendment is first for a reason,'' Karem said. ``It's been an eye-opener.'' Karem, 29, who works for KMOL-TV, was held in contempt of court and sentenced to six months in jail for refusing to identify who helped him obtain a telephone interview last year with jailed murder defendant Henry David Hernandez, who told Karem he shot police officer Gary Williams in self defense in March 1989. Attorneys in the case said they needed to know who arranged the interview to determine whether it was admissible as evidence. Hernandez is charged with his brother, Julian, in the shooting. Karem lost two U.S. Supreme Court bids to remain free while he appealed the contempt-of-court citation. Karem testified Tuesday that his confidential source is Deborah Ledesma, a cousin of the Hernandez brothers. Ms. Ledesma on Monday night released Karem from his promise of confidentiality, which he said he made because the woman feared Hernandez family members. State District Judge Pat Priest sent Karem to jail but released him after Karem handed over notes identifying Ms. Ledesma. Karem, KMOL-TV officials and their attorney, Larry Macon, said lawyers in the Hernandez case were using Karem. ``We've maintained from the beginning that this was unnecessary and the information was readily available to investigators if they just asked. They didn't need to use a reporter as the investigative tool,'' KMOL-TV news director Ron Harig said. Beth Taylor, an assistant district attorney, said it was necessary to pinpoint Karem's contact and said his not revealing the name was ``a waste of time.'' Asked what was most difficult about jail, Karem joked, ``wearing the Bexar County underwear. I tell you, that's not fun.'' Karem, who planned to take off the rest of the week and spend it with his wife Pam, 29, and their 18-month-old son Zachary, said he would go through the experience again to keep a promise to a source. ``I didn't intend to prove anything. I just intended to keep my promise, so I kept my promise,'' Karem said. Karem said support from fellow journalists helped keep his spirits high when he was in jail. ``I can't even describe all the emotions I had when I saw the support that I got,'' he said. A graduate of the University of Missouri journalism school, Karem became a reporter in 1982. He went to work for KMOL-TV in 1988 after working for newspapers and television stations in the Midwest and Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Picnic Cooker Hoses Recalled
DOC.TEXT: A manufacturer of outdoor picnic equipment is recalling hoses for 30,000 smoker-cookers because of possible fire hazards. The Coleman Co., Inc. is recalling hoses that connect propane gas tanks of its ``Cookin' Machines'' to the burner because they may loosen from the valve connection after repeated use, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Tuesday. There have been at least five reported incidents of loosened hoses causing fire damage, said the CPSC. The potentially hazardous hoses are installed on cookers manufactured by the Kansas-based company between November 1987 and March 1989. Consumers should discontinue use of the cookers immediately and contact Coleman at 1-800-835-3278 for instructions on free replacement of the hoses.
DOC.HEAD: Coalition Says More Funds Needed to Stop Deaths from Consumer
DOC.TEXT: Products

A coalition of consumer, health and insurance groups says more federal leadership and money are needed to help prevent 600,000 deaths that result each year from consumer products. In releasing a status report Tuesday, the Coalition for Consumer Health & Safety said 80 percent, or more than 480,000, of those deaths involved cigarettes and alcohol. Among the findings: _47,093 people were killed in motor vehicle accidents in 1988, an increase of 1.5 percent from 1987 when 46,390 died on the nation's roadways and a 0.6 percent rise from the previous year's toll of 46,087. _Falls were the leading cause of fatal accidents in the home, accounting for 6,500 deaths in 1988. Fires were the second-ranked cause, followed by suffocation, poisoning, firearms and drownings. _Cardiovascular disease, one of the key factors for which is diet, killed nearly 1 million Americans in 1987, while nutritional deficiencies caused a reported 2,890 deaths in the United States that year. _Cigarette smoking was responsible for 390,000 deaths in the United States in 1985. Between 1965 and 1987, the proportion of American adults who smoked dropped by 40 percent for men and 21 percent for women. About 49 million Americans still smoke cigarettes. _Alcohol was involved in 90,991 deaths in 1986, up from 88,935 the previous year.
DOC.HEAD: New SDI Chief Named
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has chosen Henry F. Cooper, a former arms control negotiator, to be the new director of the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization. The Pentagon said Tuesday that Cooper will replace Lt. Gen. George Monahan, who retired last week after 35 years of Air Force service. He will be the first civilian to direct the organization, which has been headed by two Air Force generals during its seven-year history. The program, less formally known as ``Star Wars,'' is conducting research into the feasibility of space-based defenses against ballistic missile attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Rural Alaskans Depend on Firefighting for Income
DOC.TEXT: It's peak wildfire season in Alaska, but that's not necessarily a bad thing for some remote villages where jobs are scarce. ``In some villages, firefighting is the single most important source of income in a year,'' said Pete Buist, spokesman for a Fairbanks fire station. More than 200 wildfires have ravaged a half-million acres of interior Alaska this fire season, which began in late June and could run into September. ``There's no economy in the villages,'' said Ron Silas, a former firefighter. ``Fires are quick income. It's cash that supplements hunting and fishing.'' Alaska has more than 70 firefighting crews with 16 members each, most from villages. The firefighters go through at least three days of training to learn such things as how to operate a chain saw, work a water pump and build fire lines. ``Some years, they don't all get to work. But this year everybody who wants to is working,'' Buist said. The federal government calls fire crews to work. Those who have been out of work the longest are called first, he said. Crews from outside Alaska are called only when needed. About 2,500 firefighters from across the United States were on fire lines in Alaska on Tuesday. ``A work crew can earn $2,500 a day or more. They take that money right home to the local economy,'' said Russ Davis, who represents one of several federal firefighting teams flown to Alaska to help with a 41,000-acre fire that threatened the town of Tok, 275 miles northeast of Anchorage. Firefighters earn $11.43 an hour and work as many as 16 hours a day for up to three weeks at a time, Davis said. Crews are provided sleeping bags and meals at state and federal expense. Permanent jobs in rural Alaska are scarce, said Frank Starbuck, a fire crew leader from the Inupiat Eskimo village of Selawik, a village of 680 residents just above the Arctic Circle 375 miles northwest of Fairbanks. ``Firefighting is very important to Selawik. Most guys depend on it during the summer,'' Starbuck said. He led one of two Selawik crews that spent five days this week fighting a blaze at Pedro Dome, about 15 miles north of Fairbanks. The fire charred 900 acres before it was brought under control Monday night. For many rural Alaskans, fire is a mixed blessing. ``I hate to see everything burn up _ the timber and the wildlife. They have their young ones now and I feel bad about that,'' said Molly Galbreath, an Athabaskan Indian from the eastern interior village of Mentasta. ``That's where we get our food.'' But before the fire, Galbreath, 57, had a hard time finding work. She now earns $9 an hour helping out at the Bureau of Land Management's fire station in Tok. ``This will really help for the long winter,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandatory Death Sentence For Traffickers Has Not Proved A Deterrent
DOC.TEXT: A senior police official says the mandatory death sentence for convicted drug traffickers, made law six years ago, has not deterred smugglers and that such sentences should be carried out more quickly. Despite the harsh penalty, the number of people arrested for drug trafficking has instead risen, a newspaper quoted acting Senior Assistant Commissioner Mohamed Said Awang as saying. ``The people who undertake these suicide tasks (drug trafficking) are only mercenaries, who are easily replaced,'' the New Straits Times quoted him as telling a conference on drug treatment. The impact of the mandatory death sentence on the traffickers has been diluted because of those arrested only a few have been convicted, said Mohamed. Of the 3,340 people detained under that law since 1983 only 1,130 were charged in court. Of these, only 197 were found guilty, he said. Other government officials have said that since 1975, when a law was enacted specifying life imprisonment or the death sentence for convicted traffickers, 340 were sentenced to death and 112 of them hanged. The others are awaiting appeals or execution dates. In 1983, the law was changed by parliament to death sentence only. Mohamed said that to make that law more effective hanging should be carried out as soon as possible. He said there is a current lapse of between two and six years from sentencing to execution.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Chuck D., lead singer of the rap group Public Enemy, says white critics who complain about the militant tone of his new album, ``Fear of a Black Planet,'' are just the people who should be listening to it. ``Whites aren't educated about racism because they've benefited from it,'' he said in an interview with the Chicago Tribune before an appearance here this week. ```Fear of a Black Planet' is like feeding baby food to babies _ whites are babies when it comes to racism and they won't study it unless it hits them in the face daily,'' he said. The album has sold nearly 1.5 million copies. Public Enemy performs Thursday at the University of Illinois-Chicago.

Country rocker Steve Earle says songs are literature on wheels. Sort of. ``Songwriting is literature you can read in your car,'' he said in an interview in today's The New York Times. Earle said writers Ernest Hemingway and Graham Greene influenced his life and music. ``I look at them as bookends because to me they're polar opposites,'' he said. Earle's album ``The Hard Way'' was released recently by MCA.

Madonna, Aerosmith, Don Henley and Sinead O'Connor are vying for MTV's video of the year. Nominations for the 1990 MTV Video Music Awards were announced Tuesday. Madonna led with eight nominations for ``Vogue,'' which has her prancing in glamour magazine style. Heavy metal rockers Aerosmith got seven nominations for ``Janie's Got a Gun,'' and dance queen Paula Abdul received six for ``Opposites Attract.'' Former Eagles member Henley and rapper MC Hammer received five nominations each. Henley's ``The End of the Innocence'' and O'Connor's ``Nothing Compares to U'' are up against Madonna and Aerosmith in the video of the year category, one of 21 awards to be doled out Sept. 6 in a ceremony broadcast live from the Universal Amphitheatre.

Patrick Swayze says his new double-hanky tearjerker ``Ghost'' was his heaviest role ever. ``I had to watch my death. I had to see myself in the coffin. I had to be present for my funeral _ really sort of blew me out of the water,'' the actor said in an interview taped for broadcast today on ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' In the movie, Swayze plays Sam Wheat, a New York banker who gets killed, leaving behind fiancee Molly, portrayed by Demi Moore. Swayze, who hit it big in the 1987 movie ``Dirty Dancing,'' says he drew on his own grief upon his father's death in 1982 to play an earthbound ghost. ```Ghost' was the first movie I've ever done that really changed me as a person because it's about taking the love with you after you die,'' he said.

Kirk Douglas was downplaying his movie hero image and talking about his new book when a fire alarm created some live-action adventure. Douglas was in the middle of a newspaper interview last week when an intercom in his 16th-floor hotel suite came alive. ``Remain calm and stay where you are,'' came the repeated warning over the intercom. ``Sure,'' Douglas told his interviewer from the Chicago Tribune. ``Remain calm. The ladders are outside the windows, don't look down.'' It turned out to be a false alarm. ``I didn't plan this drama, you know,'' he said. Douglas, 73, was in town to plug his first novel, ``Dance With the Devil.'' The actor's autobiography, ``The Ragman's Son,'' was made into a movie, and Douglas played himself.

DOC.HEAD: `Dr. Mark and the Sutures' Rock for Charity
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: It's a Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde kind of story, with a musical twist. When the sun goes down, two physicians, a nurse and a former receptionist turn into the rock 'n' roll band Dr. Mark and the Sutures. Several times a year, the Sutures go out in their hospital-green scrub suits and play their favorite Beatles tunes. They donate their performances for charitable causes. ``Doctors and rock music _ it's like wearing tennis shoes with a tuxedo,'' said band founder Dr. Mark Hill. ``There's not a great amount of levity in medicine. So when patients see us in this role, they're shocked,'' said the surgeon from suburban Highland Park. It's a mission that started on a lark. Three years ago Hill agreed to come up with entertainment for a neighborhood block party. Hill, who paid his way through medical school working as a musician, called on a fellow doctor at Highland Park Hospital, a patient and others he knew who also had music as a hobby. For backup singers, they eventually added a nurse from the hospital's obstetrics and gynecology department, a former receptionist from Hill's office and a couple of friends from outside the medical community. Hill, 39, plays guitar and keyboard, and Dr. Ricky Katz, a 34-year-old internist, plays guitar. The backup singers are nurse Patricia Handler, 32, and 27-year-old Vickie Tarbis, the former receptionist who since has become an airline stewardess. ``We meant this as a joke,'' Hill said. ``But there was a huge, huge crowd at the block party. People started coming up to me and calling me and asking me to do shows.'' The Sutures have played performances to raise money for a nursery school, organizations that help the handicapped and other community groups. ``We're seven people who have lives with our families and have professional careers, which take number one priority,'' Hill said. ``But we do this because we enjoy music and because we can help out for worthy causes. And that makes everyone feel good.''

DOC.HEAD: 3- and 4-Year-Olds Found Working in Onion Field
DOC.TEXT: Children as young as 3 years old were found working in violation of child-labor laws, the U.S. Department of Labor said. The department said Tuesday it had documented 238 cases of minors working illegally in Northern California, including one 3-year-old and two 4-year-olds found working in an onion field near Fresno during a June 6 sweep. The children were putting yellow onions in a bucket after their parents had cut off the tops, the department said in a statement. The operator of a labor service was fined $1,200 for four violations of child-labor laws, the department said. The parents and farm owner were not cited. Investigators from the department's Wage and Hour Division found most of the 238 alleged violations during a March 12-14 sting and in follow-up investigations. Most of the violations were in fast-food restaurants. The employers were fined almost $75,000.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Stocks Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar plunged against the Japanese yen Wednesday, while share prices rose moderately. The dollar closed at 148.10 yen, down 1.50 yen from Tuesday's close of 149.60 yen. It opened at 148.42 yen, the lowest opening since Feb. 27, and ranged between 147.65 yen and 148.75 yen. The benchmark Nikkei Stock Average for 225 selected issues gained 141.75 points, or 0.44 percent, closing at 32,294.18. The index shed 385.85 points the previous day. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar was low on a decline overnight in New York and renewed speculation that the Bank of Japan would soon raise its discount rate. The yen firmed after a Washington-based investment advisory firm Smick Medley International predicted Japan's central bank would raise its key rate for loans to commercial banks within the next few months. Japan's discount rate now stands at 5.25 percent, one of the lowest among industrialized nations. The country has been under pressure from its major trading partners to move quicker to lift the rate. The higher rates banks must pay to depositors make it more expensive for them to acquire funds for lending and investment. Foreign exchange dealers in New York said the forecast forced down the dollar's exchange rate against the Japanese currency. Daiwa Bank's Sumio Fukushima said there was little chance that Japan's central bank raise the discount rate in the near future, ``but in the long term, it's a strong possibility.'' Expectations of a statement in the Houston conference of seven industrialized nations favoring a stronger yen were still weighing down the dollar, other dealers said. On the stock exchange, dealers said the surge of the yen against the dollar and solid Japanese bond prices encouraged buying and pushed the share prices up. The price of the No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond stood at 86.78 points, up from Tuesday's close of 86.74. The yield stood at 7.240 percent, down from 7.250 the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Tearful Clay Defends His Humor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 6th graf, ```I broke ...'
DOC.TEXT: A defiant Andrew Dice Clay tossed off criticism that his comedy is racist and sexist, tearfully telling Arsenio Hall's audience that his foul-mouthed routine is a deep expression of belief in himself. Clay appeared on ``The Arsenio Hall Show'' Tuesday night to promote his new film, ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane.'' He faced a walkout by a member of the sydicated television talk show's band and blunt questions from Hall about his brand of shock-comic routine. Keyboardist Starr Parodi said she exercised her right to disagree with Clay's humor by not performing during the show. Clay shrugged off the boycott, saying ``People do what they got to do.'' Then, squaring his shoulders like Elvis Presley, Clay suddenly broke into tears as he faced the studio audience. He said his routine was the product of long, hard work to discover what is funny and true. ``I broke my ass for 12 years ... and tomorrow, when they go to see that movie, they're all going to laugh,'' he declared, his voice cracking with emotion. ``If you want to be a doctor, or if you want to be a lawyer, you don't listen to nobody and you believe in yourself. That's what it's all about.'' Clay is known for expletive-laden routines that contain vulgar references to women, homosexuals and minorities. But he said he is misunderstood by critics, including many fellow entertainers, who say his brand of humor is offensive and hateful. He said his ethnic put-down style is ``just a joke.'' ``This is the greatest country in the world,'' he added. ``We let everybody in, and that gives me more comedic material.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Wind at Houston? Tokyo Gratified at Asian Issues' Prominence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 10 to CORRECT typo. Picks up 11th pvs, `Japan's economy ...' ^With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Government officials today expressed satisfaction at the recognition of Asian issues during the Houston economic summit. One press report found a ``Japanese wind'' blowing at the annual gathering. Though the biggest political issues at the summit were how the West should react to the rapid changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu had been determined to also focus on Asian problems. Aid to China was a major component of the summit political declaration issued Tuesday. The document also cites moves to political openness in Mongolia and Nepal and praises the Philippines government for struggling to uphold democracy. A separate statement read in Houston by Secretary of State James A. Baker III was especially gratifying to the Japanese government because it mentioned Japan's 45-year-old territorial dispute with the Soviet Union. It also sought to encourage dialogue between North Korea and South Korea and expressed concern about North Korea's failure to accept international safeguards aimed at preventing the spread of nuclear weapons. A Foreign Ministry official said Japan appreciated the first mention in a summit statement of Tokyo's demand for the Soviets to return a group of islands in the Kuril chain off northern Japan. ``We hope the Soviet Union will appreciate the weight attached to this message,'' said the official, briefing reporters on condition of anonymity. The liberal-leaning Asahi Shimbun newspaper said in a commentary that Japan had stood alone at the summit in recommending the resumption of loans to China and in bringing up the territorial dispute in the context of the debate over aid to the Soviets. ``The leaders from each country must have sensed a sort of `Japanese wind,' with Japan taking a clearly different stance from the other countries and Kaifu announcing that Japan would provide large amounts of aid'' to China, the Asahi commentary said. Kaifu was a first-time participant in the summit with the leaders of the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Canada and Italy. But he has gone further and more directly than his predecessors in speaking out on the need for Japan to exert political influence in line with its economic power. Japan's economy is second in size only to the U.S. economy, and its role as the world's biggest creditor nation is increasingly recognized as important if financial power is to be used to encourage the spread of Western democracy and free-market economies. But Japan rejects European proposals to give economic aid to the Soviets _ citing the unresolved territorial problem _ and was alone in deciding to aid China. Other summit participants said China hadn't done enough yet in the human rights area to win an end to sanctions imposed after the brutal crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in June 1989. Japan plans to resume a previously frozen program of $5.2 billion in loans to China over five years. Japanese commercial bankers also plan to consider resuming substantial loans to China ``in a positive manner,'' Taizo Hashida, chairman of the Federation of Bankers' Association of Japan, said at a news conference. The summit went on debating trade issues, with some Japanese media noting that the name of the the conference site _ Rice University _ could focus attention on Japan's ban on rice imports. A cartoon in the Asahi showed a cowboy Kaifu riding a bucking bronco and shouting ``Rice, Rice'' as the other government heads watched his ``one-man rodeo.'' President Bush is urging a phaseout of barriers and subsidies to agricultural trade worldwide that would force Japan to end its ban on imported rice. Japan argues that it already imports half the food needs for its 123 million people, and it's a matter of national security to remain self-sufficient in the staple food.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Signs Legislation Honoring Historic Route 66
DOC.TEXT: Gov. John Ashcroft got his kicks by riding in a 1961 Corvette and signing legislation designating a 307-mile stretch of nostalgic Route 66 in Missouri as a historic highway. ``Route 66 was never an ordinary road. From the time it was commissioned in 1926, it was something special to those who drove it and those living along it,'' Ashcroft said at a bill-signing ceremony Tuesday making Missouri the first state to give Route 66 historic status. U.S. 66, known as ``America's Main Street,'' was made famous by the 1960s television show ``Route 66'' and the song of the same name performed by the Rolling Stones. The narrow, concrete ribbon also helped fuel booming Southern California by carrying thousands of job-seeking Midwesterners to the West. The highway stretched 2,400 miles across eight states from Chicago to Santa Monica, Calif. But the federal interstate system doomed Route 66, and the last portions of the highway were erased from the nation's road maps in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Thousands Imprisoned, Tortured, Killed Worldwide In 1989
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people were imprisoned, tortured and killed last year by governments seeking to suppress conflicts arising from ethnic tensions or nationalist yearnings, Amnesty International said today The human rights group also criticized the executions of 16 people in the United States in 1989, and U.S. court rulings that permit the death penalty for teen-agers or retarded people convicted of murder. In its annual world survey of human rights, the London-based organization said repressive measures in many cases served to entrench bitter conflicts and dimmed prospects for dialogue. ``Peaceful protesters in many countries were arbitrarily arrested in vast numbers. Many were held for months without charge or trial. In countless cases, state torture was the price citizens paid for being identified as sympathizers with ethnic or nationalist movements,'' it said. ``Around the world, particularly where the tensions erupted into violence, tens of thousands of people became victims of security operations resulting in `disappearances' and extrajudicial executions,'' it added. The nearly 300-page survey said ethnic and nationalist groups have been suppressed in Somalia, Ethiopia, Sudan, Sri Lanka, India, Burma, Indonesia, the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia, China, Chad, Mauritania, Israel, Iran, Iraq, Turkey, Bulgaria, Guatemala and Brazil. In Eastern Europe, it said, new governments have emptied their prisons of dissidents, but it said dissenters are still harshly treated in Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia. On a positive note, Amnesty noted the release of political prisoners in Benin, Ethiopia, Somalia, South Africa and Namibia, and significant reductions in executions in South Africa and Nigeria. The report cited ``disturbing'' U.S. Supreme Court rulings permitting the execution of offenders who are mentally retarded or as young as 16. With 16 executions last year, the United States carried out more legal death sentences than any other country in the hemisphere by Amnesty's count. Cuba executed four, Guyana executed one and Antigua and Barbuda executed one. Amnesty says it opposes the death penalty ``under all circumstances.'' The report highlighted these instances of ethnic or nationalist tensions being met by government repression: _ Thousands of Sri Lankans were reported to have ``disappeared'' or were summarily executed by government troops and paramilitary allies combating an armed Tamil rebellion. _ In Somalia, 46 members of the Issaq clan, including children, reportedly were murdered by government soldiers in July. Similar reprisals were reported against members of the Ogadeni clan after a rebellion by Ogadeni soldiers. _ Forty-two members of the Dinka and Nuber communities in Sudan reportedly were summarily executed in October, and members of the Dinka, Nuber, Nuer and Shilluk communities have suffered gross human rights violations ``solely because of their ethnic origin.'' _ Twenty people were killed when Soviet troops broke up a peaceful demonstration in Tbilisi, Georgia in April, and police and troops assaulted an unarmed crowd of about 1,000 people in the western Ukraine in October. _ An unknown number of Tibetans were killed and more than 1,000 arrested when Chinese troops broke up an independence demonstration in Tibet in March 1989 and imposed martial law. Amnesty said there were many reports of torture involving beatings, electric shocks and hanging by the arms. _ Israeli troops shot to death more than 260 unarmed Palestinians in the occupied territories, and 13,000 Palestinians were held in prisons or detention camps. _ Kurds have been subject to brutal treatment in Iraq, Iran and Turkey, the report said. Seven Kurds who surrendered to Iraqi authorities during an amnesty in February were executed, the report said, and Kurds were victims of a wave of secret executions in Iran that ended in January 1989. The report challenged the tactics used against the Irish Republican Army's armed campaign to drive Britain out of Northern Ireland. Amnesty renewed its demand for judicial inquiries into several killings of IRA suspects by British security forces, claiming they were not adequately investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Dives, Stocks Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar plunged to a 4{-month low against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today, while the yen's rise gave a moderate boost to prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar closed at 148.10 yen, down 1.50 yen from Tuesday's finish of 149.60 yen. It was the lowest closing since 146.47 yen on Feb. 23. The dollar now has fallen 2.90 yen in the last four trading days. After opening at 148.42 yen, the dollar ranged between 147.65 yen and 148.75 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average for 225 selected issues gained 141.75 points, or 0.44 percent, closing at 32,294.18. The index dropped 385.85 points on Tuesday. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar's plunge followed a decline overnight in New York and renewed speculation over an increase in Japan's official discount rate. The yen firmed after a Washington-based investment advisory company, Smick Medley International, predicted that Japan's central bank would raise its key rate for loans to commercial banks within the next few months. Bank of Japan officials declined to comment on the prediction. Japan's discount rate now stands at 5.25 percent, one of the lowest among industrialized nations. The country has been under pressure from its trading partners to raise the rate to stem the yen's weakness against the dollar and other major currencies. Higher interest rates tend to make a currency more attractive to investors. Daiwa Bank's Sumio Fukushima said there was little chance that the Bank of Japan would raise the discount rate in the near future. ``But in the long term, it's a strong possibility,'' he said. Spot transactions totaled $19.591 billion, up from Tuesday's $14.668 billion. On the stock market, dealers said the yen's surge and solid Japanese bond prices encouraged buying of shares that have dropped to attractively low prices. However, they said, many institutional investors sat on the sidelines amid uncertainty over currency and interest rates. ``If interest rates go higher, the big investors could be discouraged about risking their money in stocks,`` said Yoshiro Inoue of Nomura Securities. Volume on the first section was estimated at 400 million shares, up from a thin 350 million shares the previous day. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds stood at 86.90 points as of 5 p.m., up from Tuesday's close of 86.74. The yield stood at 7.215 percent, down from 7.250 the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Wrong Man Killed, Syndicate Tries to Pay Off Widow
DOC.TEXT: Japan's largest underworld organization has offered more than $67,000 to the relatives of a man apparently killed by mistake in a gang war, one of the syndicate's lawyers said today. Two men opened fire June 29 on an apartment in Osaka, western Japan, where a leader of the Hadani gang, a rival of the mammoth Yamaguchi-gumi, had lived until just two weeks earlier. The gunfire killed Akira Yamashita, a 66-year-old telephone company employee who had moved into the apartment with his wife. It was the second death attributed to the Yamaguchi-gumi's battle with the Hadani gang, which began when a Hadani gangster allegedly shot a Yamaguchi-gumi member to death in the western Japan city of Fukuoka on June 28. Police believe the shooting was to avenge a ``turf violation.'' Both gangs are based in the Osaka area. Police say the Yamaguchi-gumi has 22,000 members in about 800 affiliated gangs across the country, while the Hadani gang has an estimated 220 members. ``It is very hard to imagine that Mr. Yamashita was not killed by Yamaguchi-gumi members or their affiliates,'' said Yukio Yamanouchi, one of the Yamaguchi-gumi's lawyers. Yamanouchi, contacted by telephone, told The Associated Press that on the day after the killing, he was told by a Yamaguchi-gumi ``executive'' to take a briefcase containing 10 million yen ($67,500) to the home of Yamashita's widow and offer it as a condolence. ``But before I could explain, her son closed the door in my face,'' Yamanouchi said. Because many shootings have occurred in daylight and in crowded areas, the gang war has received heavy media coverage and aroused strong police concern. Police also see the conflict as part of the continued expansion of the Yamaguchi-gumi, which has more than doubled its membership since 1986 by forcing rivals to either join its ranks or wage costly and bloody turf battles. The National Police Agency estimates that one in every four gangsters in Japan is now affiliated with the Yamaguchi-gumi, whose main sources of income are believed to be illegal gambling, extortion and drugs. Though Japan prides itself on its low crime rates and strict gun-control laws, police fear the Yamaguchi-gumi's growth will make gangland shootouts an increasingly serious problem. ``We are being very cautious, and have seen no indication that the conflict will end soon,'' said an Osaka police official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said 14 gang-related shootings occurred in Osaka alone in the past two weeks. Thirteen Yamaguchi-gumi members were arrested last Friday after Osaka police raided 62 Yamaguchi-gumi offices and homes. No one has yet been charged in Yamashita's murder, however.

DOC.HEAD: Research Group Christens World's First Superconducting Ship
DOC.TEXT: With the smack of a sake bottle, Japanese shipbuilders today christened the world's first ship that will use superconductivity to push itself through the water. The high-tech ship, christened the Yamato No. 1, is a public and privately funded experimental vessel shaped roughly like a streamlined telephone. The ship's developers said they view the vessel as a prototype for high-speed seacraft. It will use electromagnetic force instead of a conventional screw propeller to thrust itself through the water. The main purpose of the project, however, is to demonstrate that superconductivity could be used to power a ship, they said. ``This ship has been developed without regard to cost. It's experimental,'' said Jutaro Namba, a coordinator at Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in Kobe, a major port in western Japan about 270 miles west of Tokyo. The 185-ton ship is 100 feet long and about 35 feet wide. It is drydocked in the Kobe shipyard of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Japan's largest shipbuilder and a member of a consortium developing the ship's new technology. Superconductivity is expected to make the use of electricity much more efficient, reducing the need for fossil fuels. It is being developed for use in computers and their components, in magnetically levitated high-speed trains, electric cars and other devices. Superconducting coils made of niobium and titanium in thrusters underneath the ship are used to create a magnetic field that is repulsed by an electric current carried in water circulating through the thrusters. The repulsion produces the same kind of force used to propel superconducting trains on land. Engineers who worked on the ship say a combination of helium gas and liquid nitrogen is used to cool the coils to minus 452.47 degrees Fahrenheit. At that temperature, electricity passes through the coils without resistance. The use of water-propelled thrusters instead of conventional rotating screw propellers is expected to minimize maintenance problems as well as noise and vibration. The vessel also is energy-efficient. Most of the space on board the ship is occupied, however, by diesel-engine generators used to provide an electric current for the thrusters, for pumps and for on-board equipment, the engineers said. The ship's main handicap at present is its speed, a mere 8 knots, compared with about 40 knots for fast hydroplanes. And to minimize its weight, it has space for only about 10 people. Experts say new materials are needed to produce a strong enough magnetic field to propel the ship at commercially viable speeds. Officials say sea trials will be held next spring after the ship is fitted with thrusters and other seagoing equipment. A smaller model of the ship first was successfully tested in 1987. The vessel is the brainchild of a consortium of companies, universities and government researchers led by the Japan Foundation for Shipbuilding Advancement, with funding from the Ministry of Transport.

DOC.HEAD: New NEA Definition of Obscenity Same as Supreme Court Standard
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts has adopted the U.S. Supreme Court's definition of obscenity in deciding what works to fund. The new NEA guidelines on obscenity, released Tuesday, appear to offer a much more vague standard than a previous definition of obscenity imposed on the NEA by Congress last fall. Lawyer Floyd Abrams, a First Amendment specialist representing the New School for Social Research in a lawsuit challenging the obscenity restrictions, said the Supreme Court standard ``is a possibly useful step forward, but certainly a confusing one, since the NEA seems to continue to insist that the original language be sworn to.'' In a letter to the U.S. attorney's office sent Tuesday, Abrams asked whether the Supreme Court definition may be substituted for the Congress-imposed definition when artists sign contracts accepting NEA grants. Abrams also asked that NEA Chairman John Frohnmayer be made available for a deposition July 18 to answer questions about how the new guidelines should be interpreted. Alan Taffet, the U.S. attorney representing the NEA against Abrams, said the federal agency will ask that the complaint be dismissed. The NEA's moves follows its denial of grants to four performance artists whose work has a strong sexual content. The definition of obscenity imposed by Congress last fall barred the NEA from funding work that in the NEA's judgment ``may be considered obscene, including ... depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children, or individuals engaged in sex acts and which, when taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.'' But NEA spokesman Josh Dare said under the new definition, ``Whether or not a photograph is homoerotic and obscene, for example, will be determined based on the standard set forth by the Supreme Court.'' That standard defines as obscene any work that the average person, applying contemporary community standards, would find appeals to prurient interest; that depicts sexual conduct in a patently offensive way; and that, on the whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. The New School filed a lawsuit in U.S. District Court challenging the constitutionality of the obscenity guidelines in connection with a $45,000 grant to build a sculpture garden. Abrams said that if the NEA had offered the Supreme Court definition to begin with, rather than the Congress-imposed definition, ``Certainly there would have been much less controversy and less concern that people were being asked to sign away their First Amendment rights. Now we have a situation of some confusion.'' The anti-obscenity campaign was spearheaded by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. His office did not return a call for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Events Leading to This Week's Clashes in Managua
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a chronology of events in Nicaragua, where street fighting broke out this week in Managua, the capital:
July 17, 1979 _ Anastasio Somoza, whose family had ruled Nicaragua with U.S. support since the 1930s, flees to Miami. November 1980 _ First attacks launched by anti-Sandinista rebels known as Contras. February 1981 _ Reagan administration announces suspension of aid to Nicaragua and accuses Sandinista government of supporting leftist guerrillas in El Salvador. April 6-7, 1984 _ Commando units operating from a U.S. ship plant mines in Nicaragua's ports. Jan. 10, 1985 _ Daniel Ortega is inaugurated as president following national elections. May 1, 1985 _ Reagan announces a trade embargo against Nicaragua. Aug. 7, 1987 _ Five Central American presidents sign a regional peace plan. Feb. 3, 1988 _ Congress cuts off military aid to the Contras. Non-lethal aid continues. Feb. 14, 1989 _ Five Central American presidents agree the Contras should be demobilized. Ortega agrees to hold free elections in 1990. April 28, 1989 _ President Bush signs a $49 million non-lethal aid package for the Contras that will run out three days after the 1990 Nicaraguan elections. Aug. 7, 1989 _ The Central American presidents formalize demobilization accord. Feb. 25, 1990 _ Ortega and the Sandinistas suffer stunning defeat in elections to U.S.-backed coalition led by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. March 13 _ President Bush lifts the economic embargo and asks Congress for $300 million in aid, including $45 million to demobilize and relocate the Contras. April 19 _ Sandinistas, Contras and the coalition agree on a cease-fire and the immediate concentration of the Contras in security zones. The Contras agree to begin surrendering their weapons April 25, inauguration day, and to disband by June 10. April 25 _ Mrs. Chamorro takes office in peaceful transition of government. May 11 _ About 150,000 public employees begin a week-long strike that officials call a challenge to the new government. It ends after Mrs. Chamorro agrees to raise sharply some wages. June 27 _ Contra commanders surrender weapons to Mrs. Chamorro. July 2 _ The latest round of strikes against the new government begins. They grow increasingly disruptive as strikers begin occupying government buildings and setting up roadblocks. July 9 _ Mrs. Chamorro calls in the army to break up the strikes. July 10 _ Sporadic gun battles continue between government supporters and Sandinistas. Central American presidents issue call for international aid to Mrs. Chamorro.

DOC.HEAD: Spaniard Badly Gored In Fifth Running Of The Bulls
DOC.TEXT: A 23-year-old Spaniard was badly gored today in the fifth running of the bulls of the San Fermin festival, which Ernest Hemingway made famous. Doctors at Navarre Hospital said Juan Manuel Garcia received a deep wound in his left thigh and a skull fracture after being tossed in the air by one of the six bulls that made the morning run from the corrals to the city bull ring. He was listed in serious condition. Three other Spaniards were treated at area hospitals, including a 17-year-old with a broken wrist, while 27 other people received first aid at one of the emergency stations set up along the mile-long route. The morning runs are the focal point of the weeklong revelry. Dozens of runners, mostly young men, test their bravery by running ahead of and alongside the bulls, which are later killed in the day's bullfight. The annual festival attracts thousands of tourists from around the world. It was the setting for Hemingway's 1926 novel, ``The Sun Also Rises.'' Not counting interruptions due to wars, the festival has been held continuously since 1591. Since that date bulls have gored to death 52 people, according to municipal records.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``More than 50 percent of the water is not suitable for drinking ... More than half the population is drinking damaging water.'' _ Josef Vavrousek, in charge of environmental matters in Czechoslovakia.

``There's no economy in the villages ... Fires are quick income. It's cash that supplements hunting and fishing.'' _ Ron Silas, a former firefighter in Alaska, where firefighting provides an economic boost for rural communities.

``Frankly, the people from Washington told us early on that the media attitude at previous summits was affected by the preparation and presentation of the food.'' _ Ben Love, who helped organize the economic summit media center, on efforts to please reporters and promote Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Lack of Negligence, Judge Makes Award in AIDS Death
With PM-AIDS-Women, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered a county hospital to pay $121,030 to the mother of a 2-year-old who died of AIDS contracted through a blood transfusion in 1983. ``I feel relieved. I feel peace of mind, and I feel that my baby is finally at rest,'' Belinda Jackson said. ``I hate to see anybody go through what my baby and myself went through.'' Ms. Jackson sued the hospital district after learning her daughter, Tristainne Omega Louise, contracted the AIDS virus through one of eight transfusions she received at the hospital after a premature birth. The girl died in 1985. In a decision released Tuesday, state District Judge William Hughes found no negligence in the blood-testing methods of the John Peter Smith Hospital's blood bank in 1983, but did find negligence in the way it screened blood donors. Lowell Dushman, Ms. Jackson's attorney, said it is the first court victory nationally in an AIDS-by-transfusion case that occurred before there was general knowledge about the disease, which appeared in 1981. The virus that causes it was discovered in 1983. ``We feel every time one of these can be won, it breaks down the tremendous fortress of defense the blood banks have built,'' Dushman said. Assistant District Attorney Sullivan Bradley, who represented the hospital, argued that no screening test for AIDS was available when the child received transfusions in 1983. ``It is fair to say the industry is concerned about having today's knowledge and today's standards imposed on what it should have been doing. We're talking seven years ago,'' he said. Hughes said the hospital's screening process to eliminate intravenous drug users as donors in 1983 ``fell below the standard of care to accomplish that objective.'' The judge said evidence showed that ``well prior to 1983, hepatitis B was known to be a sometimes-fatal disease transmitted by intravenous drug users.'' The blood given to the child was contaminated with the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. One of the donors, identified only as Donor X during last month's trial, was an intravenous drug user who testified in a deposition that hospital employees did not ask about drug use before accepting his blood.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Urges Increase of OPEC Oil, Wants To Coordinate With Iran
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today that it is willing to cooperate with its former foe, Iran, to boost prices of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' oil to at least $25 per barrel. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted an unidentified official at the Oil Ministry as saying Baghdad believes raising OPEC's benchmark price could easily be achieved if all 13 member states adhere to production quotas. The agency said the official was reacting to a statement earlier this week from Tehran that higher oil prices was the only ``tangible'' common grounds between Iran and Iraq and should be exploited in the search for a settlement of their 10-year-old political dispute. The INA report, monitored in Nicosia, came as Iraq's Oil Minister Issam al-Chalabi was in Jiddah for a meeting of five gulf Arab OPEC heavyweights. The aim of the meeting hosted by Saudi Oil Minister Hisham Nazer was to coordinate policy ahead of an OPEC meeting set for July 25 in Geneva. ``Iraq is seriously calling for increasing prices to $25 per barrel as soon as possible,'' the official said. ``This can be achieved through adhering to the set quotas and avoiding violations and gluts until prices eventually reach $30 per barrel,'' the official said. At its last meeting in December, OPEC set a total output ceiling of 21.086 million barrels a day in an effort to defend an $18 benchmark price. But recently, prices dropped to $14 dollars per barrel. That was attributed to a glut on the oil market caused by the violation of production quotas by some OPEC members. The chief culprits for overproduction are Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. The Oil Ministry official told INA that ``overproduction by Kuwait and the U.A.E caused fragmentation'' within the 13-member OPEC cartel. The official said even if a $30-dollar price is acheived, OPEC members should keep working to increase crude prices under a strategy that ``would not allow any alternative energy source to compete with oil.''

DOC.HEAD: Cost of Space-Station Maintenance Reportedly Sky High
DOC.TEXT: A new NASA report concludes that the planned $37 billion space station will require nearly 75 percent more maintenance than earlier predicted, a newspaper reported today. The conclusion prompted the space agency to set up a special team to search for ways to reduce maintenance of the 500-foot-long station, The New York Times said. The newspaper quoted NASA engineers it did not identify by name as saying the station, intended as a centerpiece for study of the solar system by spacewalking astronauts, must be redesigned. ``You can't do it as currently designed,'' one of the engineers was quoted as saying. ``You have to build a different station.'' He said political pressure was on to downplay the problem. ``There's a lot of pressure to make this problem not a problem,'' he said. Neither the new maintenance estimate from an earlier team of experts nor the result of the search for solutions has been made public. Both may be released next week, the newspaper said. The space station would need more than 3,800 hours of maintenance by astronauts each year, the newspaper said. Preliminary findings in March by the earlier team said the station would require about 2,200 hours of maintenance each year. The special team was put together in June at Johnson Space Center in Houston to mount a crash search for design changes and other possible solutions, but some on that team expressed doubt Tuesday that significant progress can be made. ``The numbers suggest the station cannot be built,'' the Times quoted a Johnson Space Center engineer as saying. The space agency hoped to begin building the station in the mid-1990s. The station would have a life span of 30 years. Billie A. Deason, a Johnson Space Center spokeswoman, said NASA will have no comment on either the new maintenance estimate or the search for solutions until all findings are made public. NASA already is under fire for a serious defect in the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, hobbled by a mirror defect, and fuel leaks that have grounded the $25 billion space shuttle fleet. Possible solutions to the space station maintenance problem include improvements to increase the lifetimes of parts, combining several repair tasks at one time and having advanced robots make repairs.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Midwest, Ohio Valley; West Braces for Record Heat
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell early today over the nation's mid-section, where a clash of cool air from the north and tropical winds from the south was expected to spawn violent thunderstorms. Dry weather prevailed in the West early today, but the region was expected to suffer record heat. Temperatures were likely to soar into the mid-90s in the Rockies and past 100 degrees in the desert Southwest. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered today across the South. Thunderstorms struck Southern Florida, central Georgia and along the Mississippi River at St. Louis. Rain fell early today at Chicago, Detroit, Indianapolis and other parts of the Midwest. There was a thunderstorm at Pittsburgh and rain along the Maine coastline. The Plains had mostly dry weather, but thunderstorms were expected to develop later. The stationary front of the cool northern air and warm tropical winds was to stretch from Maryland along the southern Ohio Valley and Midwest to the Oklahoma and Texas panhandles. Heavy thunderstorms were like along the front. Showers and thunderstorms were expected along the Texas and Louisiana coasts. The Northeast was likely to be dry with seasonable temperatures. The nation's high on Tuesday was 110 degrees at Red Bluff, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Steady in Calm Trading, Gold Slightly Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was steady in calm European trading late this morning as the market's attention focused on the American currency's weakness against the Japanese yen. Gold drifted slightly lower in modest dealings, traders said. The yen got a boost after Japanese authorities indicated they might be willing to raise interest rates, dealers said. The Japanese currency is also expected to get some support from the meeting of the seven major industrialized nations in Houston, Texas which ends Wednesday. ``My impression is that the yen has finished its decline,'' one analyst in Milan said. ``It might not have a sudden boom, but I don't think it's going to keep losing.'' The dollar was reported stalled in its tracks, although traders said they think it still could move lower. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar plunged to a 4{-month low against the yen. It dropped 1.50 yen to a closing 148.10 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a fractionally higher rate of 148.20 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6447 West German marks, down from 1.6465 _1.3930 Swiss francs, down from 1.3945 _5.5210 French francs, down from 5.5270 _1.8523 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8555 _1,205.50 Italian lire, down from 1,207.00 _1.1586 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1570 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.8082, compared with $1.8155 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $353.50 an ounce, down from $353.75 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $353.70. In Zurich, the bid price was $353.60, down from $353.90 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.89 to close at a bid $355.02. Silver was selling in London at a bid price of $4.82 an ounce, unchanged from Tuesday's late bid.

DOC.HEAD: Astronaut Suspension Called `Wrist Slapping' by New Commander
DOC.TEXT: Air Force Col. Fred Gregory has reluctantly accepted his new space shuttle command after a fellow astronaut was grounded for disciplinary reasons. ``This is a very difficult and emotional time for us. We know that,'' Gregory said Tuesday. ``It's like a mother spanking her child and says this is going to hurt me more than you. It's a bad experience. But these people are mature enough and the group is mature enough to keep striving forward.'' Gregory won a shuttle command slot Monday after NASA grounded Navy Capt. David M. Walker. Walker, 46, was suspended for 60 days for infractions that included an incident last year in which the T-38 he was flying came within 100 feet of a Pan Am jetliner in a near-collision outside Washington. NASA also announced Monday that Navy Cmdr. Robert L. ``Hoot'' Gibson was pulled from shuttle flight assignments and barred for a year from making T-38 jet trainer flights for violating a policy that restricts high-risk recreational activities. Gibson was involved in a fatal plane crash at an air show during the weekend. ``Both Dave Walker and Hoot Gibson are terrific pilots, but this is just a temporary activity and basically it's a wrist slapping,'' said Gregory, who said he has not talked with Walker or Gibson since the action was taken. ``Sometimes we have to do it to get somebody's attention.'' A man answering the telephone at Walker's house Tuesday said he was unavailable for comment. Gibson has an unlisted number. Gregory, with 7,000 hours of time flying high-performance aircraft, will replace Walker on a Department of Defense flight scheduled for March 1991. He has flown twice before in space, most recently as commander of a Defense Department mission launched last November. No replacement was named immediately for Gibson. Gregory said he was unaware of his being named to the upcoming flight until two minutes before an astronaut meeting Monday morning. ``I didn't know, absolutely not,'' Gregory said. ``I was shocked. People were wandering around and congratulating me on getting another command, but it's one of these you take with great reluctance.''

DOC.HEAD: Tons of Potato Products Tainted With Wire
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of tons of french fries, hash browns and potato puffs destined for fast-food chains were impounded by a food processing company after pieces of wire were found in them. Metal-laden potato products mysteriously began appearing at Lamb-Weston Inc.'s Hermiston plant June 4, said Steven Johnson, the plant's former quality assurance manager. ``It looks like wire from a wire brush that you use to scrape paint off or something,'' Johnson said in a telephone interview. ``And we found this wire embedded in the french fry after it had been processed. These wires had kicked off the metal detectors.'' The potatoes were being processed for fast food restaurants in the U.S. and Japan, but none ever reached consumers, according to a state Agriculture Department official. Most of the impounded potato products never left the plant, but were stored in a refrigerated warehouse, The Wall Street Journal reported. The paper said about 100 cases of hash browns were sent to McDonald's distribution centers, but were located and returned unused to the plant. At Lamb-Weston's parent company, ConAgra of Omaha, Neb., spokesman Walt Casey said Lamb-Weston impounded the potatoes, ``they notified the FDA, and they worked with the FDA in resolving the problem.'' But a state official said the Oregon manufacturer of the spiked spuds failed to notify state inspectors of the problem. James Black, administrator of the food and dairy division of the state Agriculture Department, said the only notification was an anonymous tip to a state field assistant on vacation in the Hermiston area. Black said the state Agriculture Department is responsible for inspecting plants in the state. He said the federal Food and Drug Administration doesn't get involved unless the product is shipped out of state. Johnson said at least 18 million pounds of potato products were affected between June 4 and June 27, when he was fired. ``We run close to a million pounds a day,'' he said. ``It was a lot of metal in a lot of french fries. ... We had 30 cases of metal kicked off on the metal detectors.'' Johnson said he discovered the wire June 15 and tried to track the source until he and six other employees were fired because of the problem. He did not elaborate on the firings and the company refused to discuss them. Black said he did not know whether plant officials had isolated the source of the problem. Johnson said he initially thought a wire brush might have been caught in a water pump feeding the flume, a water-filled chute that moves the potatoes into the processing area from the receiving area, but none was found.

DOC.HEAD: As Many As 23 Killed in Four Days of Riots
DOC.TEXT: At least 23 people have been killed in four days of clashes between riot police and stone-throwing mobs demanding the end of one-party rule, a newspaper reported today. The English-language Daily Nation said the five new deaths had all occurred Tuesday in Kiambu district, a region about 15 miles west of Nairobi. Dozens more people also were injured by gunfire and beatings and 1,040 were charged in courts in Nairobi and Nakuru with looting and rioting, the newspaper reported. The country appeared calm today. The Daily Nation said police shot dead four people in Githunguri, a town in the district, on Tuesday after rioters tried to force students to join them in building roadblocks. The paper said a 6-year-old girl was killed in the district's Muchatha village after being hit by a stray bullet. The government said that as of Tuesday morning, 15 people had been killed and 61 injured in the violence. But at least three of 10 deaths confirmed independently prior to the official tally were not included in the government breakdown. The independent tally, including the deaths reported in today's Daily Nation, was 23. President Daniel arap Moi on Tuesday blamed the violence on ``hooligans and drug addicts.'' The clashes followed last week's detentions of Kenya's most prominent supporters of multiparty democracy. They began Saturday, when police used tear gas and guns to disperse demonstrators in Kenya's capital. By Monday, the violence had spread to outlying cities and rural areas. Kenya has long been considered one of Africa's most stable and successful nations. Since early this year, however, Moi has come under increasing pressure to allow a multiparty system. But he has insisted that to do so would lead to ethnic divisions and even warfare in Kenya. One prominent lawyer under threat of arrest for his criticism of the government, Paul Muite, has gone into hiding since last week's seizures and another, human rights lawyer Gibson Kamau Kuria, has sought refuge at the U.S. Embassy. On Monday, Kenya issued a strong statement condemning the U.S. decision to give Kuria asylum, and also accused the United States of fueling the pro-democracy movement. The United States protested the charge in a meeting between Herman Cohen, assistant secretary for African affairs, and Kenya's ambassador in Washington, Denis Afande. On Tuesday morning, two large artillery guns were parked for a time across the street from the U.S. ambassador's residence. The U.S. State Department has advised its citizens to delay all non-essential travel to Kenya.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO FIX WRITETHRU NUMBER
New Headache For Gorbachev: Coal Miners Launch Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev comment. Picks up 9th pvs `Some miners...'; EDITS thereafter to trim.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOS1
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of miners struck the Soviet Union's coal fields today in a 24-hour walkout aimed at crushing Communist Party power and forcing the government to quit. The walkout in western Siberia, the Ukraine's Donetsk region and the Soviet Far North falls on the anniversary of a protracted strike last summer _ the worst Soviet labor unrest in 72 years. Last year's strike brought the coal industry to a standstill and crippled factories before the government promised the strikers improved living conditions and a greater saying in the management of their workplaces. The miners say authorities have failed to keep their promises, and say they'll form an independent union next month. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would be the first Soviet leader since Vladimir Lenin to face such a union. ``They promise us everything.
