Our personal lives are worse than they were a year ago, especially housing and food,'' lamented Alexander Zuyevsky, 40, who works in the October Mine in Donetsk. The strikes come a day after Gorbachev was re-elected party chief by the Communist Party's 28th Congress. Addressing the congress today, Gorbachev said his information indicated the walkout was not a general strike. He said participation in western Siberia was minimal. ``We feel more understanding from the side of the miners,'' he said. Strike organizers say the walkout affected about 200 of the 250 mines in the eastern Ukraine's Donetsk basin, the Soviet Union's largest coal field. They claimed that about 300,000 miners would halt work in westen Siberia alone. But organizers in the coal basins could not provide any firm figures on the number of miners who actually participated. Some miners have already taken tough action against the long dominant but now discredited Communists, whom they blame for failing to solve the country's chronic economic problems. Workers at the Kalinin and Panfilovsky shafts in the Donetsk voted this week to evict party representatives from mine offices. Alexander Tupikin, a strike organizer at the Panfilovsky mine, said the Communists should not be allowed special access so they don't ``pressure the working class, which we've had for the 72 years of Soviet power.'' At today's Donetsk rally, the mood of the crowd was angry. Speakers stood on steps in front of the party and government headquarters. Miners attending the rally fashioned hats out of newspapers to shield them from the sun. ``From 10 years old, I was against the party, but only a few years ago were we allowed to speak about that,'' Andrei Voronits, a former miner from the region, said in an interview. He added that his main demand was Ukrainian independence but that he also supported demands for better living conditions. About 100 policemen kept order at the rally, and there were no disturbances. At a pep rally Tuesday night, strike organizer Yevgeny Moiseyev told about 150 miners: ``I will call for putting the party on trial. I ask you to support me in that.'' A red banner with the slogan ``Put the Communist Party on Trial'' hung in the hall of the October Mine, where the rally was held. On a bulletin board in the hall, a hand-written notice calling for the resignation of Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov was posted next to official notices about mine activities. The miners went ahead with their walkout in defiance of appeals by Gorbachev and the 28th Communist Party Congress under way in Moscow. At the congress on Tuesday, a leader of last year's strike in the Kemerovo region challenged Gorbachev in the election for party leader. Gorbachev easily defeated the official, Teimuraz Avaliani, and Solovyev said Avaliani's candidacy would damage his popularity among miners highly critical of the Communist Party. Last summer's strike by miners was called to largely press economic demands such as increasing supplies of meat, soap and laundry detergent. But today's walkout was more political, with miners demanding: _ that the Ryzhkov government resign; _ that Communist Party representation be eliminated at factories and mines, in the KGB, the army and the police; _ that political education classes for children be eliminated; and _ that party property be nationalized. Government and party leaders already have rejected the demands and maintain they are doing all they can to improve working and living conditions for miners.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Says TV Coverage Of Commons A Success
DOC.TEXT: Television coverage of the House of Commons, which began as an experiment in November, has not increased rowdiness in the chamber and should become permanent, a Commons committee said in a report today. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and other critics had originally opposed the introduction of TV cameras, saying they feared for the reputation of the House because of frequent boisterous behavior among legislators. But the all-party Select Committee on the Televising of Proceedings of the House said in its report today that the TV cameras had not affected the behavior of lawmakers. ``We believe we are justified in concluding that the experiment should be judged a success,'' the committee said. The panel, which questioned legislators and broadcasters, added that the experiment had met with a generally enthusiastic response from millions of viewers. The 650-seat Commons, complete with speaker in traditional horsehair wig, centuries-old ritual and legislators who bawl ``hear hear'' and insults at each other, voted 318-264 in February 1988 to let the experiment go ahead. Eight TV cameras began recording the proceedings in the House on Nov. 21. The House appointed an independent company to supervise the operation and sell the TV pictures to the British Broadcasting Corp. and other broadcasters. The House ruled that when proceedings get rowdy, the cameras must shun the disturbance and focus on the speaker, Bernard Weatherill. The Commons is scheduled to vote on whether or not to accept the committee's recommendation within the next two weeks. News reports predicted it will accept the TV cameras on a permanent basis. The House of Lords, the unelected upper chamber of Parliament, has admitted the TV cameras since 1985. Radio broadcasting from the Commons began in 1975, and newspaper reporters were first let into the Commons in 1771.

DOC.HEAD: White Actor in Asian Role on Broadway Stirs Controversy
DOC.TEXT: The choice of a white actor for the lead in the play ``Miss Saigon'' has angered Asian-Americans who say the Broadway role should go to an Asian. ``It's ridiculous to have a Caucasian actor with taped eyelids play an Asian,'' Tony Award winner B.D. Wong told the Daily News for a story published today. Jonathan Pryce, the actor chosen for the role of a Eurasian pimp, also did the role in London, and received rave reviews and an Olivier Award for his performance. ``Miss Saigon'' puts the ``Madame Butterfly'' tale of a military man taking an Asian lover in a Vietnam War setting. ``I thought the yellowface days of Charlie Chan and Fu Manchu were dead,'' playwright David Henry Hwang said, complaining about the choice. Hwang won a Tony for ``M. Butterfly.'' Scheduled to open on Broadway in April, ``Miss Saigon'' already has $10.5 million in advance sales. The musical was written by the team that created ``Les Miserables.'' ``Personally, I think actors are actors, and shouldn't be criticized for playing members of another race,'' said Geoffrey Johnson, a casting director for ``Miss Saigon.'' The Committee for Racial Equality of Actors' Equity met June 28 to discuss the controversy and Equity President Colleen Dewhurst said, ``Everybody should be in an uproar ... because whoever does this role will become a star.'' Cameron Mackintosh, the show's producer, and Johnson said they saw hundreds of auditions in San Francisco, Manila and New York but were not able to find an Asian actor who fit the part. Wong, Hwang and other Asian-Americans are urging Mackintosh to reconsider.

DOC.HEAD: American League Shuts Out NL in Baseball All-Star Game
DOC.TEXT: Six pitchers pulled off a 2-0 shutout for the American League in the 61st All-Star game. Manager Tony La Russa's toughest job Tuesday night was getting up from his dugout seat to signal the bullpen. La Russa started Bob Welch then called for Dave Stieb, Bret Saberhagen, Bobby Thigpen, Chuck Finley and Dennis Eckersley. Among them they allowed only two hits. ``There wasn't much to swing at up there,'' La Russa said. ``They all pitched great.'' The National League got singles to center field by Will Clark in the first inning and Lenny Dykstra in the ninth. In between, there were two walks, 16 consecutive outs and lots of raindrops. The American League got seven hits. Julio Franco was selected the All-Star Most Valuable Player. He hit a two-run double in the seventh inning off Rob Dibble. The game was delayed at the start 15 minutes by rain and again in the seventh inning for 68 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Overrun Rebel Camp, Find 20 Bodies
DOC.TEXT: Government troops overran a major Tamil rebel camp in eastern Sri Lanka and found the bodies of 20 policemen believed to have been captured last month, military officials said today. The camp, fortified with bunkers, land mines, booby traps and an underground tunnel system, was captured Tuesday. There was no resistance, according to the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. They said at least 27 rebels and two soldiers were killed in the five-day operation to capture the half-square-mile jungle camp at Karijikudiaru in the eastern Ampara district. The 20 decomposed bodies found at the camp were probably of policemen who were among the 850 captured by the rebels when they overran a string of police stations along the east coast a month ago, the officials said. Government troops have so far discovered about 300 bodies of slain officers. Those who remain missing also are believed to have been killed by the guerrillas. Last month's attacks broke a 13-month cease-fire in the 7-year-old Tamil rebellion. The guerrillas want independence for the predominantly Tamil north and east from Sinhalese-dominated Sri Lanka. The ethnic war started in 1983 with the rebels complaining of discrimination by the Sinhalese majority in jobs, education and the use of Sinhala language. Tamils account for 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, and the Sinhalese, who make up 75 percent of the population, control the government and the military. More than 12,000 people have been killed in the rebellion; at least 2,225 combatants have been killed since the latest fighting started after a Tamil man complained to the rebels he was manhandled by Sinhalese troops. On Tuesday, three soldiers were killed and eight wounded when rebels attacked a military camp at Kokkavil village north of Vavuniya, 135 miles north of Colombo, the military officials said. They said troops assisted by helicopter gunships replused the assault, but that sporadic gunfire continued today. The rebels were reported to have suffered high casualties, but the military officials said they did not have any details. Meanwhile, the government dispatched 12 trucks with food and medicine today to the northern Jaffna peninsula where shortages are growing acute.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Takes Re-election Win as a Mandate
With PM-Soviet-Miners, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Gorbachev backing a top Ukrainian to be his deputy, details. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB4,9
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today backed a top Ukrainian official to be his Communist Party deputy in an election against Yegor K. Ligachev, the candidate of traditionalists. Speaking to the Communist Party's Congress, the Soviet leader threw his support behind Vladimir Ivashko, the 58-year-old Ukrainian president and former party chief, for the post that will assume responsibility for the party's day-to-day affairs. He expressed his confidence and closeness to the man he chose to run the Ukraine, the Soviet Union's second-largest republic, last fall when party traditionalist Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky retired. ``It is important that these two people be close,'' Gorbachev said of the two top party leaders. On Tuesday Gorbachev was overwhelmingly re-elected to lead the party, but he cannot devote full attention to the job because he also is Soviet president. A third candidate, professor Anatoly Dudaryev, 45, of Leningrad, proposed himself as a candidate. A vote was likely late today. ``As much as I have before, no matter what my job, I will be working for perestroika,'' pledged Ivashko, an economist and engineer by training. ``We have to do everything to renew the party and change its priorities.'' ``We have to understand that without us, without the party, nothing will be left of perestroika,'' he said in a forceful presentation to the delegates. The stout, white-haired Ligachev fought off a bid from the floor to prevent him from running because of his age. Ligachev is 69, and two efforts to require the deputy leader to be younger than 60, and then 65, both failed. Ligachev, addressing the nearly 4,700 congress delegates, also said he had worked well with Gorbachev. He stressed party unity in his speech, and in answer to questions spoke out against allowing private property in the Soviet Union. Ligachev said last month that one person could not handle both the party leadership and the Soviet presidency, inferring that Gorbachev should step down as party leader. But party traditionalists did not put up a candidate against Gorbachev for the party leader's post, and he steamrolled his only opposition, Teimuraz Avaliani, a local party official and coal strike leader from western Siberia. Asked Tuesday why Ligachev did not run against Gorbachev for the party leadership, Moscow party leader Yuri Prokofiev said: ``The congress did not nominate him. That says it all.'' In his brief acceptance speech late Tuesday, Gorbachev promised to take ``the most serious, far-reaching conclusions'' from strident criticism leveled at him during the congress. Earlier in the day, he ripped into his conservative critics. ``You can never go back to yesterday by any path, and no dictatorship ... solves anything,'' he told the delegates. Some 40 percent of the delegates are party bureaucrats, and some continue to run their districts as fiefdoms. ``If any of the delegates came to the congress with the hope of returning the party to old conditions, comfortable or uncomfortable, this is not a question,'' he said. ``They were seriously mistaken.'' Gorbachev and seven others were nominated for the top Communist Party post. All but Avaliani, party leader in the Siberian city of Kiselyovsk, withdrew. Avaliani, 58, also headed the strike committee in a protest for higher pay and better working conditions in the Kuznetsk coal basin last summer. His nomination came on the eve of a one-day political strike by miners protesting the Communist Party's power and the government's inability to fulfill the promises it made to end last year's strike. Miners are calling for the resignation of Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and his Cabinet. Avaliani struck a moderate stance, saying he favored continued government control of key enterprises. He said he would support strikes only on a case-by-case basis.

DOC.HEAD: Top Diplomat: Israeli Raids Complicate Hostage Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Hezbollah calling for release of all hostages and Lebanese detainees. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `Sharaa said...' ADDS 1 graf background at bottom.
DOC.TEXT: The Syrian foreign minister said today that Israeli air raids into Lebanon had complicated negotiations for the release of one of 16 Western hostages held in that country by Shiite Moslem extremists. In Lebanon, meanwhile, a senior Hezbollah official called for the release of all Western hostages and of all Lebanese detainees held by Israel. He reiterated the pro-Iranian group's standard position that it is not involved in kidnappings. Hezbollah officials have often made such statements in their effort to distance themselves from the kidnappings. But Western intelligence sources insist Hezbollah is an umbrella for underground factions holding most of the six American and 10 European hostages. Mohammed Yazbed, a member of Hezbollah's higher command, told mourners in Baalbek today: ``We ask all those holding the hostages and those holding our detainees as well to release them. ``We are against such operations (kidnappings), and support the freedom of individuals,'' he said at the funeral of two Hezbollah members killed in Israel's last air raid Monday. Farouk al-Sharaa, the Syrian foreign minister, was the first official to confirm a weekend report by the Iran's official news agency that a hostage, most likely a European, might be freed soon. Syria is the main power-broker in Lebanon. Sharaa said the raids Sunday and Monday against Hezbollah bases in south Lebanon, which claimed at least 15 lives, had ``undermined our efforts'' to secure the release of a hostage. The Syrians were instrumental in the release of American hostages Robert Polhill on April 22 and Frank Reed April 30. Both were freed in Lebanon and immediately whisked to neighboring Syria for their freedom journey home. Syria maintains 40,000 troops in Lebanon under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate. They control Moslem regions as well as west Beirut. Syria, Iran and allied Palestinian and Lebanese factions contend that Western support of Israel encourages the Jewish state's attacks against Arabs. Sharaa said he had no tangible developments to report, but it is ``not unlikely'' that that would change soon. He indirectly confirmed speculation in Beirut, London and Dublin that the hostage to be released is Belfast native Brian Keenan. ``Syria is in constant contact with Iranian government officials and we are also in contact with the Irish government,'' Sharaa said. `We are exerting efforts and we hope that these efforts will be successful,'' he said. Asked when a release might take place, Sharaa said: ``I can't tell you anything now.'' He did not elaborate on the snags that followed the air raids, but said: ``I hope we will overcome these difficulties.'' Keenan, 39, was kidnapped in Moslem west Beirut on April 11, 1986, as he walked from his home to the American University of Beirut, where he taught English. In Beirut, Shiite sources said this week Iran was pushing hard for the release of a hostage to express appreciation for relief supplies it received from the West after the June 21 killer quake. Ireland had sent one of the first relief shipments to Tehran after the disaster in which 40,000 people were killed, 60,000 injured and about half a million were left homeless. Irish Ambassador Declan Connolly said today: ``We continue to be very hopeful'' about the possible release of Keenan, He spoke to reporters after a meeting at the Foreign Ministry with one of Sharaa's senior aides, Nasser Qaddour. ``We talked about the possibility of a hostage release but at this stage it would seem there have been no concrete developments,'' Connolly said. ``I think we require a little patience,'' he added. Connolly, a non-resident ambassador, flew in from Saudi Arabia on Tuesday. On arrival he said he was in Damascus to keep in closer touch with Syrian officials to assess developments in a possible hostage release. He said he had ``good reason'' to expect a release. Syrian sources and other Western ambassadors said they had no concrete information to indicate the release of a hostage was imminent. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani has been trying to end the ordeal of the hostages in return for improved relations with the West. But he is faced with growing opposition by Iranian radicals who believe restoring ties with the West contradicts the teachings of the late founder of the Islamic Republic, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Rafsanjani, leader of the so-called pragmatist wing in the Iranian hierarchy, argues that ending Iran's decade-long isolation would lure foreign investment and technology and help the country's war-battered economy. The longest held Western hostage is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East corespondent for The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Fertility Clinic Settles Septuplet Malpractice Case For Up to $6 Million
DOC.TEXT: A fertility clinic agreed to pay up to $6 million to a mother and three of her surviving septuplets to settle a malpractice lawsuit. The fertility specialist who treated the woman, however, refused to participate in the settlement and was dismissed as a defendant. A court approved the settlement Tuesday, a day after jury selection had begun. Patti Frustaci and her husband, Sam, contended Dr. Jaroslav Marik and the Tyler Medical Clinic failed to properly monitor fertility medication and perform tests that could have indicated the potential for multiple births. Mrs. Frustaci delivered four boys and three girls in May 1985. One baby was stillborn and three others died shortly after birth. The surviving three have serious health problems, the couple say. The settlement was approved by Superior Court Judge David Rothman. The clinic will pay $450,000 to the Frustacis immediately. The three children also will receive monthly payments ranging from $400 to $1,000 until age 18. Then the monthly payments increase to $1,000 to $3,000. Based on normal life expectancy, the payments could total up to $6 million. ``I feel justice has been served in this case and I feel an enormous sense of relief,'' said Mrs. Frustaci, 35, who also announced that she was pregnant with twins, again by use of a fertility drug. Marik, who had not commented publicly on the case, said Tuesday that he was not to blame for the plight of the Frustaci septuplets. He contended that Mrs. Frustaci did not follow his instructions in her eagerness to become pregnant. As to who was at fault, he said: ``Why do you have to have someone at fault? Sometimes these things just happen.''

DOC.HEAD: North Before Iran-Contra Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North made another appearance today before a federal grand jury investigating the Iran-Contra affair. It is the former White House aide's fifth appearance since June 1 before the panel. The grand jury is examining whether Reagan administration officials covered up aspects of the scandal from Congress. The grand jury also heard June 27 from former North's boss, then-National Security Adviser John Poindexter, who was sentenced June 11 to six months in prison. Poindexter was convicted of covering up North's role in a secret Contra resupply from Congress and of concealing the U.S. role in a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. As in past sessions, Iran-Contra prosecutor Craig Gillen went into one of the grand jury rooms today at the U.S. Courthouse minutes before North entered. Gillen works for the office of Independent Counsel Lawrence Walsh. Walsh's office is trying to determine the precise roles in the scandal of President Reagan, then-Vice President Bush and other administration aides, sources have said. North worked closely with former State Department official Elliott Abrams and former CIA officer Alan Fiers in connection with the Contras. North also had contact with Donald Gregg, Bush's aide on national security during the Iran-Contra affair. North was found guilty of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress, altering and destroying National Security Council documents and receiving an illegal gratuity. He and Poindexter are appealing their convictions. North was placed on two years' probation, fined $150,000 and is performing 1,200 hours of community service work.

DOC.HEAD: Death of Young Palestinian Causes Clash in East Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinians protesting the death of a youth in their Jerusalem refugee camp hurled stones at riot police who responded with tear gas and rubber bullets today. Police arrested three Palestinians during hit-and-run battles in the Shuafat camp in Arab east Jerusalem, where 16-year-old Munser Zuhdi Musa Adabed died Tuesday. Authorities initially said Adabed was killed by police gunfire during clashes in Shuafat. But police spokesman Uzi Sandori said medical evidence that became available today showed that Adabed could not have been killed by a bullet and apparently died while handling a bomb. Doctors at east Jerusalem's Mukassed Hospital, where Adabed's body was taken, said he had shrapnel wounds in his chest. The body was later taken by relatives for burial, preventing further examination. In Shuafat, black flags of mourning, outlawed Palestinian flags and the green banners of the Moslem fundamentalists fluttered from rooftops today. Dozens of masked youths rallied around Adabed's house to protest his death. A total of 723 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis since the December 1987 start of the Palestinian uprising. An additional 233 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of helping Israel. Forty-five Israelis also have died.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Says Two Ferries to Bring Asylum-Seekers from Albania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with France sending ship too, first ship will go Thursday, other details of the transport. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Italy and France are sending two ships to Albania beginning Thursday to ferry out more than 3,500 Albanian asylum-seekers who have holed up in three Western European embassies, Italian authorities said. The first ship will leave the Italian port of Brindisi for Albania on Thursday evening, an Interior Ministry spokesman said today. It will bring out many of the approximately 2,200 people who have packed the West German Embassy, since they have endured the worst conditions, a Foreign Ministry official said. He spoke on the usual ground rule of anonymity. The ferry operation was organized through the intercession of a U.N. representative in Tirana, the Albanian capital. Italian authorities said today that an accord had been reached with the Communist government and ``now we are talking about details'' of the operation. ``The Albanians have reserved for themselves the right to decide at the last minute'' what time the ships will arrive at the Adriatic port city of Durres, the spokesman said. He added that authorities were afraid that if people knew the details of the operation, Albanians would rush to get on board and ``it would be a thing of biblical proportions.'' Officials said the ships will transport about 2,200 people from the West German Embassy, more than 800 from the Italian Embassy and about 540 from the French Embassy. The other embassies in Tirana had fewer people and would work out agreements individually with the Albanian government, the Foreign Ministry spokesman said. Scores of Albanians began entering the embassies on June 28 in an effort to escape Europe's last hard-line Communist bastion. Some dodged bullets as they scrambled over embassy walls. The first 51 asylum-seekers left their country Tuesday for Czechoslovakia on a plane sent by that nation's president, Vaclav Havel. The Italian ferries, the Appia and Espresso Grecia, will bring the asylum-seekers to Brindisi, about 85 miles across the Adriatic Sea from Albania, the Merchant Marine Ministry said in a communique. From there, the Albanians who had been in the West German Embassy will catch trains to West Germany, the Interior Ministry spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The two ships were chartered from the Societa Adriatica company for the evacuation, the Interior Ministry said. The vessels, which carry about 1,000 people each, usually take tourists to Greece. It was not clear whether they would have to make return trips for the refugees. The first ferry will leave Brindisi Thursday evening and return the next morning, the Interior Ministry said. The French ship will go to Albania on Friday, the spokesman said, adding he did not know its return destination. The Italian Red Cross has been preparing to provide assistance to the refugees once they arrive in Italy. Those who sought shelter in the French and West German embassies will be sent to those countries, the spokesman said. The Italian spokesman said that ferrying out the Albanians was ``the most obvious thing'' to do since the airport in Tirana was small. The Appia was used by the Red Cross during an Italian peace mission in Lebanon in 1982, the agency said. Albanian leader Ramiz Alia introduced some economic reforms this year and began to improve ties with other countries. The government has said it would consider establishing relations with the United States. But Alia has made clear he doesn't plan to adopt multiparty democracy or shed key Communist principles. The turmoil at the embassies appeared to contribute to a shake-up Saturday of Albania's ruling party Politburo and Central Committee. Several hard-liners associated with the late Communist ruler Enver Hoxha were dismissed. The Italian official said the shake-up ``favored this solution'' of the ferries. The official said he hoped that the adoption of internal reforms in Albania would prevent a repetition of the assault on the foreign embassies. Travel has been nearly impossible for most Albanians for 45 years, but the government recently said all Albanians over 16 were entitled to a passport.

DOC.HEAD: Mozambique and Its Rebels Hold First Direct Peace Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CORRECT that government leftist, sted Marxist, and UPDATE with background on the insurgency's goal and cost in lives. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators for Mozambique's leftist government and the nation's rebels held their first direct peace talks this week and said today they would try to end the 13-year-old insurgency. The talks, involving the rebels' No. 2 leader and a government minister, could lead to a cease-fire by the end of the year, said Mario Raffaelli, a parliamentary deputy who monitored the talks for the Italian government. Both sides met Sunday, Monday and Tuesday at the Rome headquarters of San Egidio Community, a religious organization that aids poor immigrants in Italy, and which also observed the talks. The negotiations were not announced ahead of time and were held privately. An estimated 600,000 people, mostly civilians, have died in the war in the southeast African nation. The rebels have been accused of widespread civilian atrocities by the U.S. State Department and others. The war has left Mozambique one of the poorest countries in the world. Annual per capita income is about $200 and almost half the 15 million people require some level of food aid. Leading the Mozambican government delegation in the talks was Armando Gebuza, minister of transport and communication. Raul Domingos, No. 2 official for RENAMO, as the rebels are known, headed the other delegation. ``We could be optimistic'' about the possibility for a cease-fire, Raffaelli said. ``I think it's realistic that there could be one by the end of this year, maybe in time for Christmas,'' said Raffaelli, a Socialist who formerly was the Foreign Ministry's undersecretary for Africa. Raffaelli said both sides would meet again in Rome ``as soon as possible,'' probably within several weeks. RENAMO, the Portuguese acronym for the Mozambican National Resistance, has been fighting a war against the government of the country, which gained independence from Portugal in 1975. ``Keeping in mind the greater interests of the Mozambican nation, both sides have agreed on the necessity to put aside that which divides them, and to concentrate, with priority, their attention on that which unites them, toward creating a common working base to realize, in a spirit of mutual comprehension, a dialogue within which they can debate their different points of view,'' said a communique signed by the two sides and released today. Both sides said they were ready to commit themselves toward ``the search for a working platform to end the war and to create political, economic and social conditions that will allow a lasting peace and the normalization of life of all Mozambican citizens.'' Before the peace talks this week, efforts by Kenya and Zimbabwe had failed to get both sides to the negotiation table. Raffaelli said both sides agreed a month ago to have the talks held in Italy. The Vatican was informed about the peace efforts but was not directly involved, officials at the news conference said. Pope John Paul II visited Mozambique in September 1988. RENAMO says its wants recognition as a political party and free elections, but its political program has never been clear. No government publicly supports the rebels, although South Africa openly backed them until it signed a mutual non-aggression pact with Mozambique in 1984. Mozambique's ruling Frelimo Party dropped its Marxist label last year and has been liberalizing the economy and politics. The government of President Joaquim Chissano is working toward a more market-oriented economy and is considering a constitution that would allow independents to run for parliament. however, it has not come out in favor of allowing opposition parties. The Mozambican government still receives most of its weapons from the Soviets, but it has developed increasingly close ties with Western countries. Britain helps train government troops and the United States is the leading food donor to Mozambique.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Broadens Supervision of Union Election
DOC.TEXT: The judge overseeing the settlement of the government's racketeering lawsuit against the Teamsters union has ordered broad supervision of the union's upcoming election. ``Complete supervision of all facets of the election process is the only way to guarantee the integrity of the elections and encourage extensive rank and file participation,'' U.S. District Judge David N. Edelstein said Tuesday in approving new election rules. The judge made more stringent the new voting procedures proposed by a court-appointed administrator. He gave the elections administrator, Michael Holland, authority over some election functions previously assigned to officers of the local unions. ``The supervision in this election must indeed be expansive and proactive,'' Edelstein said. Helen Hershkoff, an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer who represented a Teamsters dissident group, said Edelstein's decision was a victory for union democracy. ``The court really is asking for more strenuous, more vigorous supervision than the court officer himself imagined necessary,'' said Hershkoff, who filed a brief in the case on behalf of Teamsters for a Democratic Union. The rules establish secret-ballot elections of local delegates, who in turn will nominate candidates for the Teamsters' international board at the 1991 convention, also by secret ballot. The board will be elected by a rank and file vote, again by secret ballot. If successful, the election would be the first secret-ballot vote in ``the history of a union which has been the historic marionette of organized crime,'' Edelstein said. The election rules stem from the settlement in March 1989 of the government's civil racketeering lawsuit against the Teamsters. The settlement was intended to rid the 1.7 million-member union of corruption and establish new voting procedures. In adopting the election rules, Edelstein overruled objections by the union that the new voting system gave a court-appointed administrator too much power over the union and its locals. At an earlier point in his opinion, the judge said he approved rules that guaranteed elections ``completely secure from harassment, intimidation, coercion, hooliganism, threats, or any variant of these no matter under what guise.'' The election rules were proposed in February by Holland, one of three court-appointed administrators of the settlement, and were the subject of eight hearings held around the country in March. ``An election under these rules beacons the coming of the light of freedom to this dark union,'' Edelstein said. ``This court has reiterated that this consent decree is a unique attempt to cleanse this union. These election rules are the linchpin in that effort.'' The judge specifically ordered that all Teamster locals submit election plans to the administrator, that membership lists be released to any accredited candidate and that no delegate participate in the international convention unless directly elected. A call the union's general counsel, James Grady, was not returned.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NAIROBI
Mandela Airlifted From Ethiopia With Pneumonia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Mandela arriving in Nairobi, sources say he admitted to hospital. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela, reportedly suffering from pneumonia, arrived in Nairobi today and was whisked to town after a low-key arrival ceremony. Sources said he was admitted to a hospital. The black nationalist leader was diagnosed as having a slight case of pneumonia and was flown from Ethiopia for treatment, according to The Star newspaper of Johannesburg. The 71-year-old Mandela was attending the Organization of African Unity's summit in Addis Ababa. A hospital and a diplomatic source said Mandela was admitted to Nairobi Hospital within hours of his arrival. Both sources spoke on condition of anonymity. Mandela looked sick upon arriving in Kenya accompanied by his wife, Winnie. He walked slowly down the stairs to the runway, clutching the railing. After greeting President Daniel arap Moi and his Cabinet and waving to a small crowd of airport workers and security officials, Mandela and Moi climbed into the president's limousine and were driven away. Winnie Mandela left in a separate vehicle. The Star, which has a correspondent traveling with Mandela, said the African National Congress leader caught a cold while in Ireland and it developed into pneumonia. The paper quoted aides as saying the pneumonia was slight and there was no cause for alarm. There has been repeated concern about Mandela's health since he was released from prison in February after 27 years in jail for fighting white minority rule. Mandela was hospitalized in June and had a benign cyst removed from his bladder. Doctors have expressed concern about his heart, and he undergoes regular medical checks. He also suffered from tuberculosis in 1988. Mandela has undertaken a punishing schedule of political talks and foreign tours since his release. But the black leader has declined to trim his hectic schedule.

DOC.HEAD: Library's Trustees Rescind Juvenile ``Carding'' Policy
DOC.TEXT: Public library trustees have rescinded a policy that would have restricted children to a juvenile section. After a loud and often hostile public response Tuesday night by more than 100 residents, the library board voted 4-3 to rescind the limited access policy. Three of the seven trustees were absent when the policy was adopted last month. The policy would have let parents in this south Chicago suburb obtain cards for children under 14 years old that restricted them to the juvenile section. Opponents of the policy argued that children would no longer have access to such items as an encyclopedia and dictionary. Backers of the change said parents would gain more control over access to what their children read. For more than 13 years, library officials said, Oak Lawn has allowed children access to Playboy magazine and all other library materials, excluding music videos, which are available only to patrons 18 and over. Residents attending the meeting gave the board a standing ovation after the vote, saying the quiet suburb could return to normal after receiving national media attention over the new policy. ``I'm deeply ashamed of our library and totally embarrassed,'' said resident Mary Grana before the vote. ``My friends from all over are saying `Oh, you live in that Nazi village?''' Library Trustee Nancy Czerwiec, author of the limited access policy, said arguments that it was censorship clouded the issue of parental choice. ``An idea is on trial tonight _ the idea of parental choice,'' Ms. Czerwiec said. ``As a parent, I've always had the choice,'' said Kathleen Miller, a resident for 25 years. ``Who are you to give me the right I already have?''

DOC.HEAD: College Entry Test Quizzes Students On Protests
DOC.TEXT: High school seniors taking this year's college entrance examination faced a new series of questions on last year's pro-democracy protests, an official report said. Students were asked to ``analyze the reasons, essence and lessons that should be drawn from last year's turmoil and rebellion,'' said the Tuesday edition of the Yangcheng Evening News of Canton, seen in Beijing today. Since it crushed the massive pro-democracy protests led by college students, the Communist government has vowed to screen out students who fail to meet ideological criteria. The government also has ordered schools at all levels to spend more time on political education in order to ensure their graduates are loyal socialists. More than 2.8 million youths nationwide took the tests on Saturday, competing for 608,000 seats in the September freshman class. The number of freshmen being admitted is up slightly from last September's 597,000, but still below the 669,000 of September 1988. Authorities are believed to have cut college enrollment as part of their efforts to prevent future student protests. The all-day college exams cover most academic subjects, including history, politics, science and mathematics. The Yangcheng Evening News said the history section of this year's test stressed patriotism and ``invasion and counterinvasion'' in modern Chinese history. Questions focused on the mid-19th century Opium War with Britain, which was shipping opium into China against the will of the Chinese government, treaties that China was forced to sign giving Western countries access to Chinese ports, and Japan's invasion of China in World War II. In the past year, in the face of Western criticism of its crackdown on the protests, China's official media have stressed historical conflicts with the West and portrayed the country as beseiged by imperialists. A separate report said the new emphasis on ideological education was already showing success. The Beijing Daily said nearly 1,100 Beijing University students, one-ninth of the student body, have applied to join the Communist Party. It did not say over what period of time the applications were made. It can take years for an application to be approved. ``After last year's political storm, many students at Beijing University came to better understand through study and sober reflection that the only way to strengthen the country is by following the socialist road under the leadership of the Communist Party,'' the report said. Beijing University students were among the leaders of the 1989 protests. The school has a tradition of political activism.

DOC.HEAD: Aboriginal Leader Declares Provisional Government
DOC.TEXT: A group of Aborigines declared a provisional government today, claiming they have been neglected for decades by state and federal governments and see little prospect for change. Michael Mansell, secretary of the Aboriginal Provisional Government, said it would be autonomous, raise its own funds, have its own passports and seek recognition by foreign governments. ``It is a political body set up to provide leadership to the aspirations of Aboriginal people,'' the Aboriginal activist told a news conference. ``All we are asking is the right to control ourselves on our own land. We don't want to interfere with you people, but just leave us alone as well.'' It was not immediately clear what effect, if any, the declaration would have. The 1981 census said Australia had about 160,000 Aborigines, comprising less than 1 percent of the population at the time. Estimates indicate the country had 300,000 or more Aborigines, the indigenous people, when European settlers arrived. ``We would set ourselves a stage that in 20 to 30 years from now, we would actually have enough land in this country so that Aboriginal people could raise their own economy, legal system and run their own government on it,'' Mansell said. The new government received an early rebuff when Federal Aboriginal Affairs Minister Robert Tickner canceled a meeting set for Thursday with Mansell and other Aboriginal representatives to discuss the return of ancestoral Aboriginal skeletal remains from overseas. A spokesman for Tickner said the minister would not meet any representatives of a provisional Aboriginal government. Mansell said the provisional government would encourage local Aboriginal communities to take back what they consider their land by squatting on it and would provide them with financial and ``people'' support to resist police and government attempts to remove them. However, Mansell said the provisional government was purely a political body and would not compete with any government bodies that provide services to Aboriginal people. He said the provisional government's main aims were obtaining land rights, gaining control over Aboriginal culture and heritage, and pursuing the return of the Aboriginal skeletal remains from overseas. Mansell denied the new government would cause greater division between Aborigines and whites. ``There will always be divisions in this country because there are two distinct peoples and there is nothing wrong with being different,'' he said. ``The only thing that's wrong with people being different is where one group imposes its will upon another.'' Funding for the new government would be provided by a system of rent payments, the sale of Aboriginal passports and donations. Under the rent-payment system, already in operation in Victoria state, sympathetic whites who believe in Aboriginal sovereignty over the continent pay nominal rent to the black community.

DOC.HEAD: Strikers Seek Response From Governing Party
DOC.TEXT: Artists, intellectuals and students said today they would give up their strike only if the government agrees to work under a new president with no links to the Communists or their successors. The sit-in strikers, camping in scores of tents in the heart of the city, forced the resignation on Friday of President Petar Mladenov, a leading member of the governing Socialist Party of reform Communists. Since then, they have made new demands and requested written assurances from the main political parties that they will resolve the country's problems democratically in Parliament. Spokesmen for the strikers said today they already had received such assurances from the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, but an answer from the Socialists was still outstanding. The peaceful strike was seen as significant because it has been joined by top scientists and professors, including representatives of the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences. The students began their sit-in about a month ago to protest alleged manipulations in June's parliamentary elections, in which the Socialists won a majority of seats. Their demands were contained in a declaration issued on July 6. Mladenov's resignation fulfilled one of those demands. But the demonstrators also want a public trial of ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, who under investigation for alleged abuse of power, incitement to ethnic hatred and misappropriation of state property. Their other demands, reiterated at an improvised open-air news conference today, called for: _A new president who is not linked to the political and army establishment. _Removal of parliamentary immunity from people implicated in the running of prison camps in the 1950s, in the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia and in the state persecution of ethnic Turks in 1984-85. _The ``whole truth'' about the Bulgarian foreign debt, now about $10 billion, and about the property of the ruling party and its former leaders. Strikers have named their downtown tent camp ``the City of Truth.'' ``Every day we go to work, and we move in our old Communist world. But after work we come here to this City of Truth,'' said Ivailo Slatanov of the Academy of Science's Biophysics Institute. In Veliko Turnovo, 150 miles northeast of Sofia, Bulgaria's first multiparty Parliament in 44 years faced a constitutional crisis Tuesday as it convened its inaugural session without a president. Mladenov resigned Friday after admitting he suggested in December tanks be used to disperse tens of thousands of demonstrators rallying against communist power. No tanks were ever used. He had been instrumental a month earlier in toppling Bulgaria's hard-line leaders, but the Communist Party remained in control of the government. The opening session, a ceremonial affair held in sweltering heat, was adjourned after only 40 minutes and will resume July 17 at the Parliament building in Sofia. The Grand National Assembly's first task will be to agree on a presidential candidate and elections. There is no precedent for electing a president in Bulgaria's parliamentary history.

DOC.HEAD: A Boost for New York & Dinkins; Now the Dems Need Candidates
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf pvs, ``Democrats will... to UPDATE with Brown on possible convention changes; SUBS 15th graf pvs, Brown had... with Brown remark on New Orleans
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Chairman Ronald Brown made it official today _ the party's 1992 national convention will be held in New York City. ``Democrats will nominate the next president of the United States two years from now this week in America's most dynamic city and in one of the world's greatest cities _ New York, the Big Apple,'' Brown said in announcing the decision. Brown also said he was considering several format changes for the convention, including possibly cutting the event from four days to three and holding it on the weekend instead of mid-week. Brown, flanked by Democratic members of the New York congressional delegation, made the selection announcement at party headquarters before heading to New York to celebrate the news with Mayor David Dinkins and other city officials. New York was Brown's favorite from the outset of the search and word of his choice leaked Monday after the chairman told top aides he had made up his mind. New York officials believe the convention will pump some $100 million into the city's economy, and landing the event is a plum for Dinkins, who lobbied agressively for more than a year to convince Brown to bring the party to New York, which hosted Democratic conventions in 1976 and 1980. ``It's a real shot in the arm for the city, and a real triumph for Dinkins,'' said New York state Democratic Chairman John Marino. It was at the 1976 convention that the party nominated its last winner, Jimmy Carter, and Brown predicted New York would bring the Democrats luck again. ``In the 1990s, America will need a world class leader,'' Brown said. ``George Bush falls short of that mark. In New York _ a world class city _ we Democrats will nominate a president capable of reclaiming America's rightful place as the world's most vigorous advocate of freedom and most potent ally of Democracy.'' Even before Brown's official announcement there was renewed speculation over who will be the star of the nomination show at Madison Square Garden, with New York Gov. Mario Cuomo figuring prominently in the discussions. ``I think Cuomo will make the bid,'' said Democratic consultant Bob Beckel, who predicted a handful of Democrats ultimately would enter the 1992 race. For his part, Cuomo said landing the convention was ``great news'' for New York City. But the governor, who faces re-election this year, said the site would not affect his decision whether to enter the presidential race. In any event, Cuomo said a New York convention wouldn't boost a Cuomo candidacy. ``You could make the argument that having it in a state other than your own would be better,'' he said Tuesday. Brown grew up in New York and is close to Dinkins, making the city his favorite from the outset of the site search. New Orleans was the other finalist, but Brown told aides Monday that New York was his choice. The city's early pledge to come up with the more than $20 million needed to get the Garden ready for the event and a pledge by prominent Democratic fund-raisers in the city to fill the party's coffers went a long way in influencing Brown. Brown had said that New Orleans' chances were being hurt by the Louisiana Legislature's passage of strong anti-abortion legislation. ``It was a factor but not the deciding factor,'' Brown said today while offering repeated praise for New Orleans and Louisiana officials. The site search had attracted considerable attention, in part because of the lack of declared Democratic challengers to Bush. ``This is the strangest, quietest presidential political environment I have ever been in,'' said Democratic consultant Frank Greer. But Beckel and other Democratic activists said potential 1992 candidates are taking a fresh look at the race of late because of a growing impression that Bush can be beat. Democratic Sens. Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Albert Gore of Tennessee and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska are among those said to be considering 1992 runs. And in the past week several Democrats have said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt of Missouri has indicated he might reconsider his pledge not to run in 1992. Others frequently mentioned in such speculation include Govs. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia Re-Opens Consulate in China After 31 Years
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia on Wednesday reopened its consulate in the northern Chinese region of Inner Mongolia after a 31-year suspension of consular ties. Consul General Jundui Saara led a flag-raising ceremony at the provisional site of the consulate in Hohhot, the capital of the autonomous region, the official Xinhua News Agency said in a three-sentence report. The dispatch did not say when the two countries decided to resume consular ties, but it likely was discussed when Mongolian President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat visited China in May. His visit was the first for a Mongolian head of government since 1962, and the trip formally normalized three decades of strained relations. About 3.5 million ethnic Mongols live in Inner Mongolia, a swath of steppe and desert just inside China's northern border with Mongolia, which has a population of 2 million. Inner Mongolia remained part of China when outer Mongolia won independence in a 1921 uprising and became the world's second Communist state. Mongolia, which has long been a Soviet satellite state, sided with the Soviet Union when Moscow split with Beijing over ideological differences in the late 1950s.

DOC.HEAD: World Cup Ends, Strikes Begin
DOC.TEXT: A more than monthlong labor truce declared during the soccer World Cup ended Wednesday with strikes at airports and gasoline pumps. The strike by the technicians who approve plane takeoffs and landings stranded thousands of travelers at Italian airports. Unions had called a six-hour strike but the action was called off after 4{ hours when the government agreed to consider their demands, the Transport Ministry said. Strikers want increased overtime pay and more money for increases in productivity. Union officials said they allowed planes running short of fuel to make their scheduled landings, and regular service continued between the mainland and the islands of Sicily and Sardinia. With a few exceptions, Italy's major unions refrained from strikes to ensure visitors would not be inconvenienced during the soccer tournament that ended Sunday. In another labor action, thousands of gas station operators shut their pumps for 24 hours to pressure the government to lower the taxes on their profits. Newsstand dealers seeking more revenue from newspapers have announced they will stay open only in the mornings for three days starting Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Ambush Kills 3
DOC.TEXT: Mozambican rebels killed three people in an ambush in eastern Zambia, bringing to 10 the number killed since Saturday, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The three Zambians died when Mozambique National Resistance rebels ambushed a truck Tuesday near the town of Nyimba, 200 miles east of Lusaka, the state-run Zambia Daily Mail said. Rebels on Saturday axed seven people to death, wounded two and kidnapped an unknown number to act as porters carrying salt into Mozambique for the rebels, the Daily Mail said. The rebels, also known by the Portuguese acronym Renamo, often cross from Mozambique into neighboring Zambia, mainly to steal food and supplies. Zambian troops were sent to the Petauke border district Saturday to patrol roads where attacks have occurred. No rebels have been reported captured in recent days.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Tries to Save Dog; Both Die in Fire
DOC.TEXT: A 18-year-old died in a fire at her home as she tried to save her dog, authorities said Maria Hertzlieb, 18, was pronounced dead at the scene Tuesday, said Lake County Coroner Daniel D. Thomas. ``She went to get her collie dog and evidently it cost her her life,'' Thomas said. ``In all probability there was smoke inhalation.'' Shelby Fire Chief Ronnie Lambert said the woman's body and that of her dog were found together at the bottom of the stairs of the two-story house. Lisa Hertzlieb, the victim's sister, escaped through a second-floor bedroom window, Lambert said. She and her mother, Nilda Bartholomew, suffered smoke inhalation, and her stepfather, David Bartholomew, suffered burns over 15 percent of his body. Lambert said the blaze was caused by an overloaded electrical extension cord.

DOC.HEAD: Only Pipe Feeding West Beirut With Water Bursts
LaserPhoto BEI1
DOC.TEXT: The only pipeline feeding Moslem west Beirut with drinking water burst Wednesday, flooding a coastal highway linking the capital with south Lebanon. About a dozen ramshackle huts on both sides of the Ouzai highway were flooded with water that damaged furniture and created panic among refugees. Several shops were destroyed by the water pouring in from the street at 5 a.m. Some refugees drained the water into buckets which they emptied into the Mediterranean. Others dug holes in the floors of their huts to let the water out. ``I was soaking. I woke up and didn't know what was going on,'' said Fatima Hasan, a squatter living in a beachside hut with her husband and eight children. ``My daughters and I immediately began filling up buckets and emptying them in the sea.'' The water pressure carved a 43-inch crater in the street, which children quickly turned into a swimming pool. There was no word on how long it would take to restore water to the Moslem sector of the Lebanese capital, but the more than 1 million people living there have long been able to manage without potable water by using bottled water or standing in lines at springs.

DOC.HEAD: Police Capture 11 Members of Medellin Cocaine Cartel, Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with police saying today that Escobar was nearly nabbed in the raid. Pickup 8th, `Escobar remains...'
DOC.TEXT: Security forces nearly captured Pablo Escobar, the reputed leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel, when they arrested 11 top cartel members in a raid on a northeastern town, police said today. The raid, which also seized 3{ tons of dynamite, came Tuesday and followed last month's police killing of the mastermind of the cartel's terror campaign. Among the 11 people arrested in Puerto Triunfo, 75 miles east of Bogota, was Escobar's personal physician, according to a national police report read over the RCN radio network. Also captured was one of Escobar's relatives, Hernan Dario Quintero, who supplied dynamite and weapons to gunmen hired to carry out the cartel's bombing and assassination campaigns, the report said. A national police spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press today that security forces nearly nabbed Escobar as well but that the billionaire fugitive escaped into the jungle. The spokesman said Escobar, aided by about 15 bodyguards, fled into the jungle near Puerto Triunfo during the raid. Drug traffickers fighting a 10-month-old war against the government of President Virgilio Barco have responded with more car bombings, massacres and police assassinations that have killed hundreds of people. In Tuesday's raid, police also seized several Soviet-made AK-47 automatic rifles, revolvers, 7,700 pounds of dynamite, sophisticated communications equipment and documents that could lead to Escobar's capture, the police report said. RCN did not give details about the other alleged cartel members arrested. Escobar remains at large despite a massive manhunt to find him. The government is offering a reward of $400,000 for information leading to his capture, dead or alive. Gen. Harold Bedoya, Medellin's army commander, has accused Escobar of the June 23 massacre of 19 people, many of them teen-age students, at a Medellin bar. He said the attack was carried out in retaliation for authorities killing the cartel's terrorist operations chief, John Jairo Arias, in the city June 13. Medellin, Colombia's second-largest city with almost 3 million inhabitants 150 miles northwest of Bogota, has seen much of the drug violence. Authorities say drug traffickers have placed a bounty of $4,300 on the heads of all police officers in the city. More than 100 have been killed this year. The army said security forces on July 4 seized 800 pounds of cocaine aboard a plane that was about to take off for the United States. Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a Medellin cartel leader killed in December on Colombia's northern coast. The drug war began in August, when traffickers were blamed for the assassination of leading presidential hopeful Luis Carlos Galan. Two more presidential candidates were assassinated before last month's election, and traffickers were linked to at least one of those. Since August, Barco's administration has extradited 15 drug suspects and confiscated hundreds of properties belonging to the cocaine magnates. At one time, the Medellin cartel was believed responsible for most of the cocaine that is smuggled into the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Witness: Cocaine With the Mayor on Boats, Homes, Apartments, The Bahamas
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A 27-year-old woman testified today that she and Marion Barry snorted cocaine repeatedly from 1987 to 1989 in apartments, homes, boats and on two trips to the Bahamas. ``I hit the cocaine and he hit the cocaine,'' Theresa Southerland said of a get-together with Barry in March 1988 at the Washington residence of a friend of the mayor. Barry scooped up cocaine on a business card and inhaled it, Southerland told the jury at Barry's drug and perjury trial. On another occasion, she tried opium with Barry, but didn't like it, she testified. ``It had a funny taste,'' she said, and made her feel ``lightheaded.'' She said the mayor smoked it with restaurateur Hassan Mohammadi at Mohammadi's home. The restaurateur testified that he knew Southerland only as Miss T. Southerland said she met Barry at a Washington nightclub and that the two became intimate. ``Marion invited me'' to the Bahamas around Thanksgiving 1987, she said. Barry produced some cocaine, piled it atop a dollar bill and took ``three or four hits,'' she said. She asked Barry if she could go on a 1988 trip to the Bahamas. They stayed in separate rooms ``because I was concerned about the press,'' she said. She had carried some cocaine with her on the trip and the mayor helped her snort it, she testified. Southerland said that on two occasions, the mayor invited her aboard boats moored at Washington-area marinas, where the two used cocaine. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson issued a bench warrant for Southerland when she failed to appear in court Tuesday due to a scheduling mixup with her lawyer. On Tuesday, Barry's lawyers sought to portray Mohammadi as willing to tell any story to avoid being deported to his native Iran. What would happen if he were sent back? asked Robert Mance, one of Barry's lawyers. ``I would be prosecuted'' by the ``new regime'' in Tehran for having worked for the deposed government of the late Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi at the Iranian Embassy here, Mohammadi replied. Mohammadi testified that he supplied cocaine and opium to Barry at least 30 times. He said he and the mayor snorted cocaine in the upstairs bathroom at Barry's home while 200 guests were outside the house at a summer crab feast. He said he and the mayor smoked opium repeatedly at locations around Washington. Mohammadi said initially that he used cocaine only with Barry. Under questioning from Mance, he acknowledged that he did use it once with a woman who was with Barry on a 1987 trip to the Bahamas. Under defense questioning, Mohammadi acknowledged he had pleaded guilty and cooperated with the government in a prosecution involving payoffs to an immigration official. The bribes were on behalf of wealthy Iranians seeking permanent resident status in the United States. ``Every time that you get into trouble ... you get out by cooperating,'' Mance told Mohammadi. In connection with the probe of Barry, Mohammadi has pleaded guilty to conspiring to possess cocaine. If Mohammadi is found to have cooperated fully with the government, the Justice Department will recommend that he not be deported. Mance suggested that Mohammadi's differing stories influenced by his tenuous status in the United States and his desire to please prosecutors by telling then what they want to hear. Mohammadi detailed at the trial how the mayor shoved cocaine into a marijuana cigarette and smoked it, calling it an ``M.B. Special.'' Mance noted that Mahammadi didn't mention the incident in his grand jury testimony in April. Mohammadi said he didn't tell the grand jury about it because he wasn't asked about it. He said he lied to police in February 1989 by denying that the mayor was involved with drugs, then reported back to Barry on what questions the police had asked. ``I covered wherever I could,'' said Mohammadi. ``I was a true friend for Mr. Mayor; I was always there for Mr. Mayor.'' The restaurateur said he started cooperating with the government after Barry was arrested Jan. 18 in an FBI sting because ``everybody came from the woodwork. I did not have any choice'' because he had been implicated in Barry's drug use by others. Barry is charged with 10 counts of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his drug use.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Killed in Gun Battle Involving Mohawk Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with color, details. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Ambulances were...' ADDS 2 grafs background at end.
DOC.TEXT: Provincial riot police and Mohawk Indians blocking access to a golf course expansion project engaged in a gun battle today, and a police officer was shot and killed, authorities said. Mohawk leaders also said they took a police officer hostage, but police did not immediately confirm the report. ``We are now attacking the barricades and trying to pull them down,'' said police spokesman Richard Bourdon. ``Indians inside are firing at police.'' Police said Cpl. Marcel Lemay, 31, was shot in the mouth and died about an hour after arriving at nearby St-Eustache hospital, doctors said. Hundreds of shots were exchanged in the gun battle along the blocked access road. The crackle of semi-automatic gunfire and the thud of tear gas canisters could be heard from the area as armed provincial police officers, dressed in olive-green fatigues and wearing gas masks, confronted the young natives, who had handkerchiefs tied across their noses and mouths. As the wind moved the tear gas back across their lines, police quickly retreated. Ambulances were dispatched to a campsite where about 300 Indians, including women and children, have been living to oversee barricades in the land dispute involving Oka, a town of 3,000 that is 18 miles west of Montreal, and the nearby Kanesatake Indian community. South of Montreal, another Mohawk community blocked roads in solidarity with the Indians in Oka, and thousands of commuters could not reach the city. In Quebec City, acting public security minister Michel Page said he did not authorize the police action in Oka. An aide to Premier Robert Bourassa said the premier was not contacted before police moved in. Earlier this week, John Ciaccia, the minister for native affairs, pleaded with Oka town council to put its plans for a golf course on hold. About 100 provinical riot police surrounded the wooded area in Oka, a suburb northwest of Montreal Island early today. They ordered the people behind the barricade to move away so it could be torn down to enforce a court injunction ordering the Indians to let traffic pass. Bourdon said police then moved in to tear them down and were shot at. ``The reason we moved was because the Mohawks were breaking the law,'' Bourdon said. ``They were blocking a public road and this is a criminal act.'' A Mohawk woman standing near the police lines in Oka, Eleanor Montour, 67, said: ``I find it awful that police would attack our people.'' ``We're not savages, we're proud to be Mohawks,'' she said. ``We were pushed around for centuries and we're being pushed again and we're getting awfully tired of it.'' Police and the Mohawks pulled back from their positions after the gunfight. The Indians then seized four police cars and two vans and used a commandeered front-end loader to crush and overturn the vehicles to form another barricade. Thick black smoke belched from a pile of burning tires. The Indians also used the front-end loader to tear up one green on the golf course, a photographer at the site said. One jubilant Mohawk fired his shotgun as the police cars were put in place. Armed Indians barricaded a road to the golf course three months ago to stop the expansion project. Oka _ which is next to the Kanesatake Mohawk community near the golf course _ rents the land to the operators of the private nine-hole course. The operators say they want to cut down the white pine forest on the land and expand the course to 18 holes. The land has been in the hands of the town since 1947, but the Kanesatake Mohawk settlement surrounds it, and the Indians have always maintained it is their land. In a show of support for the Mohawks at Oka, armed Mohawks from the Kahnawake reserve south of Montreal set up roadblocks on two main highways leading to the Mercier Bridge, blocking thousands of residents on the south shore of the St. Lawrence River from getting to their jobs in Montreal. They parked pickup trucks and other vehicles including a dump truck across the highways. Construction workers on the bridge were evacuated. The roadblacks will remain until provincial police pull out of Oka, said one of the Mohawks.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Puppy Killer in 11 Minutes
DOC.TEXT: A jury deliberated 11 minutes before convicting a man of animal cruelty for stabbing his rambunctious puppy to death. Everston Eugene Webb, 22, of Orange Park, was convicted Tuesday. Prosecutors said they will seek the maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $10,000 fine when Webb is sentenced July 31 by Circuit Court Judge Giles P. Lewis. Webb stabbed the pup at least five times in the chest with a butcher knife at his home May 11. He testified he killed the dog to ``put it out of its misery'' because it had been injured by a friend. However, under cross-examination, Webb said the puppy annoyed him when it dug in the yard and got into the family's garbage.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Rattles Southeast Alaska
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake shook parts of southeast Alaska and the southwest corner of the Yukon early today, but no damage or injuries were reported. Paul Whitmore of the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center said the quake registered a preliminary magnitude of 5.7 on the Richter scale, too weak to generate a tsunami or seismic sea wave. The quake was relatively shallow, about nine miles beneath the surface, and was centered about 40 miles northwest of Haines, Alaska, Whitmore said. It was felt strongly in Haines and also was widely noticed in Juneau and in Whitehorse, the Yukon territorial capital, he said. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. An earthquake of 5 on the Richter scale can cause considerable damage, and 6 can be severe. The quake that killed 131 people in 1964 in Alaska registered 8.4 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Fires Blacken Thousands of Acres
DOC.TEXT: More than 2,000 firefighters on Wednesday mastered a series of wildfires that had blackened scenic southern France in the first major wave of fires to strike this year. About 50 separate blazes burned through Tuesday night into Wednesday, the worst consuming 4,950 acres of forest near the village of Coudoux, north of Marseille. At least a dozen homes were destroyed in the region, but no one was killed. Three firefighters suffered smoke inhalation. Officials said the casualty toll could have been much worse. In a nearby pine forest, heat from the blaze exploded a stock of bombs buried after World War II. Firefighters stayed clear of the area. Fires also struck near Aix-en-Provence, Septemes-les-Vallons and dozens of other locations, but there were no reports of property losses or injuries. In all, some 8,650 acres of brushland and forest burned. Flames were driven by 75 mph wind pushing down the Rhone River from the north. Investigators said at least two fires had suspicious origins. A local resident said she saw youths hurl flaming, gasoline-soaked tennis balls into dry brush.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
Free Food, Transportation at Summit Stifles Business in Houston
DOC.TEXT: Summit? What summit? Houston's cab drivers and business owners had looked forward to big profits from the onslaught of officials, aides and journalists at this week's economic summit. Not so. Lavish spreads of food and prompt bus service _ all free _ left local people with empty cash registers. ``Business hathere might as well not even be a summit as far as I'm concerned,'' cab driver Charles Rough said. ``Nobody needs transportation.'' Not even President Bush's favorite barbecue spot couls been so slow, d lure thousands of summit-goers out of the George R. Brown Convention Center. Why leave? They were being served round-the-clock buffets of kung pao chicken, swordfish and angel hair pasta. The endless selections, and roadblocks that made traveling a hassle, did wonders for the caterers but not much for Houston's Tex-Mex and Texas barbecue eateries. ``It's been terrible. We usually serve 500 people a day, but Monday (the first day of the summit) we only served 100,'' said Robin Upton, a manager at Otto's Bar-B-Q, President Bush's favorite spot for mesquite-grilled fixings in Houston. ``They have barricaded the people so they can't get out or in. We are right on Memorial (Parkway), where all the trafure aid. They gave West Germany the green light to complete a $3.1 billion loan, and aid from the others will surely follow. Overall, it is a giant leap toward trust after decades of Cold War suspicion and brinksmanship. The summit urged Gorbachev to take ``more radical steps'' to shift billions now spent on the Red Army and on Cuba into the sad Soviet domestic economy. He's probably planning to do this anyway in his drive to improve living conditions and hold to the levers of power. If Gorbachev succeeds in this, he stands to gain ``meaningful and sustained economic assistance,'' the windup summit communique said. It was the West's second philosophical swing within a week. Not as dramatic perhaps as NATO's decision to reduce its reliance on nuclear weapons, the rendering of first technical and then probably more direct assistance can't help but draw East and West even closer. ``The NATO summit took us toward a more peaceful world,'' a British spokesman said on behalf Margaret Thatcher. ``She believes this takes us to a more prosperous world.'' A senior U.S. official who has played a prominent role in framing administration policy put it this way: ``There is a potential for a new economic relationship between the Soviets and the industrial West. I wouldn't say the relationship is there yet. But what Gorbachev gets out of this summit is a clear, unequivocal affirmation of the belief of the Seven that it is incumbent upon the West to help perestroika succeed.'' Reflecting, the official concluded: ``What this says is that we're serious about this. We would not be going through this effort and analysis otherwise.'' Unthinkable only last July, when Gorbachev knocked on the summit door and was brushed aside as a Communist intruder, the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Japan, Italy and Canada have themselves crossed a threshold. They emerged from this year's summit in sun-baked Houston, itself a testimony to nervy free enterprise, dedicated to perestroika and committed to invest in Gorbachev's success. ``There's a common determination that we have to respond very positively to Mr. Gorbachev's request for a sustained economic dialogue between the Soviet Union and the Group of Seven,'' Canadian Foreign Minister Joe Clark said. In declaring nuclear weapons a highly unlikely last resort, the NATO allies in their 41st year moved beyond containment toward one Europe. In committing themselves to help Gorbachev in ``practical ways,'' the summit leaders blurred the 45-year divide between capitalism and communism. At the start, the industrialized democracies will take measured steps, beginning with a study conducted by bankers and other experts of the inefficient Soviet economy and the tentative moves by Gorbachev over his five years in power toward free-market reforms. The study, under the supervision of the International Monetary Fund, is supposed to be completed by December _ although officials at the World Bank said a year would be more like it. In the meantime, a tide of technical assistance is likely to flow West to East. At this stage, Bush is reluctant to go further. He wants the Soviets to cut military spending, abandon Cuba and convert to a genuine free-market system. The summit agreed, and so if these conditions are met, Bush may brave political fire from his right and propose more significant U.S. aid. ``I don't think you should ever say never,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Tuesday in refusing to permanently rule out direct U.S. aid. And will Gorbachev be pleased with the results of this summit? ``I think he will find in the response a positive encouragement to persist in his reforms, and that seems to us all the essential point,'' Douglas Hurd, the British foreign secretary, concluded.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is the AP's chief diplomatic writer.

DOC.HEAD: Student Gets Life for Killing Professor who Denied Degree
DOC.TEXT: A graduate student was sentenced to life in prison for murdering a professor who denied him a doctorate. Jens Peter Hansen, 42, was sentenced Tuesday for the first-degree murder of University of Florida cancer researcher Arthur Kimura last Sept. 1. The sentence means Hansen must serve at least 25 years before being eligible for parole. Circuit Judge Robert Cates also sentenced him to four years for a burglary-with-assault conviction, to be served concurrently. A jury convicted Hansen on June 21. Hansen and his attorney, Steve Bernstein, asked unsuccessfully for a retrial. They claimed Hansen was insane when he devised an elaborate plan to kill Kimura in the professor's home and attempt to make it appear to be suicide. Assistant State Attorney John Carlin argued against the insanity claim. ``What caused the tragedy was a monumental ego and a revengeful spirit,'' he said. Kimura was head of a committee that in August 1989 denied Hansen a doctoral degree in pathology. Trial testimony showed that Kimura and other committee members voted to drop Hansen from the program because he was straying from his goals and conducting low-quality research. On Sept. 1, Hansen packed rope, a pistol and a padded baseball bat into a rented van and drove to Kimura's home. He planned to kill the professor by knocking him out and placing him in his car with the engine running to make it appear to be a suicide, testimony showed. The plan apparently failed when Kimura set off his burglar alarm, alerting police. Hansen shot Kimura in the head outside the house and was arrested a few minutes later, testimony showed.
