We reject protectionism in all its forms. The successful outcome of the Uruguay Round has the highest priority on the international economic agenda. Consequently, we stress our determination to take the difficult political decisions necessary to achieve far-reaching, substantial results in all areas of the Uruguay Round by the end of this year. ... We confirm our strong support for the essential broad objectives of the negotiations; reform of agricultural policies; a substantial and balanced package of measures to improve market access; strengthened multilateral rules and disciplines; the incorporation of new issues of services, trade-related investment measures, and intellectual property protection within the GATT framework; and integration of developing countries into the international trading system. ... As regards agriculture, achieving the long-term objective of the reform of agricultural policies is critical to permit the greater liberalization of trade in agricultural products. ... We therefore reaffirm our commitment to the long-term objective of the reform, i.e., to allow market signals to influence agriculture production and to establish a fair and market-oriented agricultural trading system. ... The achievement of this objective requires each of us to make substantial, progressive reductions in support and protection of agriculture -- covering internal regimes, market access, and export subsidies -- and develop rules governing sanitary and phytosanitary measures. Variations among countries in the mechanisms of agricultural support reflect differences in the social and economic conditions of farming. The negotiations on agriculture should therefore be conducted in a framework that includes a common instrument of measurement, provides for commitments to be made in an equitable way among all countries, and takes into account concerns about food security. The framework should contain specific assurances that, by appropriate use of the common measure as well as other ways, participants would reduce not only internal support but also export subsidies and import protection in a related way. ...
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Burning Barricades, Bulldozers: Nicaragua During Strike
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
LaserPhoto MGA6
DOC.TEXT: To the kids in the working-class neighborhood of Villa Don Bosco, it was like a giant puzzle: How to fit the paving stones back into the torn-up street just the way they were. It was going slowly. The stones had been used by backers of a massive Sandinista strike to make barricades, tying up this capital of 1 million. In a few neighborhoods they had been taken down Wednesday and piled neatly alongside the ruptured streets, available to be used again. But on the northern highway, the main entry to Managua, barriers of burning cars and the Maltese cross-shaped stones remained. Army bulldozers pulled them down and left. Police stood by as strike supporters rebuilt them. In some cases police even directed the reconstruction. ``With so many people, what can we do?'' shrugged a member of the Sandinista-controlled police. He said their orders were, essentially, to keep the feuding sides apart. Radio Sandino, the voice of the Sandinista National Liberation Front, is a drumbeat of accusations that the strikers are under attack by backers of the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro instead of being the instigators. There are dark hints of an American invasion. North of Managua protesters felled large trees across highways and rolled boulders onto the road. One bore the black-painted message, ``Everything Will Be Better,'' the Sandinista campaign slogan of last February's elections in which the Sandinistas lost the presidency. At the edge of the capital police stood by as protesters threw four-pronged spikes known as ``Miguelitos,'' or ``little Michales,'' under the wheels of moving vehicles. Pro-Sandinistas with megaphones tried to whip up the crowds, urging them to ``stand fast.'' In some poorer neighborhoods squads of men in red-and-black Sandinista caps and scarves, armed with AK-47 assault rifles, prowled the unpaved streets checking identities of strangers. It has been 11 years since the last Sandinista uprising but clearly, they haven't forgotten how. The paving stones are still called ``Somoza stones'' by some. In the 1979 uprising that toppled dictator Anastasio Somoza, barricades of the stones played a key role in allowing the Sandinistas to hang onto control of much of the city. Somoza owned the factory that produced them. Weapons are increasingly in evidence in Managua. There are few shoppers in the public markets, gasoline is hard to find, and hundreds of businesses are closed because people can't get through the barricades to go to work. Reliable information hardly exists these days and rumors fly like shrapnel across the hot, muggy lakeside capital. Wednesday's biggie was that the airport, closed by a strike of traffic controllers, might open. About 50 people were there Wednesday morning, some having spent the night on the marble floor. But there were no planes coming or going. Zurita Winzeler, 25, a naturalized American citizen who left Nicaragua for Miami in 1983, had come back to Nicaragua for a wedding and got caught by the strike. ``We're just waiting for the first flight out, we don't care where,'' she said. ``We thought things would be better here under Chamorro. But the Sandinistas are still the ones running the show.''

DOC.HEAD: Historic New Economic Links Parallels Shift In NATO Doctrine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs Thatcher quote, 8th graf; should stand.
DOC.TEXT: However quarrelsome, the Western industrial giants took a historic and probably irreversible turn at their 16th economic summit toward a permanent post-Cold War relationship with the Soviet Union. President Bush and his six partners agreed Mikhail Gorbachev was entitled to their assistance. They argued over details: How much? How soon? What in return? But they agreed on immediate technical assistance and dispatched a study team to recommend how to target future aid. They gave West Germany the green light to complete a $3.1 billion loan, and aid from the others will surely follow. Overall, it is a giant leap toward trust after decades of Cold War suspicion and brinksmanship. The summit urged Gorbachev to take ``more radical steps'' to shift billions now spent on the Red Army and on Cuba into the sad Soviet domestic economy. He's probably planning to do this anyway in his drive to improve living conditions and hold to the levers of power. If Gorbachev succeeds in this, he stands to gain ``meaningful and sustained economic assistance,'' the windup summit communique said. It was the West's second philosophical swing within a week. Not as dramatic perhaps as NATO's decision to reduce its reliance on nuclear weapons, the rendering of first technical and then probably more direct assistance can't help but draw East and West even closer. ``Coming after last week's very successful NATO summit, which took a major stride towards a more peaceful world, the results of thee meeting in House are an important step towards a more prosperous world for everyone,'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said at a news conference. A senior U.S. official who has played a prominent role in framing administration policy put it this way: ``There is a potential for a new economic relationship between the Soviets and the industrial West. I wouldn't say the relationship is there yet. But what Gorbachev gets out of this summit is a clear, unequivocal affirmation of the belief of the Seven that it is incumbent upon the West to help perestroika succeed.'' Reflecting, the official concluded: ``What this says is that we're serious about this. We would not be going through this effort and analysis otherwise.'' Unthinkable only last July, when Gorbachev knocked on the summit door and was brushed aside as a Communist intruder, the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Japan, Italy and Canada have themselves crossed a threshold. They emerged from this year's summit in sun-baked Houston, itself a testimony to nervy free enterprise, dedicated to perestroika and committed to invest in Gorbachev's success. ``There's a common determination that we have to respond very positively to Mr. Gorbachev's request for a sustained economic dialogue between the Soviet Union and the Group of Seven,'' Canadian Foreign Minister Joe Clark said. In declaring nuclear weapons a highly unlikely last resort, the NATO allies in their 41st year moved beyond containment toward one Europe. In committing themselves to help Gorbachev in ``practical ways,'' the summit leaders blurred the 45-year divide between capitalism and communism. At the start, the industrialized democracies will take measured steps, beginning with a study conducted by bankers and other experts of the inefficient Soviet economy and the tentative moves by Gorbachev over his five years in power toward free-market reforms. The study, under the supervision of the International Monetary Fund, is supposed to be completed by December _ although officials at the World Bank said a year would be more like it. In the meantime, a tide of technical assistance is likely to flow West to East. At this stage, Bush is reluctant to go further. He wants the Soviets to cut military spending, abandon Cuba and convert to a genuine free-market system. The summit agreed, and so if these conditions are met, Bush may brave political fire from his right and propose more significant U.S. aid. ``I don't think you should ever say never,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Tuesday in refusing to permanently rule out direct U.S. aid. And will Gorbachev be pleased with the results of this summit? ``I think he will find in the response a positive encouragement to persist in his reforms, and that seems to us all the essential point,'' Douglas Hurd, the British foreign secretary, concluded.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is the AP's chief diplomatic writer.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Partners Reach Deal on Farm Subsidies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Bush comments, subbing 4 grafs for 3rd graf pvs, The agreement
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the world's seven richest democracies today reached a last-minute compromise on government payments to farmers in hopes of giving a push to stalled efforts to overhaul the world trading system. President Bush and the other leaders, winding up their annual economic summit, endorsed the compromise language in a short morning session. The deal between the United States and its European trading partners had been arranged during an all-night bargaining session among negotiators. Bush said at a mid-day news conference he hoped the compromise would help efforts to reach a broad international trade agreement in negotiations that have been going on for four years. The summit agreement called for across-the-board cuts in all categories of farm subsidies, as demanded by the United States, but it also contained less specific language that was more acceptable to the Europeans. Bush acknowledged that ``there will be some political opposition'' in the United States to phasing out subsidies at home. But when asked if he would press for such action, he said, ``Absolutely. We have to do it.'' Noting that no quick action was expected in Europe, he said of a U.S. effort, ``That's a little down the road.'' The final language in the communique urged each nation ``to make substantial, progressive reductions'' in the areas of export subsidies, internal price supports and barriers to imports. The compromise also contained a European demand that it be allowed to work out a formula to measure, and then reduce, a variety of farm subsidies. This measuring mechanism had been opposed by the Americans. The leaders pledged to maintain ``a high level of personal involvement'' to bring a successful end to the Uruguay Round of international trade talks in December. The farm fight had been a major focus in the three days of talks between the heads of government of the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Italy, Canada and Britain. The summit was held on the campus of Rice University. The sessions were also attended by a representative from the 12-nation European Community. ``We consider the text in general as a satisfactory outcome of this meeting,'' said a community official, demanding anonymity. ``Everybody has got something out of it.'' A British official hailed the farm agreement and said Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher believed it would mean a successful windup of the world trade talks. Bush had made achieving progress on farm subsidies a top priority at this year's summit, believing that without movement on farm subsidies an ambitious effort to rewrite the rules governing world trade could be doomed. The United States has a lot riding on the 96-nation Uruguay Round talks. The president has said they offer the best hope of expanding export opportunities for U.S. farmers and businesses and thus reducing America's huge trade deficits. Bush spoke forcefully during the sessions but he faced strong resistance from European countries, who contended that his insistence on complete elimination of all trade-distorting farm subsidies could end up costing the jobs of up to 3 million farmers. The leaders had extended their afternoon session on Tuesday for an extra 90 minutes, grappling with the farm subsidy issue, finally sending lower level negotiators off to work through the night in an attempt to come up with compromise language. The draft agreement specifically mentions reductions in the three areas of farm subsidies targeted by the United States for cuts. These include export subsidies, internal price supports and barriers to imported goods. The United States had insisted that the areas be spelled out in any agreement, despite opposition from the European Community. But in an effort to bridge the gap between the two sides, the agreement also refers to the community's more general approach to cutting subsidies which employs a technical yardstick to measure subsidy levels. The global trade negotiations, which opened in 1986 in Uruguay, are due to wind up with a final round of hard bargaining in early December in Brussels, Belgium. European Community officials have long fought to protect their expensive export subsidies. They contend that getting rid of the program would translate into higher farm prices in Europe and result in the loss of jobs for millions of farmers. The program gives exporters help so more high-priced European farm products can compete with lower prices on the world market. The United States has responded by setting up its own Export Enhancement Program. American officials also have pressed the community to open its markets wider to foreign farm products and reduce farm payments that encourage overproduction of crops. The Uruguay Round is being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and agreement for promoting freer trade.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Carry Out Threat of Nationwide Road Blockade, Angering Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Farmers ignored motorists' jeers and blocked roads nationwide Wednesday with tractors, trucks and combines to try to pressure the government into guaranteeing minimum farm prices. ``All main highways have been blocked with farm machinery,'' police spokesman Aleksander Chyl said shortly after the start of the two-hour protest organized by the farmers union Rural Solidarity. All 49 provinces were affected, including the road to the main border crossing with the Soviet Union at Brest, PAP said. In addition to highways, many local streets were blocked. Police did not interfere. Although the protest appeared largely successful, there were no signs that the government intended to retreat from its refusal to grant minimum prices. The roadblocks were the latest challenge to the Solidarity-led government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who in recent months has grappled with strikes by farmers and rail workers and a stream of criticism from Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa over his tough economic policies. In an attempt to smooth relations with workers, Mazowiecki met for two hours Wednesday with a blue-collar delegation from the Gdansk shipyards. Union members there accuse the government of forgetting its roots and not explaining itself to the people who elected it. On the main Warsaw-Poznan road just west of Warsaw, promptly at noon farmers rolled four tractors, a truck and a delivery van decorated with white-and-red Polish flags across the highway. Traffic piled up for a half-mile almost immediately. Some frustrated drivers turned around and others parked their vehicles and sat in a roadside restaurant. Some drivers yelled at the farmers. ``Who's going to pay this bill?'' stranded driver Mariusz Maciejeski shouted, referring to his lost time. ``If this were 20 years ago, during Communist times, you would be hanging from a tree,'' said an outraged retiree, who hit Rural Solidarity chairman Gabriel Janowski on the shoulder. Janowski remained calm and appealed to motorists for sympathy. ``I hope you understand what this is all about. This is our only form of protest,'' he told one couple headed on vacation with their children. They had shouted an epithet at him. A few of the drivers did sympathize. ``It's not very pleasant to sit here for two hours, but in my opinion the farmers are right _ nobody listens to them,'' said Mariusz Wojciechowski of Suwalki in northeastern Poland. Janowski's Rural Solidarity is independent of the Solidarity trade union movement under Walesa, although the unions were broadly allied in the fight against communism. Walesa is on vacation and planned no statement on the farmers' protest, his office said Wednesday. Janowski said the protest was justified despite some concessions granted farmers this week. He said guaranteed minimum prices were as necessary for farmers as a national minimum wage is for workers. Poland's 2.5 million private farmers have been among the groups most harshly affected by the Mazowiecki government's ``shock therapy'' to reform the Polish economy. Higher consumer prices have sharply limited the market for their crops and dairy products, and the big cooperatives that buy from them are on the brink of bankruptcy, squeezed by high interest rates. On Monday, the Cabinet acknowledged the farmers' difficult situation and made several conciliatory gestures, including lowering interest rates on farm loans and providing emergency funds to allow dairies to pay off debts to farmers. But the government has refused to give in to the demand for government-set minimum prices, saying that would run counter to the basic principle of establishing a market-based economy. The government twice has had to resort to force in the past month to counter farm protests, first to unblock the main road between Gdansk and Warsaw and then to end a three-day sit-in at the Agriculture Ministry.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Welcome New Economic Cooperation
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union welcomes efforts by the leading capitalist powers to create a new model of economic cooperation between East and West, a Soviet spokesman said Wednesday. Speaking at a regular news briefing, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said his country welcomed new approaches that ``correspond to the spirit of the times.'' Gerasimov's comments were reported by the Tass news agency. Wrapping up a three-day summit meeting in Houston, Texas, the leaders of the seven largest capitalist economies urged that Western technical assistance be dispatched immediately to help the Soviet Union ``mobilize its own resources.'' They ordered a study to recommend ways to ensure that any future aid will be useful. President Bush said he would brief Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on the results of the summit, and had already sent a cable to him. France and Germany have urged a large aid package to Gorbachev to bolster his reforms, but other countries expressed doubts whether the Soviet Union could use the aid effectively. Gerasimov added that the Soviet Union also backed appeals by the capitalist powers for negotiated settlements to the conflicts in Afganistan, Cambodia and Angola. He said the Soviet Union regretted a paragraph in summit documents on the Soviet Union's dispute with Japan over the Kurill Islands. The Soviet Union took control of the islands after World War II, and both sides consider them to historically be part of their territory. The two countries never have signed a peace treaty ending hostilities in World War II because of their differences over the islands. ``The Soviet Union favors concluding a peace treaty with Japan that, naturally, will cover the geographic aspect,'' Gerasimov said. ``But talks to conclude such a treaty are part of bilateral relations and therefore we regard the attempt at internationalizing the question of the so-called Northern Territories as counterproductive.''

DOC.HEAD: Dog's Death Blamed on Airline
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose dog died during a four-hour flight delay has sued two airlines for $13 million, charging that the animal was left in the cargo hold on a hot summer day. Mary Elizabeth O'Brien of McLean, Va., filed the lawsuit Tuesday against Piedmont Airlines and USAir. The lawsuit claims her purebred chow chow, Maxwell, was kept in the cargo area of a Piedmont Airlines plane at Baltimore-Washington International Airport during part of a four-hour delay for mechanical repairs July 12, 1987. The high temperature at the airport that day was 94 degrees. The woman contends she reminded Piedmont employees of the high temperature, asked them repeatedly to be sure the dog had water and sufficient ventilation, the lawsuit said. USAir merged with Piedmont last year. Dave Shipley, USAir spokesman, said Tuesday that the company does not comment on lawsuits.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury: Debt Limit Must Be Raised or Government Will Default
DOC.TEXT: The government likely will default on its debt for the first time next month unless Congress raises the limit before leaving Aug. 6 on its month-long recess, the Treasury Department warned on Wednesday. ``Treasury's current estimates show that the permanent ceiling of $3.12 trillion will be sufficient only until mid-August,'' Treasury Undersecretary Robert R. Glauber told the House Ways and Means Committee. The nation's debt topped the $3 trillion mark last April and by Monday had surpassed $3.09 trillion. While Glauber did not say how much of an increase was needed immediately, he did provide estimated ceilings for the next three fiscal years to guide congressional and White House budget negotiators as they continue their budget-cutting talks. ``We estimate that a debt limit of $3.51 trillion will be sufficient'' to last through the 1991 fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, he said. Current estimates indicate a need for ceilings of $3.81 trillion through fiscal 1992 and $4.05 trillion through fiscal 1993. Rep. Sam Gibbons, D-Fla., expressed anger that the Bush administration was planning to add hundreds of billions of dollars to the national debt. ``He's the president of the United States, he's convinced the voters they don't need to pay for anything, we can just keep on borrowing,'' Gibbons said. ``My answer to him is, `No.''' Another panel member, Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., asked Glauber if he felt ``a twinge of hypocrisy'' asking for increased borrowing at a time that the administration is supporting a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget. ``No,'' he replied. Glauber testified that without an increase in the debt limit before the congressional recess, it is likely the Treasury will run out of cash and borrowing authority and efault on $20 billion of notes maturing on Aug. 15 and interest payments totaling about $21 billion due that day. ``Also, the United States most likely could not honor, on Aug. 3, $3 billion of military retirement and salary payments or payments totaling over $11 billion to Social Security and supplemental security income recipients, railroad retirees and veterans,'' he added. Glauber also repeated Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's warning last month that the government's estimates are uncertain because of difficulty in predicting the cash needed to bail out the savings and loans industry. The government narrowly averted its first default last November when Congress raised the debt limit from $2.8 trillion for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. It also had come close to default on several other occasions. The national debt has more than tripled since the beginning of the decade as the Treasury was forced to borrow more and more money to finance government spending that exceeds tax receipts. The annual deficits have gone down from their peak of over $200 billion a year, but the deficit still totaled $152.1 billion in the year ending last Sept. 30. It totaled $151.68 billion after the first eight months of the current fiscal year and some analysts say it could return to the $200 billion level again by year's end.

DOC.HEAD: NYU President to Leave in 1991
DOC.TEXT: New York University President John Brademas, credited with transforming the university from a commuter school to a national university, will step down next year, officials said Wednesday. Brademas, who came to NYU in 1981 after 11 terms as a Democratic congressman from Indiana, will step down as president in December 1991, said NYU spokesman Virgil Renzulli. He would officially retire in March 1992 at age 65, after a nearly three-month sabbatical. Brademas would become president emeritus and help the university raise money and develop its international programs. ``Under his tutelage NYU basically went from a commuter school, with most of our students coming from the metropolitan New York area, and became a major national research university,'' Renzulli said. During his tenure, Brademas recruited top faculty members and saw enrollment soar to about 40,000 students. He also helped raise $800 million and increase the university's endowment from $287.5 million to $540 million. To ease his departure, the responsibilities of NYU Chancellor L. Jay Oliva, considered a likely successor, have been expanded to include oversight of campus construction and the implementation of new programs. Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of the NYU trustees, said the board hopes to name a new president before Brademas leaves. The university, founded in 1831, employs 12,000 people, has an annual budget of $1.1 billion and offers more than 25 degrees.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Foundation Announces Winners of Awards in Mental Retardation
DOC.TEXT: Seven people cited for improving the lives of the mentally retarded were named winners Wednesday of the 1990 Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation Awards in Mental Retardation. The winners are former Sen. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., of Connecticut (Human Service Award); Edward Zigler, Ph.D., of Yale University (Scientific Leadership Award); the Kingsley family of Chappaqua, N.Y. (Special Achievement Award for Families); Paul Wehman, Ph.D., of Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, Va., and Marty Wyngaarden Krauss, Ph.D., of Brandeis University, Waltham (Future Leaders in Mental Retardation Award). The awards will be presented at a ceremony Sunday in Hyannis Port celebrating the 100th birthday of Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy. Three women will also receive the first Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy Leadership Award for work in the field. Their names will be announced Sunday. The award includes a $15,000 prize. Weicker, who has a child with Down's syndrome, wrote legislation mandating educational services to all handicapped pre-school children, wrote the initial Americans with Disabilities Act and led the passage of the Education for All Handicapped Children Act. He will be awarded $15,000. Zigler, who also wins $15,000, wrote groundbreaking books on child development and early childhood education. The Kingsley family includes Jason, 16, an actor on ``Sesame Street'' who has Down's syndrome; his mother, Emily, who wrote the acclaimed ``Kids Like These'' television program in 1987; and his father, Charles, who has served on many committees devoted to improving the lives of the handicapped. They will share $5,000. Krauss is the director of the Starr Center for Mental Retardation at Brandeis. Wehman developed the concept that with on-the-job support, mentally retarded people can be productive employees in private industry. Krauss and Wehman will share a $2,500 prize. The foundation, which has given the awards seven times since 1962, is named for Joseph and Rose Kennedy's eldest son, who died during World War II. Their daughter, Rosemary, is mentally retarded.

DOC.HEAD: Direct Investment
DOC.TEXT: Free flows of investment increase global prosperity by complementing the open international trading system. In particular, foreign direct investment can help restructure the economies of developing and Central and Eastern European countries, create new jobs, and raise living standards. All countries should therefore seek to reduce their barriers to investment and resist protectionist pressures to discourage or discriminate against such investment. ...
DOC.HEAD: Reform in Central and Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: We welcome the political and economic reforms taking place in Central and Eastern Europe. At the recent Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE) in Bonn and by the agreement to establish the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), the participating countries of the region accepted the key principles underpinning market economies. However, the degree of implementation of economic and political reform varies widely by country. Several countries have taken courageous and difficult measures to stabilize their economies and shorten the transition to a market economy. We and other countries should assist Central and Eastern European nations that are firmly committed to economic and political reform. Those providing help should favor countries that implement such reforms. Foreign private investment will be vital in the development of Central and Eastern Europe. Capital will flow to countries with open markets and hospitable investment climates. Improved access for their exports will also be important for those Central and Eastern European countries that are opening up their economies. Western governments can support this process by various means, including trade and investment agreements. The recent decision by the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls (COCOM) to liberalize export controls is a positive step.
DOC.HEAD: The Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: We discussed the situation in the Soviet Union, and exchanged views regarding the message that Soviet President Gorbachev sent us several days ago on his economic plans. We welcome the efforts underway in the Soviet Union to liberalize and to create a more open, democratic, and pluralistic Soviet society, and to move toward a market-oriented economy. These measures deserve our support. The success of perestroika depends upon the determined pursuit and development of these reform efforts. In particular, we welcome President Gorbachev's suggestion for a sustained economic dialogue. We have all begun, individually and collectively, to assist these reform efforts. We all believe that technical assistance should be provided now to help the Soviet Union move to a market-oriented economy and to mobilize its own resources. Some countries are already in a position to extend large scale financial credits. We also agreed that further Soviet decisions to introduce more radical steps toward a market-oriented economy, to shift resources substantially away from the military sector and to cut support to nations promoting regional conflict will all improve the prospect for meaningful and sustained economic assistance. We have taken note of the decision of the European Council in Dublin on June 26. We have agreed to ask the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD and the designated president of the EBRD to undertake, in close consultation with the Commission of the European Communities, a detailed study of the Soviet economy, to make recommendations for its reform and to establish the criteria under which Western economic assistance could effectively support these reforms. This work should be completed by year's end and be convened by the IMF. We took note of the importance to the Government of Japan of the peaceful resolution of its dispute with the Soviet Union over the Northern Territories.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Medicare Losing Millions in Double Payments for Care
DOC.TEXT: The Medicare program pays at least $400 million annually for medical services that should instead be covered by private insurance plans, a federal official told a Senate subcommittee Wednesday. Michael Mangano, a deputy inspector general at the Department of Health and Human Services, testified the money is being lost because the Medicare program does not ensure that companies that insure people who also receive Medicare pay the primary cost of their medical bills. He estimated the annual loss at between $400 million and $600 million based on 1988 data, but added, ``that is a very conservative estimate.'' Sen. William Roth, R-Del., ranking member of the Senate Government Affairs' investigations subcommittee, said other estimates put the loss as high as $1 billion a year and called the problem ``absolutely astounding.'' ``It gives lie to claims that the federal government needs to raise taxes to make its budgetary ends meet,'' said Roth. ``Until we get our house in order on the waste, fraud and abuse that cost the taxpayers so dearly, we have no right to ask these same taxpayers to shell out even more in taxes.'' Mangano said his office has recommended that the Health Care Financing Administration, which handles Medicare, improve efforts to determine when beneficiaries are also covered by private insurance. Although HCFA has taken some actions, agency officials ``have not eliminated the problems,'' he said. The $105 million Medicare program helps pay the medical expenses for about 34 million Americans who are 65 and older or are disabled. The subcommittee focused on one insurance company _ Provident Life and Accident Insurance Co. _ which Roth said ``allegedly followed a deliberate policy of evading payments on claims of patients they had insured by foisting these claims off on Medicare.'' The inspector general's office recommended government action against the company, but the Justice Department declined to prosecute ``due to manpower shortages'' and because other remedies were available, Mangano said. Larry Simmons of the inspector general's office said the inquiry and internal company memos show Provident's strategy appeared to be that ``they would not pay until someone told them to.'' Winston W. Walker, president of the Chattanooga, Tenn.-based insurance company, testified that the blame was Medicare's alone. ``Our company was prepared to pay as primary payer,'' but its efforts to determine how much and when to pay a claim were ``rebuffed'' by Medicare officials, he said. He said Medicare has no procedures to identify beneficiaries with other insurance coverage before it pays a claim. Medicare and an insurance plan often both paid benefits to health-care providers or beneficiaries, he said. Medicare then expected the recipient to volunteer to repay Medicare the amount overpaid, he said. ``Provident did not cause this breakdown, and Provident cannot fix it,'' Walker said. ``Only the government can fix it, and then only by implementing rational administrative procedures.''

DOC.HEAD: Deaf Contestant `Sings' Way to State Beauty Pageant
DOC.TEXT: The sound of music is a silent one for Audrey Stevenson, but that won't stop her from singing her kind of music at the Miss New York State Pageant this week. The 20-year-old Stevenson is the first deaf contestant ever in the Miss New York State Pageant. She is one of 17 women vying to become the successor to the reigning Miss New York, Lisa Molella, Saturday night in Watertown. Stevenson, a civilian postal clerk at the U.S. Army's Fort Drum, enters the state pageant as Miss Thousand Island, a title she won in part by singing in sign language. ``It's hard not to be moved by her talent,'' said Sharon Cantwell, director of the Miss Thousand Island pageant. Stevenson turned down an opportunity to compete in the preliminaries for the Miss Deaf America pageant for a chance at the Miss New York crown. ``It's very important for me to be in this pageant. I want hearing people to understand better the world of a deaf person. I want to show other deaf people that they can realize their goals, too,'' said Stevenson, who is accompanied by an interpreter although she speaks clearly on her own. Clear enough, in fact, that she delivered a graduation speech to local eighth-graders last month. ``Her deafness has never been a handicap. She's always done precisely what she wanted,'' said her mother, Margaret Scougal. Stevenson has been deaf since she had meningitis when she was 18 months old. The 5-foot-7, 112-pound contestant has blue-green eyes and sandy brown hair. One of her dreams has always been to compete in a pageant. ``This year I just decided `I'm going to do it. It's now or never,'' said Stevenson. Stevenson ``blew away the judges with a strong, opinionated interview,'' recalled Cantwell. Then she stole the talent segment by signing the words to ``I Hear Your Hands,'' a song she had first performed at her high school graduation. As the runners-up were being announced and Stevenson's name wasn't being mentioned, Scougal said she was preparing what she would say to comfort her daughter. Words that never needed saying. ``I was so amazed that I won because it was the first time,'' said Stevenson, who clapped and looked around the stage for several seconds until she realized the master of ceremonies had announced her name as the winner. Stevenson is planning to repeat her signing song at the state pageant, with some minor alterations and enhanced choreography. The national pageant had its first deaf contestant last year, Jennifer Wall, Miss Washington, said Bill Caligari, stage producer for the Atlantic City extravaganza. She was one of the 10 finalists.

DOC.HEAD: Spouses Visit Medical Center, Barbara Bush Talks to Cancer Patients
DOC.TEXT: First Lady Barbara Bush, who lost a daughter to leukemia, visited young cancer patients Wednesday while other summit spouses toured different parts of a sprawling medical complex. On the final day of the three-day economic summit, the spouses went to the Texas Medical Center, which is made up of hospitals and medical schools. At the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Mrs. Bush first talked to adults receiving anti-cancer drugs in the center's ambulatory treatment center, the world's largest facility for outpatient chemotherapy. She then visited two children in their rooms before going to see a group of youths attending summer school as they receive outpatient treatment at the hospital. ``Wow, what a day, what a weird day,'' said 5-year-old Eric Edelmann. Many of the children wore caps on their heads to hide the hair loss they've suffered from chemotherapy treatment and several were attached to intravenous tubes. The Bushes' daughter, Robin, died at age 3 of leukemia in 1951. Mrs. Bush specifically asked to see Denis Lokter, a 15-year-old cancer patient from the Soviet Union who came to the hospital for treatment several months ago. ``We had a wonderful visit from your president,'' she said, referring to Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's recent trip to the United States. Lokter, who speaks limited English, said later he did not know much about politics. Mrs. Bush wished happy birthday to Patrick Chapman, who turned 7 Tuesday, and asked him to open his mouth for a quick inspection. Patrick is missing a front tooth. ``You have one enormous tooth. Where's the other one?'' she asked. ``Certainly, it's going to have a friend, isn't it. They're going to call you Fang.'' Mrs. Bush told reporters she felt the spouses attending the summit were impressed with the city. France's Danielle Mitterrand, Canada's Mila Mulroney, Italy's Livia Andreotti, and Japan's Sachiyo Kaifu also went to the medical center Wednesday. England's Denis Thatcher, the only male spouse, did not go to the center. Hannelore Kohl, wife of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, and Marie Delors, wife of European Commission President Jacques Delors did not accompany their husbands to Texas. Mrs. Mitterrand toured the Texas Heart Institute, watched a presentation on pediatric AIDS at Texas Children's Hospital and went to the Houston Shriners Hospital for Crippled Children. Mrs. Mulroney also toured the Texas Heart Institute and the Texas Children's Hospital, where she talked to doctors about current research and treatment for cystic fibrosis. She also met with some teen-agers with cystic fibrosis. Mrs. Andreotti visited a cholesterol research laboratory at The Methodist Hospital and sampled some low-cholesterol Italian food at the hospital's heart-healthy gourmet restaurant. She also met doctors from the Texas Heart Institute and St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital. Mrs. Kaifu met with famed heart surgeon Dr. Michael DeBakey and saw some of his pioneering inventions for heart surgery. She also met heart transplant recipients.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas State Attorney General Charged With Theft by Deception
DOC.TEXT: The state attorney general was charged Wednesday with theft for allegedly entertaining political allies and friends at taxpayers' expense. Steve Clark, 43, who in February withdrew from the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination because of the allegations, pleaded innocent to the charge. After a brief court appearance, he said, ``My only statement is, I am innocent of the charge against me and I do not to intend to resign.'' The charge followed a ruling by Little Rock Municipal Judge Marion Humphrey that there was probable cause to charge Clark with one count of theft by deception. His ruling was based on a 55-page affidavit submitted by Pulaski County Prosecutor Chris Piazza. Bond was set at $2,500. The felony charge carries a maximum penalty of five to 20 years in jail and a $15,000 fine upon conviction. The case was sent to circuit court for trial. The affidavit accused Clark of covering up his use of a state-issued Visa card for personal meals by submitting names of people who did not dine with him. He also claimed to discuss state business at the meals when private matters were discussed, the affidavit said. The affidavit listed 86 allegedly improper transactions totaling $8,448.27. Fifty-six were allegedly for private meals charged to the state. Among them were a $713 party in Memphis, Tenn., which included $613 worth of alcoholic beverages charged to the state. Included were four $125 bottles of Dom Perignon champagne. Three of the four people listed by Clark as guests _ including Arkansas State University President Eugene Smith _ said they didn't attend. The purchase of alcohol at taxpayers' expense in prohibited by state law. The affidavit also said Clark charged the state for a meal with his mother, reporting to the state's finance department that he met with officials to discuss improvements to a state highway. Clark said in January the errors were made when he tried to itemize his expenses 60 or 90 days after the fact. He blamed the discrepancies on sloppy bookkeeping. The attorney general is not required by state law to itemize his expense claims; Clark said he wanted to be more accountable. Clark has been attorney general since 1979.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President Bush's news conference Wednesday at the seven-nation Economic Summit: President Bush: Well, thank you all very much. And I have a brief opening statement, and then I'll be glad to respond to your questions. My colleagues from France and the United Kingdom, Germany, Canada, Italy, Japan, and the European Communities and I have just completed this 16th meeting of the leaders of the largest industrialized democracies. And this, the first economic summit of the postwar period, celebrates the resurgence of democracy and free markets around the world. Over the past three days, we've had full discussions on the key issues of our time: advancing political and economic freedom; promoting sustained economic growth, both in developed and developing countries; assisting the transition to market economies in Central and Eastern Europe, and indeed in the Soviet Union; and protecting the environment. We are united in a common goal: to extend to those who seek political and economic freedom a helping hand with our resources, talents, and experience. As our declaration states, ``when people are free to choose, they choose freedom.'' We identified the successful completion of the Uruguay Round of global trade talks as one of the highest economic priorities, and we recognized that agreement on fundamental reform of agriculture is critical to achieving this goal. We commended the report by the chairman of the GATT _ the GATT Agricultural Group, the De Zeeuw report to our negotiators as a vehicle to move these talks forward. And we also committed to maintain our personal involvement and to exercise political leadership at every step along the way as we move toward the final ministerial meeting in December. On the Soviet Union, we discussed our common efforts to assist the Soviet reform effort, the success of which is in our common interest. In addition to offering the Soviets technical assistance, we've asked the IMF to coordinate a major study of the Soviet economy and make recommendation for its reform. In keeping with the agreements reached here, I will be conveying to President Gorbachev the results of our deliberations. We achieved major progress on the environment, particularly on climate change and forests. We committed to finish the negotiations on a framework climate change convention by 1992. In a first, we agreed that implementing protocols should consider all sources and sinks of greenhouse gases consistent with the comprehensive approach that we recommend. We agreed to launch a special effort to address the deforestation in the rain forests, a concern that was very forcefully raised by Chancellor Kohl. And I found a very receptive audience for my proposal that a free-standing global forest convention be negotiated without delay, and we agreed to move ahead on this rapidly. In short, this was a summit that addressed itself to a rapidly changing world. We agreed to welcome, respond to and manage the changes on behalf of free markets, free political systems and a better life for people everywhere. It is no small achievement that we came to a positive and unanimous conclusion on so many important and difficult issues. And I would stress those two words: positive and unanimous. And I want to congratulate my colleagues on the results of the collective effort. I think they left feeling good. We had a very generous letter to our Secretary of State just now received from Prime Minister Mulroney, and he's a veteran of these summits. And I must say to the Canadians here, I, once again, benefited from his _ not only his commitment _ learned from his commitment on certain issues like the environment _ but benefited from his advice. I also want to thank the two secretaries who were at my side, Secretary Baker and Secretary Brady, Ambassador Carla Hills, Secretary Yeutter, Secretary Mosbacher, who worked with their colleagues and others at this summit. I want to thank the sherpas _ most of them stayed up _ I understand they all stayed up to 4 this morning in ironing out this final communique. So, it was a team effort, and I think most of our _ well, I think all of our summit participants left feeling good about this particular summit. And now, I think Terry Hunt has the first question.
DOC.NOTE: MORE:

DOC.HEAD: Last Hand-Cranked Phone System Going Modern
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: What is believed to be the last hand-cranked, magneto-operated telephone party line in the United States is hanging it up after six decades, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. The 20-party, single line system runs for 40 miles, strung on trees, fence posts and treacherous cliffs high above the Salmon River in an isolated section of east-central Idaho in the Salmon River National Forest. The line, operated by the non-profit North Fork Telephone Corp., was installed by the U.S. Forest Service in 1931 and sold to users for $1 in 1952. In its place will be a $250,000, state-of-art digital system operated by the Rural Telephone Co. of Glenns Ferry, Idaho, said the department's Rural Electrification Administration, which provided financing for the new system. One of the old system's last customers, Garry Pedrow, said he hated to see the change, because of the system's historical value, but ``as far as being in business, it's hard to communicate on this line.'' His wife, Peggy, agreed. ``Once it's gone, it's gone forever. But ... I guess I'm ready because I can't hear anything'' on the 40-mile party line. The size of the system will almost triple immediately to a total of 37 subscribers, the REA said. A buried cable is the heart of the new system, most of it along a narrow, dead-end roadbed, the only way _ other than the river _ in and out of the 40-mile canyon. The first call, scheduled for early Friday, is to be made from Shoup's Country Store and post office, run by the Pedrows in the canyon's only town, population 2. Joe Miller, president of the Idaho Public Utilities Commission, was scheduled to make the ceremonial call to Gary C. Byrne, REA administrator, who will be attending a rural development conference in Denver. The REA began making rural electric loans in 1935 and was authorized by Congress in 1949 to develop a similar program for telephones. Since then, the agency has approved $8.9 billion in direct and guaranteed loans for more than 1,000 telephone systems. REA spokesman Jim McKenna said nearly all rural hand-cranked magneto telephones were converted to modern versions by 1970. At the peak, he said, perhaps 1.25 million had served the nation's farms, by conservative estimates. When they were installed decades ago, most hand-cranked phones were wall-mounted units with a black metal mouthpiece on an arm and a receiver hung on a two-prong hook on the left side. A crank on the right side rang bells along the line, and _ if one persisted in cranking _ in a ``central'' office where an operator took care of calls to town numbers or long-distance. Each farm had a coded ring _ two longs and a short, for example. The customer being called was supposed to answer that ring and ignore the rest. But party line chatter, with two or three parties talking and several more secretly listening, was a popular rural recreation, long before electricity, television and even radio. A ``line call'' of continuous ringing was often used to alert families of emergencies such as approaching storms, tornadoes, or fires in forest areas and on the prairie.

DOC.HEAD: HOUSTON: First question.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, I'd like to ask you about Soviet aid. Is this six-month study of Soviet needs a way of delaying a political decision on aid? Or at the end of that, will the United States make a commitment to send some cash to Moscow? A: Well, it's not an effort to delay anything. It is, as we said in the report, a step towards assisting the reforms. And I'll make clear to President Gorbachev that he ought to view this outcome of this summit very positively. You may remember that in London only a few days ago, I gave my views on the U.S. lending money at this time. So, it's not an effort to forestall anything, it's an effort to move forward and encourage forward motion and be helpful to the Soviet Union in terms of reform. They need much, much more reform, and they're the ones that say this. And in Gorbachev's letter, he asked for assistance in many areas _ personnel management and how they change their systems _ and we've already started bilaterally, as have other countries, in trying to assist. So, it's really a coordinated effort to help the Soviet Union. Q: Well, in six months then can Mr. Gorbachev expect that the United States will be sending some financial assistance to meet these needs? A: Not particularly. Not necessarily. But, what he can expect is that we will have been helpful to him in the reforms that he knows that he has to undertake. And maybe, you know, this _ this could lead to support. But there are things that have to happen. And I've been very up front with him personally and then in public statements as to what has to _ what has to happen for the United States to send money. And, incidentally, I don't _ I'm trying to think on the Gorbachev letter. I don't think there was a request for sending money. And then, I also told our Soviet partners that we had some problems, legal problems _ the settlement of this Kerensky debt, for example _ before we would be free to give more, like direct financial support. So, I wouldn't set a time frame on when and if the United States decides to go forward. But I must say that I hope he will _ I hope the Soviets will view this as positive. And, indeed, I have contacted Mr. Gorbachev already by cable telling him I want to talk to him about the summit, and telling him that _ why I felt that it's positive, and also congratulating him on his landslide win. Certain readings I was doing before then, I wasn't sure that it was going to work out quite that way. But he's in the political arena, and he did pretty darn well, and I congratulated him. Helen? Q: Mr. President, for 40 years, we've spent untold billions to fight the Soviet Union. Is it conceivable, as you and Secretary Baker have portrayed, that the U.S. _ American taxpayer would not be willing to spend a dime to help them now? A: We are trying to help them now. And I think we're going to send the kind of help that in the long run will be most beneficial to them. And they need reform, and they know it, and we're going to try in every way to facilitate that reform because we are in a very different age. But we have some problems. I'm not particularly enthusiastic about the intercontinental ballistic missiles aimed at US cities. I find it a little contradictory to think that they will continue to spend $5 billion a year for Cuba, a totalitarian system whose leader is swimming against this tide of democracy and freedom that is lifting up most hopes in the Soviet Union. So, there's _ certain things have to happen before I, as president, will make recommendations for direct financial aid. So, what we're trying to do is carry our part of the load in helping the reforms.
