Perkin-Elmer ordered the guidance part from Composite Optics in July 1981. ``However, during assembly at the Perkin-Elmer facilities, it was discovered that the prime contractor had furnished Composite Optics engineering drawings in reverse of what was needed,'' the auditors found. The audit said Composite Optics acknowledged it salvaged a significant portion of the backward guidance part. But, the auditors said, ``Perkin-Elmer did not make any reductions to the subcontractor's proposed costs'' in December 1981 when it gave out a new contract to rebuild the part. David Chamberlain, director of administration at Composite Optics, said he doubted many parts were salvageable.

DOC.HEAD: Nominee to Head DEA Sails Through Senate Hearing
DOC.TEXT: Federal judge Robert C. Bonner sailed through a Senate hearing Wednesday on his nomination to head the Drug Enforcement Administration, with Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. telling him, ``You are going to be confirmed.'' Bonner was approved by the same committee before he became a U.S. District Court judge in Los Angeles last year. For the previous five years, he was U.S. attorney in Los Angeles. President Bush nominated Bonner, 48, to succeed John C. Lawn, who retired in March after five years at DEA's helm. Bonner suggested that the United States may have to start hitting drug users harder. He said California never prosecutes anyone for personal use of drugs on a first offense while in Japan, those who are arrested for drug use are detained for 21 days for treatment. ``It seems to me that's something that we have to start considering doing,'' Bonner told the Senate Judiciary Committee chaired by Biden, D-Del. He also told the committee that he supports some controls over domestically produced assault-style weapons. The committee's confirmation vote was expected in the next few weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Protege Defeats Ligachev for Party's No. 2 Job
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf `Ivashko defeated' to ADD that Ivashko has been Politburo member since December. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `In its...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB4,6,7
DOC.TEXT: A Ukrainian protege of Mikhail S. Gorbachev was elected Wednesday to be his right-hand man in the Communist Party, the Tass news agency reported, in a stinging rebuff to the party's leading traditionalist. Vladimir Ivashko, the man Gorbachev picked to run the Ukrainian republic last fall, was elected to the post of deputy general secretary of the Communist Party by delegates to the 28th party congress, Tass reported, citing ``trustworthy sources.'' Ivashko defeated Politburo conservative Yegor K. Ligachev, who has been Gorbachev's most vocal hard-line critic. Ivashko has been a member of the party's ruling Politburo since December. In its brief report, Tass did not give any vote totals from the secret ballot held Wednesday night. The results were to be officially announced on Thursday at the congress. Ivashko, a 58-year-old economist and engineer, will run the party's day-to-day affairs. Gorbachev, who was re-elected as party leader on Tuesday, had sought a protege to handle those tasks while he concentrates on his presidential duties. Ivashko's election gave Gorbachev a further triumph at the congress. It showed his personal strength at a congress that has been dominated the past nine days by conservatives who have criticized his reforms. It was also a personal repudiation of Ligachev. On Tuesday, Moscow party boss Yuri Prokofiev told reporters that he thought Ligachev's political career was over. Meanwhile, about 500 anti-Communist demonstrators rallied on the edge of Red Square, and shook their fists in the face of departing delegates. One man spat at a delegate, and police had to hold back many of the protesters, who whistled derisively or shouted ``Shame!'' and ``Resign!'' ``Communism, go away!'' said Maya Ivanova, who described herself as a supporter of Boris N. Yeltsin, the reform president of the Russian republic. The crowd, which waved czarist flags and anti-Communist placards such as ``Communism is Worse than AIDS,'' listened to speakers through a megaphone that didn't always work. Scores of uniformed police kept protesters off the cobblestones of Red Square, and undercover agents milled at the rally's edges, speaking into plastic bags that concealed their walkie-talkies. The vote between Ivashko and Ligachev gave delegates a clear choice between giving Gorbachev a loyal deputy or saddling him with a rival in charge of day-to-day party affairs. A third candidate, Leningrad professor Anatoly Dudaryev, also was on the ballot. Ligachev, who eight days earlier had been applauded by the largely conservative congress for his harsh criticism of Gorbachev's policies, almost didn't make it onto the ballot for the No. 2 job. Hours after nominations had closed, Gorbachev told the congress that the rules required a final vote certifying the ballot. Several delegates promptly rose to complain that Ligachev did not truly support Gorbachev's reform program. The congress then voted 2,293 to 1,916 to drop Ligachev from the ballot. But other delegates immediately objected. One argued that the congress was the party's ruling body and could change its own rules. So the group voted 2,349 to 1,816 to ignore the ballot certification requirement and restore Ligachev's candidacy. Afterward, delegate Dr. Svyatislav Fyodorov said he believed Gorbachev engineered the incident. Ligachev told reporters: ``It was just a procedural question. Don't look for politics in it.'' Ligachev also fought off a bid from the floor to prevent him from running because of his age. Ligachev is 69, and two efforts to require the deputy leader to be younger than 60, and then 65, both failed. Ligachev, who stumbled badly when speaking to delegates and frequently forgot questions, told delegates he had worked well with Gorbachev. He spoke against allowing private property in the Soviet Union. Gorbachev chose Ivashko to run the Ukraine, the Soviet Union's second-largest republic, when party traditionalist Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky retired last fall. ``It is important that these two people be close,'' Gorbachev said of the two top party leaders. ``As much as I have before, no matter what my job, I will be working for perestroika,'' pledged Ivashko. ``We have to do everything to renew the party and change its priorities.'' ``We have to understand that without us, without the party, nothing will be left of perestroika,'' he said in a forceful presentation to the delegates. Ivashko resigned the party leadership of the Ukraine this spring after he was elected president of the republic. He offered his resignation as the Ukraine's president Wednesday, the Tass news agency said. The Ukrainian parliament had urged all of its members to return to the Ukraine for a key decision on the republic's sovereignty. Many, including Ivashko, were at the party congress. Tass quoted Ivashko as saying that he was offering to resign because he felt a lack of support from parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Drought Takes a Toll on Crops, But Relief May Be In Sight
DOC.TEXT: Six weeks of hot, dry weather have seared corn, soybean, cotton and tobacco crops in the Southeast, but farm experts looked hopefully for weekend rains that could avert an agricultural disaster. Karl Harker, an agricultural meteorologist with the National Weather Service at Auburn University in Alabama, said a low pressure system will move into the region as early as Thursday, increasing the likelihood of showers and thunderstorms. ``My farm is on irrigation, but our water supply is gone,'' said Albert Johnson, who owns a 53-acre farm in South Carolina. ``The extreme heat is making tobacco do things that I've never seen before. ... The tobacco is literally baking.'' Georgia Agriculture Commissioner Tommy Irvin said without significant rain in the next two weeks, farmers could face their worst disaster since the 1986 drought. ``We're at a crossroads,'' he said. ``If it doesn't improve, we stand to be worse than then.'' Irvin said farmers need a break in the heat and two or three days of light showers to soak the ground. Harker said 30-day rainfall totals in Georgia are running 2 to 6 inches below normal. The weather service said North Carolina averaged 1.25 inches in June, instead of the usual four inches. South Carolina has shortfalls of two to five inches, according to the Southeast Regional Climate Center in Columbia, S.C. The center's director, John Purvis, said Tennessee also has been dry. Nashville's shortfall is 9.14 inches since Jan. 1. Irvin said the drought has severely damaged Georgia's corn crop, has killed soybean plants and is expected to substantially reduce cotton yields. It has also lowered milk production, forced farmers to feed their cattle hay normally reserved for winter, has lowered egg production and has reduced the weight of chickens. South Carolina officials said corn, tobacco and soybeans have been hardest hit. Joe Burns, a crop specialist with the University of Tennessee Agricultural Extension Service, estimated that farmers in eastern Tennessee are losing about 400,000 bushels of corn a day _ or about $1 million a day _ because of the drought. Tobacco, the main cash crop in eastern Tennessee, have virtually stopped growing, said Charles Farmer, an Extension Service economist. ``It's an iffy situation,'' Farmer said. ``I think we can still make some good crops if we get some moisture pretty soon. But obviously we have lost some ground.'' North Carolina's tobacco crop is protected by irrigation on most farms, but corn has withered in some fields, officials said. Most of the state's 1.25 million acres of corn is in the hard-hit eastern part of the state. Columbus County extension director Garland McMullen said farmers in his county will lose about half their corn. ``We have some areas ... the farmers will not be able to harvest at all,'' he said. ``There's no ears on the stalk.'' Carl Cross, a statistician with the North Carolina Agriculture Department in Raleigh, said only an eighth of the state's corn crop was rated good this week, compared to one-third last week.

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian Miners Glad to See Ivashko Go
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When Ukrainian coal miners learned at a rally Wednesday their republic's president might be moving to a top Communist Party post in Moscow, they cheered and applauded. It was not happiness for a local boy making good. It was more pleasure at the prospect of getting rid of Vladimir Ivashko. ``He's a windbag. He doesn't do anything,'' said Anatoly Berezhnikov, one of about 3,000 angry miners demonstrating in the heart of the Ukraine's coal fields during a one-day strike to press demands that the Communist Party get out of their lives and the Soviet government resign. Ivashko defeated fellow Politburo member Yegor Ligachev for the No. 2 Communist Party job in a vote Wednesday night at the 28th party congress in Moscow, the official Tass news agency reported. Ivashko, a protege of Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, will run the party's day-to-day affairs in his new post as deputy secretary general. This will allow Gorbachev to concentrate on his duties as Soviet president. dispute with the republic's parliament. Ivashko also offered his resignation as Ukrainian president Wednesday in a dispute with the republic's parliament. Miners here in the Soviet Union's biggest coal-producing region admit they don't know Ivashko well because he has been in the Ukrainian leadership only since last fall. But still they cast him as a part of the Communist Party and government apparatus that has failed to improve their living and working conditions. ``Have you been around to the stores?'' the 34-year-old Berezhnikov, who has spent 13 years in the mines, asked a reporter interested in his view of Ivashko. Without awaiting an answer, he offered: ``They're empty.'' The cigarettte-smoking miner said Ivashkov must share the blame along with the rest of the republic's leaders. The officials, he said, ``are fighting for power and doing nothing for us.'' But there was a dissenter in the crowd. The wife of a miner said she respects Ivashko and thinks it will be a loss for the Ukraine if he moves to Moscow. ``You can sense his knowledge. He's not stupid and has common sense. He knows how to assess things and propose what is needed,'' said the woman, who would identify herself only as Ludmilla. Ivashko, a 58-year-old economist and engineer, is much more closely identified with Gorbachev than the former Ukrainian leader, Vladimir Shcherbitsky, a party traditionalist. Speaking to the party congress on Wednesday, Ivashko pledged total support for Gorbachev's policies. Organizers of the one-day national miners strike said they weren't happy with any of the proposed candidates for the No. 2 party job. ``Ligachev and Ivashko are from the same regime. There's no way we can support him,'' Yuri Makarov, a Donetsk strike organizer, told a news conference. Another organizer, Yuri Boldyrev, said the miners had all but given up on the party. ``We don't have hope for a party headed by either Ligachev or Ivashko,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: City Hall Welcomes Democratic Convention
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins told the Democratic Party on Wednesday it won't be disappointed it chose his city for its 1992 national convention. ``We won't let you down,'' Dinkins told Democratic National Chairman Ronald Brown, an old friend. ``New York is a great convention town.'' Brown came to New York after announcing in Washington that his hometown was chosen as the convention site. The gathering should bring 35,000 delegates, guests and journalists to town and pump an estimated $100 million into the city's economy. ``Democrats will nominate the next president of the United States two years from now this week in America's most dynamic city and in one of the world's greatest cities _ New York, the Big Apple,'' Brown said. The race to be that nominee is wide open, but one possibility _ Gov. Mario Cuomo _ was on hand for the hoopla at City Hall. Cuomo added his signature to a contract signed by Dinkins and Brown, then parried reporters' questions about national office. ``I have no plans to run for president,'' Cuomo said. ``I have no plans to make plans,'' he continued, adding with a laugh, ``You guys don't believe me. It's too bad.'' Political experts say New York's selection as host would help a Cuomo candidacy only in the unlikely event the convention is contested. ``I don't think it matters where the convention is because that's the end of the process,'' said former Iowa Democratic Party Chairwoman Bonnie Campbell. ``Certainly it makes it easier for the governor if he's our nominee. He won't have to travel as far.'' At a flag-bedecked City Hall, Dinkins and Brown sat at a desk that belonged to George Washington and a band played ``Happy Days Are Here Again.'' The two men engaged in some Republican-bashing, stressing the savings and loan bailout. Dinkins said $500 billion was being spent to bail out the ailing thrifts, adding: ``We must not ask honest borrowers and businesses to bail out the savings and loan stockholders, the big depositors and, in many cases, the same crooks and thieves who caused this mess in the first place.'' He said he hoped the '92 convention would be ``a time to renew America's progressive values and principles.'' Brown said the S&L crisis lay in the laps of President Bush and former President Reagan. ``It happened on their watch,'' he said. ``It's the fox and the chicken coop with no prosecution of the thieves.'' Brown said he was considering several format changes for the convention, including cutting it to three days from four and holding it on a weekend instead of midweek. The site selection committee had narrowed its search to New York and New Orleans. Brown said New Orleans' chances were hurt by the Louisiana Legislature's passage of strong anti-abortion legislation, but said that was not the deciding factor. New York's early pledge to come up with more than $20 million to get Madison Square Garden ready for the convention, and a promise by prominent Democratic fund-raisers here to fill the party's coffers, helped persuade Brown the Big Apple was the place to go. New York played host to the convention in 1976, when Jimmy Carter was nominated and won the presidency, and in 1980, when Carter was renominated and lost.

DOC.HEAD: After Democrats Choose Big Apple, Big Easy Turns to GOP
With AM-Democratic Convention
DOC.TEXT: Spurned by the Democrats, who chose New York City to host their 1992 national convention, New Orleans officials Wednesday said they would try to get the Republicans. Mayor Sidney Barthelemy's chief of staff, Terry Alarcon, said Republican officials on Tuesday asked New Orleans to start working on a proposal to play host to the 1992 GOP convention. ``They said we set the standard'' in 1988, when the Republican convention was held at the Louisiana Superdome, Alarcon said. Economists estimated the 1988 convention pumped up to $130 million into the New Orleans economy. For weeks, New Orleans had been battling New York for the 1992 Democratic do. Alarcon and Steve Hand, who led the New Orleans campaign, said New York edged out their city because the Democrats want the Big Apple's access to big-money individuals and corporations. Both have been in relatively short supply in New Orleans since the oil industry declined in the early 1980s. ``We feel like New York won based on one very simple reason,'' said Alarcon. ``It is the financial capital of this nation.'' In Washington Wednesday, Democratic Chairman Ron Brown said ``a factor but not the deciding factor'' was the Lousiana Legislature's recent passage of the toughest sta divisions some unions would accept women as pastors, but indications are that the majority of unions do not find this acceptable.'' The delegates' vote against ordaining women is binding on all congregations within the church. A vote to close off the debate Wednesday morning prevented 45 delegates from taking their turns at the microphone. During Tuesday's two-hour debate, many of those supporting the ordination of women referred to Ellen G. White, an early church leader thought by some Seventh-day Adventists to be a prophet. ``We need to liberate the Holy Spirit to do his work with whomever he chooses to do his work with,'' said Stella Greig, representing Andrews University in Berrien Springs, Mich. ``If God can ordain women, as Ellen White told us he did her, I cannot see why the Seventh-day Adventist Church cannot also ordain women.'' Delegates opposing the ordination of women relied on the Bible, which provides the guiding principles for the 127-year-old church. Gabriel Boakye-Dankwa of the church's African division urged other delegates to resist social pressures. ``The Bible is silent on the ordination of women; the writings of Ellen G. White are silent on the ordination of women and we should also be silent,'' Boakye-Dankwa said. ``If it is in the Bible we want it. If it is not in the Bible, this church must reject it.''

DOC.HEAD: Syrian Official Says Israeli Raids in Lebanon Hurt Hostage Talks
DOC.TEXT: The Syrian foreign minister said Wednesday that Israeli air raids into Lebanon had complicated negotiations for the release of one of the 16 Western hostages held by Lebanese Moslem groups. In Lebanon, a senior Hezbollah official called for the release of all Western hostages and Lebanese detainees held by Israel, reiterating the pro-Iranian group's standard posture that it is not involved in kidnappings. Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa was the first official to confirm a weekend report by Iran's official news agency that a hostage, most likely a European, might be freed soon. Syria is the main powerbroker in Lebanon. Most of the six American and 10 European hostages are believed held by pro-Iranian zealots operating under the umbrella of Hezbollah, or Party of God. Sharaa said the Israeli raids Sunday and Monday against Hezbollah bases in southern Lebanon had ``undermined our efforts'' to secure the release of a hostage. At least 15 people died in the raids. There was no immediate reaction by the Israeli government to Syria's remarks. The Syrians were instrumental in the release of U.S. hostages Robert Polhill on April 22 and Frank Reed on April 30. Both were freed in Lebanon and immediately taken to neighboring Syria before going on to the United States. Syria maintains 40,000 troops in Lebanon under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate from 1976, a year after Lebanon's Christian-Moslem civil war began. The Syrians control west Beirut and Moslem regions. ``The Israeli air raids into Lebanon have complicated the issue, and undermined our efforts,'' said Sharaa. The remaining Western hostages in Lebanon are six Americans and 10 Europeans _ four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. ``We ask all those holding the hostages and those holding our detainees as well to release them,'' said Mohammed Yazbed, a member of Hezbollah's higher command. ``We are against such operations (kidnappings), and support the freedom of individuals,'' he said in Baalbek, Lebanon, at the funeral of two Hezbollah members killed in Israel's last air raid Monday. Hezbollah officials often have made such statements in their effort to distance themselves from the kidnappings. But Western intelligence sources insist Hezbollah is an umbrella for underground factions holding most of the hostages. Syria, Iran and allied Palestinian and Lebanese factions contend that Western support of Israel encourages the Jewish state's attacks against Arabs. Sharaa said in Damascus that he had no tangible developments to report, but it is ``not unlikely'' that situation would change soon. He indirectly confirmed speculation in Beirut, London and Dublin that the hostage to be released is Irish educator Brian Keenan. ``Syria is in constant contact with Iranian government officials and we are also in contact with the Irish government,'' Sharaa said. `We are exerting efforts and we hope that these efforts will be successful.'' Asked when a release might take place, Sharaa said, ``I can't tell you anything now.'' He did not elaborate on the snags that followed the air raids, but said, ``I hope we will overcome these difficulties.'' Keenan, 39, was kidnapped in Moslem west Beirut on April 11, 1986, as he walked from his home to the American University of Beirut, where he taught English. A native of Belfast, Keenan also holds a British passport. In Beirut, Shiite sources said this week Iran was pushing hard for the release of a hostage to express appreciation for relief supplies it received from the West after the devastating earthquake June 21. Ireland sent one of the first relief shipments to Tehran after the disaster in which 40,000 people were killed, 60,000 injured and about half a million were left homeless. ``We continue to be very hopeful'' about the possible release of Keenan, said Irish Ambassador Declan Connolly. He spoke to reporters after a meeting at the Foreign Ministry with one of Sharaa's senior aides, Nasser Qaddour. Connolly flew in from Saudi Arabia on Tuesday. On arrival, he said he had come to Damascus to keep in closer touch with Syrian officials to assess developments in a possible hostage release. ``We are hopeful on behalf of the Irish hostage Brian Keenan,'' he said, noting that he had ``good reason'' to expect a release. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani has been trying to end the ordeal of the hostages in return for improved relations with the West. But he faces growing opposition by Iranian radicals who believe restoring ties with the West contradicts the teachings of the late founder of the Islamic Republic, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Rebel Delegation Arrives for Peace Talks
With AM-Liberia
DOC.TEXT: A rebel delegation headed by Thomas Woewyu arrived here late Wednesday to open peace talks with the beleaguered Liberian government of President Samuel Doe. The four rebel negotiators came here by sea from the rebel-held port of Buchanan, about 60 miles southeast of Monrovia. They arrived at the Sierra Leone government wharf after nightfall in a heavy tropical rainstorm and were driven immediately to their hotel in the resort suburb of Aberdeen. Woewyu, who resides in East Orange, N.J., told reporters he was too tired to make any immediate statement but he might meet press repesentatives Thursday. He said he had no plans for any immediate meeting with the government delegation headed by Senate president Tambakai Jangaba. Jangaba has been waiting for the rebel delegation to return to Freetown since June 14 when a previous round of peace talks was broken off. The two delegations conferred here under the protection of the Sierra Leone government. Rebels have been advancing on the capital of Monrovia since December in the hopes of disposing Doe.

DOC.HEAD: Watkins Changing the Way DOE Does Business At Nuclear Waste Sites
DOC.TEXT: Energy Secretary James Watkins said Wednesday his department will take more direct control of the contaminated Hanford Nuclear Reservation as part of a plan to clean up problems at the nation's nuclear weapons program. ``We are changing the way of doing business at one of our major facilities. This is the first of a number of shoes to drop,'' Watkins said at a news conference. In addition to taking a greater government role in managing the Hanford site at Washington state, Watkins said the Energy Department will enter a new agreement with the Army Corps of Engineers on Thursday to help clean up radioactive wastes at the nation's nuclear weapons plants. Watkins said he was ``extremely disappointed'' with the condition of the nuclear weapons plants when he initiated a 30-year cleanup plan about 18 months ago. ``It was a shock to me. I had no idea we had not learned the lessons of Three Mile Island,'' he said. ``Now is the time to pay the piper and clean up 40 years of waste. The department announced last week it was increasing its estimate of the cleanup costs nationally to nearly $30 billion over the next five years. Watkins said Wednesday the boost was due partly to budget officials who fear they will be subject to lawsuits if they don't ask for enough cleanup money and partly to the discovery of additional contamination. Watkins said the work one official currently performs at Hanford will be handled by three deputies under his new management plan, including one who will be directly responsible for waste cleanup. Also under the new plan, the new site manager John Wagoner will report directly to the director of the department's office of environmental restoration and waste management. Wagoner, deputy manager of the Savannah River facility the past two years, replaces Hanford site manager Mike Lawrence, who resigned last week to take another job. ``Now we will have direct reporting from one of our major sites,'' Watkins said. The Hanford site along the Columbia River near Richland, Wash., contains 600,000 cubic yards of radioactive waste, Watkins said. Disclosures in recent years show that dangerous contaminants were released directly into the air, water and soil. Watkins said the Energy Department, which oversees the nation's nuclear weapons plants, is trying to upgrade plant operations by adding workers and administrators directly charged with improving of safety. ``We need people in the plant walking, looking, being sensitive to the health issues on a seven-day a week, 24-hour a day basis,'' he said. ``None of that's been done in the past. That is one of the reasons we've been targeted and targeted so successfully by groups who have legitimate complaints against us.'' Watkins said details of the memo of understanding with the Army Corps of Engineers will be made available on Thursday. He said more specific plans for the agreement at Hanford are expected over the next week with other site-specific plans to follow in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Police, Mowhawks Trade Gunfire In Land Dispute, Officer Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with standoff continuing, report that Oka authorities requested police intervention, comments by public security minister, premier and Mohawk spokesman, minor editing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: About 200 armed Mohawk Indians wearing war paint fought off a police assault Wednesday in a dispute over plans to expand a private golf course surrounded by tribal land. One officer was killed. Provincial police officers in helmets, fatigues and gas masks exchanged hundreds of rounds of bullets with the Indians and fired tear gas and stun grenades during a battle over several hours. Police later retreated and both sides remained behind barricades in a standoff. The Indians patrolled the edge of the disputed golf course in stolen carts in preparation for another attack. On Tuesday, Oka Mayor Jean Ouellette had asked police to intervene to enforce a court injunction ordering the removal of a Mohawk barricade set up three months ago on the access road to the disputed land. ``The reason we moved was because the Mohawks were breaking the law,'' police spokesman Richard Bourdon said. ``They were blocking a public road and this is a criminal act.'' Mohawk tribe members reacted angrily to the police attack. ``I find it awful that police would attack our people,'' said tribe member Eleanor Montour, 67. ``We're not savages, we're proud to be Mohawks. We were pushed around for centuries and we're being pushed again and we're getting awfully tired of it.'' The dispute centers on land owned by the town of Oka since 1947. The Indians have always maintained it is their land, and their Kahnesetake settlement surrounds it. Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, rents the land to the operators of the private nine-hole course. The operators say they want to cut down the white pine forest on the land and expand the course to 18 holes. Quebec's public security minister Sam Elkas insisted neither he nor any other government official knew that provincial police were headed to Oka. He said the police intervened at the request of Oka municipal authorities. After the police warned Oka officials of the possible consequences, the police then asked the Mohawks to leave the barricade, Elkas said. ``They refused, at that point we went in to remove them, and gunshots were fired,'' Elkas said. Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa blamed the violence on the Mohawks. ``What we saw this morning was revolting and intolerable,'' said Bourassa. ``We cannot accept the use of violence under any pretext, and even less so when the use of such violence is directed at those whose aim is to uphold the law,'' he said. But Mohawk spokesman Harvey Nicholas said the Indians were just returning fire after police began shooting. ``They can shoot us down like animals, but we can't shoot back,'' Nicholas said. ``People are getting killed because boys want to run around and play golf.'' Earlier this week, John Ciaccia, the minister responsible for native affairs, pleaded with the Oka Town Council to put its plans for the golf course expansion on hold. About 100 police officers in helmets, fatigues and gas masks moved into the area at about 5:30 a.m. Wednesday. Shots were fired and tear gas was lobbed into the Mohawk encampment near the barricade, but nobody was hurt. After bringing up heavy equipment and placing snipers in trees around the barricade, police staged an assault about 9 a.m. with automatic weapons, stun grenades and more tear gas. Cpl. Marcel Lemay, 31, was shot in the face and was declared dead about an hour later at nearby St. Eustache hospital. About 200 armed Mohawks wearing war paint and covering their faces with bandannas fought the police assault from the barricade. They were joined by about 100 women and children from the 1,000-member Kahnesetake community. The crackle of hundreds of rounds of gunfire was punctuated by the thud of tear gas and stun grenades detonating just outside Oka. As the wind moved tear gas back across their lines, police retreated toward Oka and the situation turned into a standoff. The Indians took advantage of the retreat to seize four police cars and two vans, then used a commandeered front-end loader to crush the vehicles to form a barricade on a hill across the main highway through the region. Their position overlooked a police roadblock at the bottom of the hill. Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, in Houston for the summit of the Western industrial powers, said he understood ``the matter was being properly handled by the authorities in Quebec.'' ``I have instructed my colleagues in Ottawa to make sure all proper assistance is offered to the provincial authorities in Quebec to bring the matter to a successful conclusion,'' he said. In a show of support for the Indians, armed Mohawks from the Kahnawake reserve south of Montreal used pickup trucks and other vehicles to set up roadblocks on two main highways leading to the Mercier Bridge, blocking thousands of residents on the south shore of the St. Lawrence River from getting to their jobs in Montreal. Three Mohawk men were arrested after they tried to flee a police patrol in the area. A police officer was slightly injured after he grabbed the door handle of the Indians' truck and was dragged for about half-a-mile. Other Mowhawk settlements on or near the U.S.-Canadian border have had similar confrontations with authorities. The Ganienkeh Mohawk encampment in northern New York was the scene of an 11-day standoff March 30 after a National Guard helicopter was shot down over Indian land. Police were called to the St. Regis Indian Reservation on the U.S.-Canadian border after an inter-tribal gambling war resulted in two shooting deaths May 1. Police remain on the reservation to this day.

DOC.HEAD: High-Tech Research Funding Advances in House Vote
DOC.TEXT: The House approved Wednesday a bill authorizing $290 million for the National Institute of Standards and Technology and expanding government technology programs. The bill would authorize $50 million this year and $100 million next year for the Advanced Technology Program, established in 1988 trade legislation to promote industrial consortiums in high-tech areas such as high-definition television, superconductivity and advanced manufacturing. It would authorize $250 million in fiscal 1992 for that technology program. President Bush had requested only $10 million for the progam, and Republicans mounted an unsuccessful effort to strip the $250 million 1992 authorization from the bill. The House voted 327 to 93 to approve the bill. Grants under the Advanced Technology Program would be awarded to research ventures on technology important for various industries, but which no single company is likely to undertake on its own, sponsors said. The Commerce Department would be required to negotiate agreements to ensure the govermment receives a return on its investment. Sponsors said the bill would help the United States be more competitive in high-technology industries in world markets. Rep. Robert Walker, R-Pa., said the Bush administration wanted no specific amount of money named in the bill for the Advanced Technology Program and warned that Bush may veto the bill. Rep. Robert Roe, D-N.J., chairman of the Science, Space and Technology Committee, responded: ``Every time we go to the bathroom around here somebody says, `check with the White House, they're going to veto.' Well, let them veto.'' The bill would authorize $290.2 million in fiscal 1991 for the National Institute of Standards and Technology, the federal agency that regulates weights and measures. That figures includes money for the technology program. A similar bill has passed the Senate, and differences will have to be worked out in conference.

DOC.HEAD: Brewers, Farmers Protest; EGerman Gov't Promises Price Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: East German beer brewers and farmers temporarily blocked West German border crossings with their trucks Wednesday to protest what they said is unfair competition from the West. The government, meanwhile, threatened to close retail stores to stop price gouging by former state-owned businesses now feasting on the nation's new free market. The government said it would take tough measures to break up the retail monopolies that have been charging arbitrarily high prices in the country since it shifted to a market economy on July 1. East Germany merged its economy with West Germany's on that date and began using the West German mark as its official currency. Former state-owned grocery and gas station chains that once sold goods at government-set levels have raised many prices dramatically, some of them even higher than in wealthy West Germany. Government spokesman Matthias Gehler said West German food retailers agreed to send ``mobile shops'' with their goods to compete against the East German firms. The government last week said it would break up the chains by selling individual stores. The Cabinet of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere on Wednesday issued an order saying that employees of the giant HO grocery and retail chain would have the first opportunity to buy those stores. De Maiziere toured two grocery stores in East Berlin and threatened to close shops and levy fines on stores guilty of price gouging. He also criticized the fact that only 15 percent of the goods sold in the stores he visited were produced in East Germany. The rest were Western products. ``My impression confirms the reports I've read,'' he said. ``We will see what we can quickly do about this.'' East Germany's beer brewers blocked a West German border points in the southwest corner of the country for about 30 minutes, creating huge traffic snarls, the East German news agency ADN said. It said the domestic brewers have lost 90 percent of their business since East Germany opened its doors to Western products on July 1. Rainer Doetsch, head of the Castle Brewery, accused West German brewers of ``dumping'' their beer in East Germany at below-market prices. Meanwhile, farmers in the agricultural heartland of the north blocked a main highway leading to the West German border with scores of tractors and trucks, ADN said. Farmers say the refusal of East German retailers to stock their goods in favor of West German products is denying them a chance to compete. Many East German retailers have signed agreements with West German grocery chains that prevent them from stocking many East German goods in their stores.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Denies Selective Prosecution of Black Politicians
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh on Wednesday angrily denied suggestions by some civil rights leaders that the Justice Department has targeted black politicians for prosecution. ``We are prosecuting people on the basis of whether or not there is legally admissible evidence to prove beyond a reasonable doubt their wrongdoing regardless of race, religion or color or political affiliation,'' Thornburgh said. The attorney general expressed disappointment that Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the NAACP, had accused federal prosecutors of targeting Washington Mayor Marion Barry and other black officials while ignoring savings-and-loan fraud by rich whites. Thornburgh told reporters at a luncheon that he had spoken to Hooks privately about the criticism that the civil rights leader had previously leveled at the Justice Department. ``Apparently his public response is to simply repeat these allegations as he did earlier this week,'' Thornburgh said. ``It disappointed me that he did.'' Hooks, in an interview with The Washington Post, charged that overzealous prosecutors had spent millions of dollars pursuing such black politiicans as Barry while ignoring ``those lying, conniving, thieving savings and loan officials who robbed this country blind.'' Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., voice a similar charge that black public officials were targeted for prosecution last spring when Thornburgh testified before the House Judiciary Committee. ``That would be a pretty hard message to sell to former Gov. Arch Moore, a white Republican who is now facing a long time in the slammer,'' said the attorney general. The former West Virginia governor was sentenced this week to nearly six years in prison for mail fraud, extortion, filing false income taxes and obstruction of justice. Thornburgh said the department did not have any figures to rebut the contention of black commentators that prosecutors spent millions of dollars to obtain the drug possession and perjury indictment of Barry, who is now on trial here. ``How can you put a price tag on justice? Our investigations cost whatever it takes to get a conviction,'' Thornburgh said. Asked what steps he was taking to counter the perception that black public officials are being singled out, Thornburgh said: ``I don't know how you address false perceptions other than by inviting people to look at the record. ``The record clearly indicates there is no such pattern of prosecution,'' he said. The attorney general said the department does not compile statistics on the race, religion or political affiliation or criminal defendants that he contended would rebut the charges. ``Do you think it would make any difference?'' he said. Of 21 congressmen convicted of crimes relating to their conduct in office since 1976, only one was black, according to a list provided later in the day by the Justice Department. Former Rep. Charles Diggs, D-Mich., was convicted of payroll padding.

DOC.HEAD: Intellectuals: Will End Strike if Gov't Has No Communist Ties
DOC.TEXT: Artists, intellectuals and students said Wednesday they would end their sit-down strike only if the government agrees to work under a new president with no links to the Communists. The strikers, camping in scores of tents dubbed ``the city of truth,'' forced the resignation last Friday of President Petar Mladenov, a former leading member of the governing Socialist Party, which is the renamed Communist Party. The main opposition alliance, the 16-party Union of Democratic Forces, has indicated it would nominate Petar Dertliev, the respected 74-year-old leader of the Social Democratic Party, as the UDF presidential candidate. But the leader of another influential party within the UDF said Wednesday he opposed Dertliev's candidacy. Milan Drenchev, leader of the opposition Agrarian-Nikola Petkov Party, charged the Social Democrats harbor many former Communists. Drenchev's reasoning for rejecting Dertliev contradicts Dertliev's own account of his hardships under the Communists. Earlier this year, Dertliev said that as a Social Democratic Party activist he had spent 10 years in prison for his political activities after the Communist takeover. Drenchev ruled out a candidacy for himself. According to Bulgarian newspapers and analysts, other possible candidates may be Zhivko Stalev, head of the Central Electoral Commission, and Blagovest Sendov, president of the Academy of Sciences. Both are considered unaffiliated. The Socialists won an absolute majority of 211 of Parliament's 400 seats in last month's multiparty elections. The UDF garnered 144 mandates, 32 of which went to the Agrarian-Nikola Petkov Party, Drenchev said. The student demonstration, which began about a month ago, was seen as significant because it has been joined by top scientists and professors, including representatives of the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences. The students began their protest because of alleged manipulations in June's parliamentary elections, in which the Socialists won a majority of seats. The demonstrators are also demanding a public trial of ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, under investigation for alleged abuse of power, incitement to ethnic hatred and misappropriation of state property. The demonstrators reiterated their other demands at an improvised open-air news conference Wednesday. They want: _A new president who is not linked to the political and army establishment. _Removal of parliamentary immunity from people implicated in the running of prison camps in the 1950s, in the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia and in the state persecution of ethnic Turks in 1984-85. _And the ``whole truth'' revealed about the Bulgarian foreign debt, now totaling about $10 billion, and about the property of the ruling party and its former leaders.

DOC.HEAD: No More Swimsuit Photo Sessions For Miss America Pageant
DOC.TEXT: Miss America contestants will no longer pose for photographers in swimsuits, but the swimsuit competition will remain a part of the preliminary and final contests, the pageant director said Wednesday. ``I personally find it difficult to rationalize putting a young college woman in a swimsuit and high heel shoes,'' said Leonard Horn, who feels the photo sessions no longer fit in with a pageant he envisions as a scholarship contest. He noted, however, that pageant traditionalists oppose removing that segment, adding, ``It's such an integral and traditional part of the competition that I would be loathe to change it without an alternative.'' In years past, photo sessions with bathing suit-clad contestants were held at sites around Atlantic City. Judges tally the score according to a formula that gives 15 percent each to the swimsuit and evening gown competitions, 30 percent for an interview with a preliminary panel of judges and 40 percent for talent.

DOC.HEAD: Witness: Friends Covered Up Super Bowl Cocaine Collapse By Barry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, Barry was, to CORRECT Washington Redskins to New York Giants; picks up 9th graf, In the, ^By PETE YOST
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry collapsed from a cocaine overdose during a 1987 trip to the Super Bowl and friends helped cover up the cause of his medical treatment, a lawyer testified Wednesday at the mayor's drug and perjury trial. Lloyd Moore, who also described using drugs with the mayor, said he learned of the cocaine overdose in January 1987 in a telephone conversation with a friend of Barry's who was in Los Angeles with Barry. Barry's friend, Jeffrey Mitchell, ``indicated that they had smoked ... cocaine laced with something,'' Moore said of the phone call. Barry was ``very sick. ... They thought he was going to die,'' Moore said Mitchell told him. Moore was the sixth prosecution witness to describe using drugs with the three-term mayor. He followed to the stand Theresa Southerland, a 27-year-old secretary who said she snorted cocaine repeatedly from 1987 to 1989 at apartments and homes and on two trips to the Bahamas. Barry is facing 10 counts of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy and three counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged involvement with drugs. Prosecutors are using the testimony of Moore, who was appointed by Barry to the city boxing and arts commissions, to support a charge that Barry conspired to conceal his cocaine use. Barry was hospitalized for what was officially described as a hiatal hernia in 1987 in Los Angeles, where he had traveled to see the New York Giants play the Denver Broncos in the Super Bowl. In the phone call, Mitchell said he told hospital workers ``what he would allow them to do,'' testified Moore. The hospital ``was not allowed to take blood'' from the mayor, Moore said Mitchell told him. Moore, who practices law in Washington, testified he and Barry used cocaine together at Moore's home about six times from May 1986 to March 1987. Barry used cocaine by himself at Moore's home about three times, Moore said, adding that he gave Barry cocaine ``a couple of times,'' each time in an amount worth about $50. ``Thirteen times you saw the defendant use or possess cocaine in your home?'' asked assistant U.S. attorney Richard Roberts. ``That is correct,'' replied Moore. Moore was appointed by Barry to the D.C. Boxing Commission and the D.C. Commission on the Arts and Humanities. The testimony of Southerland, the second woman to testify about having a romantic relationship with Barry, echoed statements by other witnesses who said they had used drugs with the mayor at Washington homes and in the Bahamas. ``I hit the cocaine and he hit the cocaine,'' Southerland said of a March 1988 get-together with Barry at the Washington residence of a friend of the mayor. ``I used my fingernail'' to snort the cocaine up her nose and ``he used a (business) card,'' she said of Barry. FBI tests last month turned up traces of cocaine on Barry's business cards seized Jan. 18 when he was videotaped in a sting operation smoking crack, according to earlier testimony. Southerland met the mayor at a Washington nightclub, became romantically involved with him and the two started taking drugs in November 1987, she said. They last used drugs last November, she said. Southerland testified that ``Marion invited me'' to the Bahamas around Thanksgiving 1987. She testified she was known to Barry's group simply as ``T or Miss T.'' In his hotel suite, Barry produced some cocaine, which was piled atop a dollar bill, and the mayor took ``three or four hits,'' she said. Restaurateur Hassan Mohammadi testified earlier that he had given the cocaine for that trip to Barry in the mayor's office. Southerland said she also carried some cocaine with her on the trip and the mayor snorted it with her. She said Barry also smoked opium, a drug she said she did not like, at Mohammadi's home. Under cross-examination by Barry's lawyers, Southerland said she and Barry often had ``five to eight shots'' of liquor each when they used drugs. She admitted that she had been a cocaine user for about a year before she met Barry and said she often supplied the drugs that the two used.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Wednesday's Session of Party Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2 `BATTLE FOR' to UPDATE with Ivashko victory. Picks up 3rd pvs, `ANTI_COMMUNIST RALLY...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Highlights of Wednesday's session of the 28th Communist Party congress, its ninth day:
BATTLE FOR NO. 2: Delegates voted for the post of an assistant to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, installing a Gorbachev protege, Ukrainian Vladimir Ivashko, over Politburo traditionalist Yegor K. Ligachev.

ANTI-COMMUNIST RALLY: On the edge of Red Square, about 500 anti-Communist demonstrators rallied in the evening, shaking their fists in the face of delegates who were leaving the congress. One demonstrator spat at a delegate, another yelled ``This is your last meeting in Moscow!'' and others chanted ``Shame!'' and ``Down with the Communist Party!'' Scores of police kept the demonstrators off the cobblestones of Red Square.

NAMING THE BABY: A relaxed, smiling Gorbachev read a brief note to delegates about a happy event for one of their comrades. ``Please congratulate Anatoly D. Kravchenko on the birth of a son, an heir, on the 10th of July,'' Gorbachev said to loud applause. ``Are we going to discuss what to call the son or not?'' Gorbachev continued, playfully, as the delegates roared with laughter. ``And then vote on it?''

KEY QUOTE: ``As much as I have before, no matter what my job, I will be working for perestroika. We have to do everything to renew the party and changes its priorities. We have to understand that without us, without the party, nothing will be left of perestroika.'' _ Vladimir Ivashko, Gorbachev's choice as his right-hand man in the party leadership.

DOC.HEAD: American Chamber of Commerce Chief Leaves Country After Threats
DOC.TEXT: The president of the American Chamber of Commerce in the Philippines, who criticized government economic policies, has left the country after receiving warnings that his life was in danger, sources said Thursday. Mark Blacker, who is also first vice president of the American Express Bank and executive director of the International Corporate Bank, left for Hong Kong last week, sources in the business community said. It was uncertain when he would return. His departure comes amid increasing concern over security for about 140,000 Americans residing in the Philippines. Officials of the chamber are not generally known outside the business community. But Blacker had been in the news recently after publicly criticizing President Corazon Aquino's government for failing to provide incentives to foreign investors. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Blacker was warned that Communist rebels planned to kill him. They said Blacker had been planning to go abroad anyway for eye surgery but that the timing of his departure was influenced by concern over his security. Communist rebels are believed to have killed eight Americans in the Philippines since April 1989. All but two of them were U.S. service members or affiliated with the military. In a statement last year, Romulo Kintanar, commander of the New People's Army, said U.S. service members were the principal targets and that the rebels would not harm ordinary civilians who were not linked to the government's counterinsurgency program. Last month, the U.S. government withdrew all Peace Corps members and suspended the program because of fears that the rebels would try to kill or kidnap a volunteer. After the order, U.S. officials learned that one volunteer, Timothy Swanson of Cheyenne, Wyo., had been held by the rebels on Negros Island since June 13. The newspaper BusinessWorld said Blacker received a warning from a U.S. official one day after he told foreign correspondents that would-be investors were being driven from the Philippines because of inadequate infrastructure and government indecision. ``I don't see any solution at hand,'' Blacker said in a meeting with correspondents July 3. ``I don't know what they (government agencies) are doing. I would like to see more unity of purpose between everybody in this country.'' Blacker's comments were widely reported in the Philippine media. Some commentators claimed the remarks were part of an orchestrated U.S. government plot to pressure the government to extend the lease on the six American military bases, which expires in September 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Violence with Mohawk Indians on U.S.-Canada Border
With AM-Mohawk, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Mohawk Indians who live on the border between the United States and Canada are again in conflict with the authorities. Here is a look at their relations with the governments on both sides of the border in recent years. 1979 _ 20 ``traditionalists'' Mohawks were arrested after a handful of Franklin County deputies were held hostage over the cutting down of trees by tribal Mohawks who elect the tribe's leaders. 1980 _ New York State sends 70 heavily armed policemen onto the reservation to head off a confrontation between tribal Mohawks and traditionalist Mohawks. June 1989 _ State police complete a two-day raid on the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation, arresting four people for illegal gambling and confiscating more than 200 gambling machines. July 1989 _ 300 FBI agents and state troopers raid gambling casinos on the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation, arresting 12 Mohawk Indians on gambling charges. Following the raid, there is a 10-day standoff between state and federal authorities and the Warriors Society, a self-appointed Mohawk security force. August 1989 _ Shots are fired at a one of the gambling casinos on the St. Regis Reservation in the latest round of violence stemming from gambling on the Reservation. November 1989 _ Offices of a weekly pro-gambling newspaper on the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation are hit by gunfire in further violence over illegal gambling casinos. March 1990 _ A doctor aboard a Vermont National Guard helicopter, on a medical mission, was struck by a bullet fired from a rifle as the helicopter flew over the Ganienkeh Mohawk Territory. Three bullets penetrated the helicopter. July 11 _ Mohawk Indians wearing warpaint fire on Canadian police, killing one officer in a dispute over land for a golf course.

DOC.HEAD: Regional Party Bosses Headed for Politburo of All Political Stripes
With Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 15 republic Communist Party leaders to become Politburo members under new rules adopted by the party congress include traditionalists and reformers. Most want a deal with the Kremlin to give the regions more autonomy. Following are thumbnail sketches: ARMENIA _ Vladimir Movsisyan took office in April, succeeding a strong Armenian nationalist. Born in 1935, he has spent his entire career in Armenia, specializing in agriculture. He is thought to be a traditionalist inclined toward reforms, including more sovereignty for the republics. AZERBAIJAN _ Ayaz N. Mutalibov leads a republic that has been under martial law for six months due to ethnic rioting. Mutalibov was elected in January after his predecessor was expelled from the party. An economist and technocrat, Mutalibov worked at a household appliance factory in the republic's capital of Baku before switching to party work in 1977. In a 1989 interview in the government newspaper Izvestia, he was quoted as saying it was necessary to strengthen the economy before tackling social problems such as unemployment. BYELORUSSIA _ Yefrem Sokolov supports glasnost and advocated open discussions of public policy before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985. However, Byelorussia was one of the last republics in which grassroots movements took hold and it has acquired a reputation as a conservative backwater. ESTONIA _ The Estonian Communist Party plans to split this fall into two factions, both of which are represented at the Congress. The independent faction is led by chairman Vaino Vyalyas, a former ambassador and Communist Youth League comrade of Gorbachev's youth, and first secretary Enn Arno Sillari. The loyalist faction is led by Alexander Gusev. It is not known which faction's leader would be chosen for the Politburo. GEORGIA _ Givi Gumbaridze, an enthusiastic supporter of Gorbachev and his reforms, was born in 1945, making him one of the youngest republic party leaders. He was chairman of the KGB in the southern republic for four months before taking over the party post in April 1989, replacing a leader blamed for permitting a military crackdown on demonstrators. Georgia is pushing for independence and has a strong secession movement supported by many republic Communist leaders. KAZAKHSTAN _ Nursultan Nazarbaev supports reforms to give his Asian republic control of its natural resources and revive its language. He wants to close the nuclear testing range at Semipalatinsk. Born in 1940 and trained as a technocrat, he advanced rapidly in the party and was elected first secretary in June 1989. Speaking to the congress, he pleaded for clearer direction from the Kremlin, likening current policy to ``an army that is retreating in haste without a plan.'' KIRGHIZIA _ Absomat Masaliyev is a traditionalist who feels party leaders have not adequately defended the party from critical attacks. He called for the safeguarding of communist ideals, saying anything else would be a betrayal of whole generations of communists. He repeatedly quoted Lenin to a congress that has otherwise rarely referred to its former leader. LATVIA _ Alfreds Rubiks, 54, was listed by a Latvian youth magazine in 1988 and 1989 as one of the most unpopular men in his small Baltic republic. A career party worker, Rubiks came to prominence as mayor of the capital city of Riga in 1984. Rubiks opposed Latvia's independence declaration in May. The republic's Communist Party has split, and Rubiks leads the majority pro-Moscow faction. He complained at the congress that Communist parties were too eager to make compromises with other groups. LITHUANIA _ Mikolas Burakevicius, a hard-liner, represents a close-knit Communist group opposed to independence. His faction is greatly outnumbered by the pro-independence faction led by Algirdas Brazauskas, which was not invited to the party congress. MOLDAVIA _ Pyotr Luchinsky, a reformer, is a native of Moldavia, which shares language and culture with bordering Romania and which has declared itself sovereign with the right to overturn national laws. Luchinsky, who took office in November 1989, says the earlier the 15 republics obtain full self-reliance, the faster ethnic tensions will subside. The son of peasants, Luchinsky studied history and philosophy before launching a career in Moldavia's Young Communist League. He worked in the party's propaganda department in Moscow and was second-secretary in Tajikistan before returning to Moldavia. RUSSIAN FEDERATION _ Ivan Polozkov, 55, swept to power on a tide of conservatism last month at the reconstitution of the Russian wing of the party. The previous month he narrowly lost the Russian presidency to Boris Yeltsin. As party leader in the southern Russian region of Krasnodar, Polozkov gained attention for a vigorous campaign against cooperatives, the small, privately held businesses permitted under Gorbachev's reforms. Polozkov, an economist, says he's not as conservative as critics claim. TADZHIKISTAN _ Kakhar Makhkamov complained to the congress that new social groups and parties criticize the Communist Party without taking any responsibility themselves for society's problem. He advocated a strong party and implied it was still virtually indivisible from the government. However, he backed more independence for republic parties and defended Gorbachev. TURKMENIA _ Sappar Niyazov appears to be a centrist trying to steer a middle course on perestroika, but occasionally veers to the right. UKRAINE _ Stanislav Gurenko, the newly elected party chief in the second-largest republic, warned congress delegates not to underestimate the dangers of anti-communism: ``We should rebuff mud-slinging slander. We should not retreat from our positions, we should stop committing suicide, we should stop this self-flagellation.'' Gurenko faces anti-communist challenges in the Don River coal-mining basin in the eastern Ukraine and in the western region near Lvov. UZBEKISTAN _ Islam Karimov, 52, gave a cautious speech to the congress, mildly criticizing central authorities for their handling of ethnic disputes. He said he supported Gorbachev as party leader but felt the party should not deviate from its core policy of democratic centralism.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Says It Needs $2.2 Billion a Year to Save the Amazon
DOC.TEXT: The government said Wednesday it needs $2.2 billion a year in aid from industrialized countries to stop the destruction of the Amazon, the world's largest wilderness. Science and Technology Secretary Jose Goldemberg said the money would be used to replant deforested areas, relocate settlers and patrol the Amazon to stop slash-and-burn devastation of the vast jungle. Scientists say slash-and-burn destruction of Amazon rain forest by ranchers and farmers releases carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and adds to the greenhouse effect, which increases the Earth's temperature. ``This wouldn't be charity,'' Goldemberg told The Associated Press. ``The developed countries would be defending their own interests by stopping the global warming.'' An average of 8,700 square miles of rain forest has been cut and burned each year since 1978, or about 8 percent of the 2-million-square-mile wilderness, Goldemberg said. He said the data was obtained from Brazil's Space Research Institute, based on 222 Landsat satellite photos of the rain forest. Earlier estimates of Amazon destruction had ranged from 5 to 20 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Protests by Homeless Israelis Turn Violent
DOC.TEXT: Homeless Israelis living in tents throughout the country on Wednesday blocked major road junctions and burned tires as protests for housing solutions turned violent. In Tel Aviv, dozens of protesters burned tires at the Tel Kabir junction. They were later dispersed by police, and no arrests were reported. At the Housing Ministry in Jerusalem, 22-year-old Yaakov Azulai poured petrol on his body and threatened to set himself on fire, Israel radio reported. It said police and an ambulance crew called to the scene persuaded Azulai not to go through with his threat. In downtown Jerusalem, hundreds of protesters marched toward the Parliament and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's residence, blocking roads on their way. Some demostrators scuffled with police who tried to force them off the roads, witnesses said. There were no arrests or injuries, although one demostrator fainted and was taken to a hospital. The protesters returned to their tent encampment across from Israel's Parliament later Wednesday. Rents have doubled and even tripled throughout Israel with the arrival of Soviet immigrant wave, which has totalled more than 63,000 since 1989. It is expected to reach a total of 150,000 this year. The demonstrations were the first violent protests by Israelis forced out of their rented homes by the inflated housing prices. The immigrants, meanwhile, are beginning to experience housing shortages themselves. A group of Soviet Jews joined the protesters living in tents in Jerusalem, saying they would soon become homeless as well. A violent incident involving Soviet Jews was reported Wednesday in Nazareth Ilit, or Upper Nazareth, the Jewish suburb of the biblical Nazareth in northern Israel. Israel radio said the state-run Amidar housing company invted Soviet immigrants to look at 250 renovated apartments available in the city. Roughly 900 Soviets arrived from across the country, and a scuffle between them soon developed into a ``full-scale riot'' as a result of which four immigrants were hospitalized, the radio reported.

DOC.HEAD: Medellin Cartel Boss Escobar Evades Police Once Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 5th graf `But the' to UPDATE with police spokeswoman blaming TV station for blowing cover on raid. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `The raid...'
DOC.TEXT: Security forces nearly captured Pablo Escobar, reputed leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel, but the billionaire fugitive escaped into the jungle, police said Wednesday. During a widespread drug raid Tuesday in northeastern Colombia, police closed in on Escobar, Colombia's most wanted man, a national police spokesman told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. He spoke on condition of anonymity in accordance with police policy. Police said that during the raid they arrested 11 employees of the Medellin drug cartel, all of whom are reportedly close associates of Escobar. But the drug lord, aided by about 15 bodyguards, fled into the jungle near Puerto Triunfo, about 75 miles east of Bogota, the police spokesman said. A police spokeswoman blamed a television station for blowing the cover on the supposedly confidential raid. Attempting to explain how Escobar had eluded capture once again, she said Colombia's TV Hoy had disclosed the raid. ``This has hurt us. It has taken the element of surprise from the operation,'' she said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The raid was the latest attack in the government's 11-month-old war on drug traffickers. It began last August when traffickers were blamed for the assassination of leading presidential hopeful Luis Carlos Galan. Since then, the traffickers have retaliated with a terror campaign of car bombings, massacres and police assassinations, and hundreds of people have been killed. About 600 army troops and policemen participated in the raid, a presidential press spokesman told The AP. He also spoke on condition of anonymity. Some of the officers who directed the operation were trained by the British and Canadian armies, the police spokesman said. The police spokesman said the operation will continue indefinitely, and the head of Colombia's national police, Miguel Gomez Padilla, told reporters he still hoped to capture Escobar. ``We believe that he is still in the region. We are close to him,'' Gomez said. Police said that among those arrested was Escobar's brother-in-law, Hernan Quintero. The police spokesman said Quintero supplied dynamite and weapons to be used in the cartel's bombing and assassination campaigns. Also arrested was the man believed to be Escobar's personal physician, Jose Cortes, the police spokesman said. The other suspects allegedly included Escobar's security chief and a man believed to be in charge of transporting hired assassins around Colombia, the Bogota daily newspaper El Tiempo said, quoting police sources. Troops sweeped the region, using helicopters and radio equipment, after a private citizen requesting anonymity tipped authorities to Escobar's whereabouts, authorities said. The police spokesman said officers seized 7,700 pounds of dynamite, assault rifles, revolvers, sophisticated communications equipment and documents that could lead to Escobar's capture. At one point during the raid, security forces were able to intercept Escobar's communications with his guards, the police spokesman said. Escobar had escaped manhunts twice before in the last year. The last time was in central Colombia in November when he fled into the jungle in his underwear after being encircled. The government has offered to pay $400,000 for information leading to Escobar's capture, alive or dead. Authorities say his drug empire is based in Medellin, Colombia's second-largest city with almost 3 million inhabitants. The city, 150 miles northwest of Bogota, has been plagued by drug violence. Gen. Harold Bedoya, Medellin's army commander, has accused Escobar of the June 23 massacre of 19 people, many of them teen-age students, at a Medellin bar. He said the attack was carried out in retaliation for authorities killing the drug cartel's terrorist operations chief, John Jairo Arias, in the city June 13. Authorities say drug traffickers have placed a bounty of $4,300 on the heads of all police officers in the city. More than 100 have been killed this year. One of the cartel's leaders, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, was killed in December on Colombia's northern coast. Since August, the administration of President Virgilio Barco has extradited 15 drug suspects to face charges in the United States and confiscated hundreds of properties belonging to the cocaine barons. At one time, the Medellin cartel was believed responsible for most of the cocaine that is smuggled into the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Philly Mayor's Task Force on Homeless Resigns in Protest
DOC.TEXT: A committee formed in 1983 to advise the mayor on the homeless quit in protest Wednesday, saying Mayor W. Wilson Goode ignored it while making drastic cuts in services. Some 80 members of the Mayor's Public-Private Task Force on Homelessness resigned in a unanimous voice vote at a meeting two days after its leadership recommended the action. After the vote, the city's managing director, David Pingree, told the group that quitting en masse would leave the homeless without a voice in City Hall. ``They are advocates for the homeless,'' Pingree said afterward. ``The task force provided them an internal mechanism in government that very few groups had the opportunity to have. ``In order to preserve the purity of their advocacy, they were throwing away a very pragmatic tool.'' ``We're not losing anything _ we're gaining the ability to go back to being advocates,'' said task force steering committee co-chairwoman Chris Simiriglia. ``It sent them a message,'' said Chris Sprowal, founder of the Committee for Dignity and Fairness for the Homeless and a member of the task force's steering committee. ``It says the most conservative homeless group in the city will not sit still while you try to implement these terrible, terrible cuts.'' Steering committee member Phyllis Ryan, director of the Philadelphia Committee for the Homeless, a private organization, estimated last year's budget cut money for the homeless in half, to $17 million. The current budget cuts leave only about $10 million for homeless services, she said. ``Nobody can use us again to say there is a rational process going on here,'' Ryan said. ``That was destroyed today.'' The task force _ made up of officials from city agencies, directors of private efforts such as shelters and soup kitchens, as well as homeless people _ had no real power, members said. ``This has been a con job for years,'' Sprowal said. ``They have made people feel important by saying `You're a member of a task force,' and they get letters from the mayor, saying `Come to a meeting.' ``And they feel important, that they have some influence. When in the end they found out they had no damn influence at all.'' Pingree, managing director for four months, said he regretted that the group quit. He said nobody from the group had come to him during budget talks to argue their case. A statement from the steering committee said: ``Our protests against the devastation of the cutbacks fell on deaf ears. It's now impossible to remain in this group whose forum has no influence.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Rejects Probe of Rabin
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Wednesday rejected calls for a probe of former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin's handling of the Palestinian uprising. The move came hours after a new poll was released indicating Rabin has become Israel's most popular politician. The poll showed Rabin, the No. 2 man in the left-leaning Labor Party, could defeat Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, the leading figures in the right-wing Likud bloc, if direct elections were held. However, the poll indicated both Shamir and Sharon could defeat the Labor Party leader, former Prime Minister Shimon Peres, if the elections were held now. The poll was expected to strengthen Rabin's hand in challenging Peres for party leadership. Voters currently select slates of candidates, but Parliament has given preliminary approval to a bill for election reform for direct balloting. The motion for a probe of Rabin's handling of the Palestinian uprising was defeated by a vote of 65 to 16. Both right- and left-wing legislators had accused Rabin of illegally ordering soldiers to beat rioters in January 1988. The orders led to a number of deaths and serious injuries of Palestinians. Rabin was defense minister until March 13, when he resigned with other Labor ministers to protest Shamir's hesitancy to accept American peace proposals. Shamir last month formed a right-wing government that excluded Labor. In all, 723 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians since the uprising began in December 1987. An additional 233 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most for alleged collaboration with Israeli authorities. Forty-five Israelis also have been killed by Arabs. One sponsor of the call for a probe accused Rabin of failing to support army officers charged with illegally beating Palestinians to death. He claimed troop morale was also at stake. ``You personally gave these orders, why shouldn't you stand trial?'' said Michael Eitan of Shamir's Likud bloc. ``Soldiers from now on will fear that all the orders they get will later be disavowed.'' Another sponsor, Yossi Sarid of the left-wing Citizens' Rights Movement, said ``if the government found it necessary to establish an investigation into Sabra and Chatilla, it should certainly do so now.'' He was refefering to the 1982 massacre in Beirut refugee camps by Lebanese militiamen during Israel's occupation. An official inquiry into the massacre of hundreds of Palestinian refugees ended in the resigation of Sharon as defense minister. Rabin defended his policies by saying that beatings were ordered to limit the use of live ammunition, which were causing many fatalities at the time. He insisted his instructions were clear that once a demonstration was under control, beating should cease. Rabin said he told senior officers on Jan. 21, 1988, that ``the aggressive response by our soldiers, including beatings, during riots and against attacks on our forces, are necessary to prevent the worst -- opening fire and causing death.'' ``And I also said in the same discussion, `this, which means beatings, is better than what went before, which means opening fire with live ammunition, on condition it is done during demonstrations and attacks and not afterwards.'' The Israeli-born Rabin, 68, also a former prime minister, gained popularity in Israel for his tough stance against the Palestinian uprising. The poll indicating his most recent popularity was conducted between June 24 and July 3 among 1,200 Jewish adults by independent pollster Hanoch Smith. It had three percent margin of error. It was published in The Jerusalem Post daily. It showed that in a direct election Rabin would gather 50 percent of the vote, to Shamir's 33 percent. The remainder were undecided. Against Sharon, 54 percent would choose Rabin, 28 percent Sharon. Shamir, however, would out-poll Labor leader Peres 44 percent to 29 percent, and Sharon would beat him 37 percent to 34 percent. New elections are not scheduled until 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Byelorussia Declares Disaster Area Because of Chernobyl
DOC.TEXT: The Byelorussian legislature declared the republic a ``national ecological disaster zone'' Wednesday because of the Chernobyl nuclear plant disaster and ordered that supplies of cars and tractors to other regions be cut, Tass said. The news agency said the supplies were being reduced because contaminated vehicles must be taken out of service. It offered no explanation. Tass said milk and meat supplies to other republics were also being reduced. Byelorussia received much of the radioactivity from Chernobyl, which is in the neighboring Ukraine, but its leaders have been slow to order evacuations of residents and take cleanup measures. More than 2 million Byelorussians are living on contaminated land four years after the accident, Tass said, and more than 119,000 of them must be moved. In Gomel, Byelorussia, workers at 20 factories struck for two hours Wednesday to complain about government handling of the Chernobyl cleanup.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Says `Dick Tracy' Video Plans Unset
DOC.TEXT: Disputing a report that ``Dick Tracy'' may appear in video stores as early as November, the Walt Disney Co. said Wednesday that the film's video debut has not been set. The Wall Street Journal, citing industry sources, reported Wednesday that ``Dick Tracy'' could arrive in video stores for the Christmas season. A spokeswoman for Disney's home video arm said that although the company has discussed the video release of ``Dick Tracy'' with retailers, no firm decision has been made. ``This is really in the discussion stage,'' said the spokeswoman, Tania Steele, who said Disney also hasn't picked a suggested retail price. ``Dick Tracy,'' starring Warren Beatty, Al Pacino and Madonna, is playing in more than 2,200 theaters and has been one of the box-office blockbusters of the summer season.

An earthquake in northwestern British Columbia jolted parts of the Yukon and Alaska on Wednesday, the Pacific Geoscience Center reported. There were no reports of damage or casualties. The quake measured 5.4 on the Richter scale and was centered in the St. Elias Mountains about 35 miles west of Haines, Alaska. It was felt at Whitehorse and Haines Junction in the Yukon and in Alaska. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of 5.0 magnitude can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Supreme Court Hears Arguments in Impeached Governor Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to show that court is simply considering whether it can consider challenge.
DOC.TEXT: The Arizona Supreme Court said Wednesday it will consider whether it has jurisidiction over a challenge that could determine impeached Gov. Evan Mecham's comeback attempt.
DOC.HEAD: A former, 2nd graf.
Jesse Jackson Calls on President Bush to Hold Civil Rights Summit
LaserPhoto LA8
