DOC.TEXT: In an early version of an article July 10 on the federal fraud trial of three commodities traders, The Associated Press erroneously reported that the jury failed to reach a verdict on more than 70 counts against Chicago Mercantile Exchange trader Robert D. Mosky. The jury convicted Mosky of five fraud counts and two counts of violating trading rules, acquitted him of 20 other counts and failed to reach a verdict on 55 counts.

DOC.HEAD: Analyst Fired Over Trump Remarks Files Suit
DOC.TEXT: A securities analyst fired after panning Donald Trump's new casino is seeking $2 million in damages for alleged defamatory comments by the developer that he was a ``bad analyst'' and ``unguided missile.'' Marvin B. Roffman, formerly a vice president with the Philadelphia brokerage firm Janney Montgomery Scott Inc., sued the New York real estate and casino operator in U.S. District Court on Tuesday. Roffman, 50, was fired March 23, three days after a negative critique in The Wall Street Journal about Trump's new Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City, N.J. The case has attracted wide attention, not only because it involves Trump but because it has raised questions about the independence of securities analysts who comment frequently about companies and business trends. Roffman told the Journal Trump's casino would flourish immediately after it opened in April, but ``once the cold winds blow from October to February, it won't make it. The market just isn't there.'' John Barry, a Trump spokesman, said he expects the lawsuit to be dismissed. ``We will take the appropriate action to have the suit dismissed as quickly as possible,'' he said. In a letter to Janney Montgomery President Norman T. Wilde after Roffman's comments were published Trump said, ``For a long while I have thought of Mr. Roffman as an unguided missile,'' according to the suit. The lawsuit contends Trump's letter ``contained false and defamatory material'' because Roffman's comments ``were not outrageous; he is not an unguided missile, unprofessional ... and a bad analyst.'' Roffman's attorney, Martin Sobol, said his client believes he lost his job because ``he was honest.'' Roffman, who is currently unemployed, declined to comment. The lawsuit quotes publications that reported Trump's comments about Roffman as evidence of defamation. In the April 2 edition of Barron's, Trump said of Roffman: ``He's a very unprofessional guy, a hair trigger.'' In the May 7 edition of Fortune, Trump is quoted as saying: ``They got rid of a bad analyst, a man with little talent,'' the lawsuit said. Barry said Trump was free to express himself. ``If Mr. Roffman thought the statements were defamatory, why isn't he suing the publications in which they appear?'' Barry said. The lawsuit also claims Trump ``maliciously'' persuaded Janney Montgomery to fire Roffman. ``Mr. Trump has no financial interest or control over Janney Montgomery. To blame Mr. Trump for Janney Montgomery's action is incomprehensible,'' Barry said. Trump threatened to sue Janney Montgomery unless Roffman publicly retracted the comments or the firm fired the 16-year veteran analyst. Roffman initially signed a letter of apology, but withdrew it in a second letter and then was fired. Janney Montgomery contended Roffman was dismissed because he violated company policy by issuing statements to the press that had not been cleared or disseminated to the firm's clients. Wilde said in a statement that Roffman also disobeyed a supervisor's orders by sending the second letter to Trump retracting his apology. ``In dismissing Mr. Roffman, we took measures to uphold industry standards concerning the professional integrity of security analysts,'' the statement said. Janney Montgomery is a wholly owned subsidiary of Penn Mutual Life Insurance Co. The firm has 1,050 employees and 40 offices. Roffman's comments about Trump made him a highly sought subject for interviews, especially after recent disclosures that Trump faced a cash crunch. Trump made a last-minute deal with bankers June 26 that allowed him to meet the $43 million payment to holders of high-yield junk bonds backing another casino, the Trump Castle.

DOC.HEAD: Futures Industry Breathes Sigh of Relief
DOC.TEXT: From the trading floors to the executive suites, futures industry professionals breathed a little easier after the government failed to prove a fraud racket operated at Chicago Mercantile Exchange. ``The reaction here is a deep sigh of relief,'' said John Damgard, president of the Washington-based Futures Industry Association, a trade group for commodity futures brokerage firms. ``The verdicts shore up the contention that this was petty theft compared with everything that's gone on in the savings and loan and securities industries, and we can feel pretty good about ourselves,'' Damgard said. Business was brisk Tuesday in the Merc's Swiss franc futures pit _ one day after a federal jury convicted two franc traders of relatively minor trading violations and acquitted a third. The jury could not reach verdicts on scores of more serious charges, including a racketeering count against one defendant and mail and wire fraud charges against all three. Federal prosecutors have said they plan to refile the remaining charges against the men, whose sentencings are tentatively scheduled for November. Two more commodity fraud trials resulting from an FBI sting operation at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade are scheduled for September. Monday's conclusion of two months of U.S. District Court proceedings felt ``like kissing your sister,'' said Anton Valukas, the former U.S. attorney, now in private practice, who initiated the 1988 undercover probe and announced the indictments last August. But Valukas said he was not disappointed in the verdicts. ``In terms of the overall investigation and prosecution, my sense is that you await the outcome of all of the cases and then you can sit back and talk about whether it was appropriate or not appropriate,'' he said. Several defense lawyers preparing for the September trials said they were heartened by the verdicts. ``It puts into serious question the government's basic claim that what happened here is that customers were defrauded on a wholesale basis,'' said James Streicker, attorney for indicted yen futures trader Michael Smith. Defense lawyers said the government's failure to win a conviction on the racketeering count would dissuade other traders charged with racketeering from pleading guilty to reduced charges. Leo Melamed, chairman of the Merc's executive committee, noted that the guilty verdicts on eight counts _ seven against floor broker Robert D. Mosky and one against independent trader Danny Scheck _ represented a total of $200 in funds lost to their customers through trading irregularities. Melamed said the Merc did not condone any wrongdoing but added, ``It has to be put in perspective.'' ``We clearly don't believe this is as major a federal crime as some of these other things that are going on,'' he said, citing scandals in the S&L industry and the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Sol Kaufman, an independent trader of currency futures at the Merc, said news of the investigation and indictment's had tarnished the Merc's image. ``I think to a certain degree this verdict will redeem that reputation,'' he said. The jury found independent trader David Zatz innocent of two counts of trading violations. The jury also acquitted Mosky of 20 counts of mail and wire fraud and couldn't reach a verdict on the racketeering count against him. The panel returned verdicts on just 30 of the 116 counts in the federal indictment. Each commodity fraud count conviction carries a maximum prison sentence of five years and a $100,000 fine, prosecutors said. The two-month trial was the first to result from a sweeping undercover FBI investigation of corruption at the Merc and the larger Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two biggest futures exchanges. In all, 48 people have been indicted since August. Sixteen have pleaded guilty to reduced charges, including two Swiss franc traders who testified against Mosky, Scheck and Zatz. Two other groups _ 13 soybean traders from the Board of Trade and 15 Japanese yen traders from the Merc _ go on trial in September.

DOC.HEAD: Research Group Christens World's First Superconducting Ship
DOC.TEXT: With the smack of a sake bottle, Japanese shipbuilders on Wednesday christened the world's first ship that will use superconductivity to push itself through the water. The high-tech ship, christened the Yamato No. 1, is an experimental vessel shaped roughly like a streamlined telephone. It is drydocked in the Kobe shipyard of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Japan's largest shipbuilder and a member of a consortium developing the ship's new technology. The ship's developers said they view the vessel as a prototype for highg-spped seacraft. It will use electromagnetic force instead of a conventional screw propeller to thrust itself through the water. The main purpose of the project, however, was to demonstrate that superconductivity could be used to power a ship, they said. ``This ship has been developed without regard to cost. It's experimental,'' said Jutaro Namba, a coordinator at Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in Kobe, a major port in western Japan about 270 miles west of Tokyo. The 185-ton ship is 33 yards long and about 11 yards wide. Superconducting coils made of niobium and titanium in thrusters underneath the ship are used to create a magnetic field that is repulsed by an electric current carried in water circulating through the thrusters. The repulsion produces the same kind of force used to propel superconducting trains on land. Engineers who worked on the ship said a combination of helium gas and liquid nitrogen is used to cool the coils to minus 452.47 degrgees Fahrenheit. At that temperature, electricity passes through the coils without resistance. The use of water-propelled thrusters instead of conventional rotating screw propellers is expected to minimize maintenance problems as well as noise and vibration. The vessel also is energy-efficient. Most of the space on board the ship is occupied, however, by diesel-engine generators used to provide an electric current for the thrusters, for pumps and for on-board equipment, the engineers said. The ship's main handicap at present is its speed, a mere 8 knots, compared with about 40 knots for fast hydroplanes. And to minimize its weight, it has space for only about 10 people. Experts say new materials are needed to produce a strong enough magnetic field to propel the ship at commercially viable speeds. Officials said that sea trials would be held in the spring of 1991, after the ship is fitted with thrusters and other seagoing equipment. A smaller model of the ship first was successfully tested in 1987. The vessel is the brainchild of a consortium of companies, universities and government researchers led by the Japan Foundation for Shipbuilding Advancement, with funding from the Ministry of Transport. Superconductivity is expected to make the use of electricity much more efficient, reducing the need for fossil fuels. It is being developed for use in computers and their components, in magnetically levitated high-speed trains, electric cars and other devices.

DOC.HEAD: State Court Backs Choice of Securities Arbitration Forum
DOC.TEXT: The state's highest court has upheld investors' ability to take some stockbroker disputes to independent arbitration, dealing a blow to brokerage firms that have sought to limit them to industry-run panels. The 6-0 ruling Tuesday by the New York state Court of Appeals in Albany could affect thousands of investors nationwide who must sign contracts with stockbrokers out how they must resolve disputes. ``It's really a victory for the consumer,'' said Theodore Eppenstein, who represented investor Jeffrey Anderson in a case against the brokerage Cowen & Co. ``It gets us up to the level playing field we're looking for.'' Anderson in December 1988 sought to use a loophole in his arbitration contract to have a dispute settled by the American Arbitration Association rather than one of three industry-run panels. Anderson claims he lost $250,000 through mishandling of his accounts. Opponents claim the securities industry's abitration system is stacked against the investor because the majority of arbitrators have some industry affiliation. The industry denies any unfairness. Many investors have sought to bypass restrictions in contracts via a clause in the American Stock Exchange's constitution that permits customers to use the AAA unless the contract limits arbitration to specific exchanges. The Cowen contract states arbitration must be settled ``in accordance with the rules'' of the Amex, New York Stock Exchange or National Association of Securities Dealers. The court interpreted ``rules'' to include the Amex constitution. ``Arbitration agreements are contracts and their meaning is to be determined from the language employed by the parties under accepted rules of contract law,'' the court said. The federal 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals earlier this year closed the so-called ``Amex window'' in two cases, stating that the contract language restricted arbitration the industry forums. Matthew Farley, an attorney for Cowen, said the ruling would not resolve the issue of where customers can arbitrate their claims because it was limited to the language of the Cowen contract. ``I take some comfort in the fact that the court did not choose to issue a broad public pronouncement,'' Farley said. ``So I don't think it has any universal application, that it's such a dire event for the industry.'' But Eppenstein said many brokerage contracts use the same language as in Cowen's, and many states choose to follow New York state law on securities issues. In a brief filed on behalf of Cowen, the Securities Industry Association said ``many members have arbitration agreements similar'' to Cowen's. The group said the ruling ``will affect the contracts of many of our members and hundreds of thousands of their customers'' and have ``major implications for the securities industry.'' A spokesman for the SIA could not be reached for comment. Amex associate general counsel Scott Noah said he not read the decision yet and could not comment. The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering an Amex proposal to clarify its constitution to give customers the right to go to the AAA only if their contracts do not limit arbitration to the industry forums.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators Hope for Deal by August
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Talks resume 1 p.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Budget bargaining between the Bush administration and congressional leaders is resuming, with participants hoping they can make a deal before Congress takes its August recess. The negotiators held their first session Tuesday since June 29, when Congress began a Fourth of July break. They spent most of their time discussing possible changes in the budget process but planned to return today to an exploration of possible spending cuts. The bargainers are trying to find at least $50 billion in new taxes and spending reductions for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. Lawmakers worry that with this year's congressional session cut short for election campaigning, they need to work out a deal soon to allow enough time to enact their package into law. ``If we don't make a deal before the recess, we're not likely to make a quick deal after the recess,'' said a negotiator, Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan told Republican senators, meantime, that a solid, multi-year deficit-cutting deal would be a major boost in lowering interest rates, participants said. Greenspan's luncheon comments cheered boosters of a budget pact, who have long argued that such a package would benefit the economy by producing lower interest rates. Meanwhile, the administration reiterated its support for a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution, telling Congress it would support such a measure when the full House votes on it next Tuesday. House Democratic leaders oppose the proposal and expect to defeat it. A requirement for a balanced budget would cut government borrowing, which simply passes costs onto future generations in the form of loans that must be repaid, said White House budget director Richard Darman. ``Although the voters of the present are extremely well-represented in our democratic system, the voters of the future are not,'' Darman told the House Judiciary economic and commercial law subcommittee. But subcommittee Chairman Jack Brooks, D-Texas, said such an amendment would simply require what everyone wants _ a balanced budget _ but not provide any help in achieving the difficult goal. ``Why don't we pass a constitutional amendment that simply declares that we shall have clean air henceforth, we'll have a drug-free society, and AIDS shall no longer be a menace to society,'' Brooks said.

DOC.HEAD: Upstart Network Going After Pint-Sized Viewers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dr. Putrid T. Gangreen in 9th graf, `There is also ...', is cq. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Fox Broadcasting Co. is going after pint-sized television viewers with the same vengeance it courts hip adults. Doing battle with Disney Studios, the upstart network on Tuesday announced its bold foray into children's programming. The Fox Children's Network will debut Sept. 8 and will include 5{ hours of animated and live-action shows, Margaret Loesch, president of a new children's programming division, said during Fox's annual summer presentation to critics. Among the programs Fox unveiled Tuesday was an animated series featuring Peter Pan. Disney first featured the animated version and produced the classic feature-length film. The Walt Disney Co. last February brought an antitrust lawsuit against Fox, contending Fox threatened to drop some affiliate stations to force them to carry its own afternoon children's programming rather than Disney's. Citing figures that showed cartoon audiences, just like prime-time viewers, are turning away from the big three networks _ CBS, NBC and ABC _ Fox executives said they hope to grab the defectors. The Saturday morning package includes ``Tom and Jerry Kids,'' a new Hanna-Barbera production of the cat-and-mouse series known to millions of youngsters. This version takes place in Tom and Jerry's adolescent years. Also on the kiddie slate: ``Bobby's World,'' an animated look into the daydreams of a 4-year-old boy. The show was created by comedian and actor Howie Mandel, who also provides Bobby's voice. There is also ``Attack of the Killer Tomatoes,'' based on the cult feature film of the same name. John Astin recreates the voice of Dr. Putrid T. Gangreen, the character he played on the big screen. The executive producers of the hot prime-time cartoon ``The Simpsons'' also addressed the critics' meeting. Cartoonist Matt Groening, an executive producer of the show, said a movie was possible ``if we could come up with a story idea that could sustain a feature film.'' Groening, whose ``Life in Hell'' comic strip is on greeting cards and in newspapers, said he has considered penning a Simpsons strip. Groening and his fellow Simpsons producers, Sam Simon and Oscar and Emmy-winner James Brooks, said they were miffed to learn Fox decided to move the show to Thursday night against NBC's top-rated ``The Cosby Show.'' ``We're worried,'' Brooks said. ``It's formidable. I mean we're going up against `The Cosby Show,' for God's sake.''

DOC.HEAD: Contractors Meet To Discuss Getting Trump To Pay Them
DOC.TEXT: After weeks of debt negotiations with bankers, Donald Trump now has to deal with about 150 subcontractors, who claim the developer owes them $70 million for their work on his Taj Mahal Casino Resort. On Tuesday, the subcontractors elected a seven-person committee to negotiate the alleged overdue payments in a three-hour meeting that included Trump officials. The group refused to discuss the talks. Before the meeting, Atlantic Plate Glass executive Marty Rosenberg, whose company is owed $1.1 million, said Trump officials had offered to resolve the dispute. But he said, ``I do not feel it is a fair offer.'' Trump offered to pay $20 million in cash to the contractors but wanted to use non-interest-bearing notes to pay the remaining $50 million over the next five years, according to today's editions of The Press of Atlantic City. The newspaper quoted unidentified sources as saying Trump offered an immediate payment of $5 million to a number of the smaller creditors and $15 million to the remaining creditors in two installments, one this month and one in August. Although some of the subcontractors had promised to discuss the negotiations with the media, they clammed up midway through the meeting shortly after Trump officials entered the discussions. Trump attorney Nicholas Ribis also refused to comment on Tuesday's talks at Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel, which is next door to the Taj Mahal on the Boardwalk. The dispute with the contractors follows reports that Trump is suffering from a severe cash crunch caused by the enormous debt on his casinos and real estate properties. He negotiated a deal with banks last month that allowed him to meet a $43 million payment to holders of high-yield junk bonds backing another casino, the Trump Castle. The Taj Mahal, the city's largest casino, has averaged daily gross gaming revenues of just under $1.2 million a day since its April 2 opening. Analysts have said it needed about $1.3 million a day to break even. Larger contractors are watching the progress of the negotiations with the smaller contractors before deciding how to claim the $30 million they contend Trump owes them. ``It's something that has been going on for some time,'' said attorney Noah Bronkesh, who represents Avalon Commercial Corp., which laid down tiles, marble and carpeting in the casino. Avalon was not at the meeting Tuesday. ``People are getting restless,'' Bronkesh said. ``They're tired of waiting. We're probably going to have some action by week's end.'' Trump has been sued three times in connection with construction work on the Taj. One of the plaintiffs is Molded Fiber Glass of Ashtabula, Ohio, which built the minarets and onion domes patterned after the casino's namesake, a 17th century white marble mausoleum in India.

DOC.HEAD: IMF Chief Urges Rapid Moves In Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The head of the International Monetary Fund on Wednesday urged East European countries to move quickly toward market economies. But Michel Camdessus, IMF managing director, said the financial institution would not divert resources away from the Third World to help the fledgling democracies in East Europe. He told a news conference that the 152-nation fund might be able to provide technical assistance to the Soviet Union, although that country would not qualify for direct financial aid. Leaders of the seven industrialized nations at the economic summit in Houston have proposed the IMF take part in a detailed study of Soviet economic needs. Camdessus, who was in Geneva to speak to the United Nation's Economic and Social Council, outlined a series of recommendations for East European countries moving away from centrally planned economies. Warning against half measures, he stressed market reform programs must be introduced as rapidly as possible and must be as general as possible for them to succeed. ``You can't take a little liberalization of prices, a little autonomy of enterprises ... a little less state regulation because that doesn't work,'' he said. He also emphasized the need for a ``social safety net'' to cushion the impact of the reforms on vulnerable sectors of the population. ``The passage to a market economy does not create poverty, but it reveals it. The characteristics of a centralized economy are unemployment and inflation in waiting. When you liberalize prices ... these increase,'' he said. The Washington-based IMF provides loans to Third World countries in exchange for promises of economic reform. The fund currently has about $175 billion.

The stock market turned upward today, bouncing back from Tuesday's late slump. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 23.27 points on Tuesday, rose 22.53 to 2,913.37 by noontime today on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 824 up, 461 down and 534 unchanged. Analysts noted some tentative buying interest among traders looking for short-term ``bargains'' after Tuesday's drop in prices. But many observers questioned whether the market could launch a sustained rally as earnings reports for the second quarter begin to come out in earnest. Projections and results issued by a fairly broad sampling of companies to date have produced a series of negative surprises. Brokers say that has put investors in a generally cautious mood about chasing after stocks for which profit figures are still due. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up ] at 48{; General Electric, up ] at 71[; Exxon, up } at 47{, and Abbott Laboratories, up } at 43{. Hilton Hotels, which reported lower second-quarter earnings on Tuesday, dropped 1} to 51\. Oracle Systems fell 2| to 19} as the most heavily traded issue in the over-the-counter market. The company posted an earnings gain for the fiscal quarter ended in May that came in below expectations. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.30 to 196.06. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .77 at 358.50. Volume on the Big Board came to 76.52 million shares at noontime, against 68.62 million at the same point Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: EC Commission Urges Broad Organizational Help For East Europe
DOC.TEXT: The EC Commission urged its member states Wednesdasy to help East European nations draft key legal frameworks, including corporate, banking and tax laws, to improve investment conditions there. It's not enough, the commission said, for the new East European democracies to only acquire capital goods and new technologies and engage in joint ventures with the West. ``They also need help in creating an entirely new legal, administrative, banking and tax environment in order to pave the way for industrial expansion and to improve the conditions for foreign investors,'' the Commission said in a report to the 12 EC states. Western companies still complain about the lack of communications and banking facilities, ``a defective or non-existing network of services, bureaucratic procedures and the non-convertibility or, at any rate, insufficient convertibility of currencies,'' the report said. The Commission made a series of proposals to boost East-West trade, including providing help in drafting company laws and legislation on fair competition.

DOC.HEAD: Paramount Offers $52 Million for Remaining Stake in TV Company
DOC.TEXT: Paramount Communications Inc. has boosted its majority stake in a company that owns six television stations to 83.3 percent and offered to buy the remaining interest for about $52 million. Paramount, the entertainment and publishing giant, said Tuesday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had agreed to purchase 757,852 shares of TVX Broadcast Group Inc. stock from Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd. and First Capital Corp. of Chicago. It said the purchase boosted its stake in the company to 83.3 percent from about 79 percent. At the same time, Paramount said it offered to buy the remaining 7 million shares or equivalents that it does not control for $7.50 a share, or about $52 million. In national over-the-counter trading, TVX jumped $2 a share Tuesday to $7.25 in the wake of the Paramount announcement. Paramount acquired control of TVX last December from Salomon Brothers Holding Co., paying $110 million and assuming debt estimated at about $30 million. TVX owns TV stations WTXF in Philadelphia, WDCA in Washington, D.C., KTXA in Dallas, KTXH in Houston, WLFL in Raleigh-Durham, N.C., and KRRT in San Antonio, Texas. In April, the Federal Communications Commission approved a petition by a Paramount affiliate to take control of TVX. Paramount said its acquisition of the TV stations ``broadens our participation in the television industry and provides a strong base for expansion in broadcasting.'' Paramount is a major supplier of television programs.

DOC.HEAD: Workers End 14-week Strike
DOC.TEXT: Some 2,300 workers on Wednesday ended a 14-week strike at Waterford Wedgwood Group PLC's crystal-making operations in Ireland, the company said. Waterford said it would begin phasing in production Wednesday night. The plant shut down April 5 when workers refused to implement a cost-cutting plan. The company has suffered losses in the past three years, partly because of a weaker dollar and its dependence on the U.S. market. Workers now have accepted some of the cost cuts, and management and the unions have agreed to refer issues still in dispute to binding arbitration, the company said. In a statement, Waterford Wedgwood Chairman Paddy Byrne said, ``Whilst I am obviously pleased that a formula has been agreed that allows a return to work, it must be recognized that we still have a long way to go in order to transform Waterford Crystal into a robust and profitable part of Waterford Wedgwood Group. ``Until this is achieved, the future of the crystal division will not be secure,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: West Virginia School Refuses Tobacco Grants
DOC.TEXT: West Virginia University has stopped accepting money from tobacco giant R.J. Reynolds Co. for tobacco growth research, university President Neil Bucklew said. The university had continued to accept Reynolds funding after announcement of a ban on the sale and use of all tobacco products on university property, beginning July 1. But a committee formed by Bucklew recommended that the university stop accepting the grants due to the negative health effects of tobacco use. The school has received $168,000 in grants from Winston-Salem, N.C.-based Reynolds since 1977. West Virginia ranks second in the nation in tobacco-related deaths, with almost 3,300 each year, said Dr. Fred Butcher, director of the university's Mary Babb Randolph Cancer Center. The campus smoking ban grew out of concern about the effects of second-hand smoke.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Soar
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices soared on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday, boosted by a weaker pound and a strong performance on Wall Street. The rise in U.S. shares helped London sustain early gains caused by the falling pound, dealers said. This removed some of the pressure from those stocks which are heavily exposed to currency exchange rates, with most of their earnings from overseas markets. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 33 points, or 1.4 percent, to close at 2,360.5, its high of the day. The low, a decline of 2.9 points, came at the start of trading. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 22.7 points at 1,877.7 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 14.86 points to close at 1,272.88. Volume was 447.8 million shares, compared with Tuesday's 442 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar and Gold Firmer in Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with close in Europe and midday quotes in New York; AMer planned by 5:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar gained against the major currencies in European trading on Wednesday in what dealers said was a modest rebound from its sharp decline of Tuesday. Gold prices moved higher. Foreign exchange dealers said that despite the dollar's better showing it was still weak against the yen, while high interest rates were still shoring up European currencies. They said the final communique from the Group of Seven richest nations in Washington had little effect on their markets. The British pound lost 1.75 cents after zooming to an 18-month high of 1.8155 dollars Tuesday. Dealers agreed there was room for a modest correction of the pound, which moved strongly on speculation that Britain will soon enter the Exchange Rate Mechanism of the European Monetary System, designed to curb exchange rate fluctuations. However, they said the pound should remain firm because of the government-imposed 15 percent base interest rate on bank lending to curb inflation. The high interest rate continues to attract investor money to London. One British pound cost $1.7980 in London late Wednesday, cheaper for buyers than Tuesday's $1.8155. At midday in New York, sterling was quoted at $1.79825. Other late dollar rates, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.6507 West German marks, up from 1.6465; 1.4030 Swiss francs, up from 1.3945; 5.5285 French francs, up from 5.5270; 1.8582 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8555; 1,207.04 Italian lire, up from 1,207.00; and 1.1586 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1570. Earlier in Tokyo the dollar closed at 148.10 Japanese yen, a new 4{-month low and down from 149.60. In London late Wednesday the dollar closed higher at 148.64 yen, and in New York, it was quoted at midday at 148.65 yen. Other selected midday quotes for the dollar in New York included: 1.6500 West German marks; 1.4000 Swiss francs; 1,208.25 Italian lire; and 1.15925 Canadian dollars. Gold bullion prices rose by 70 cents in London and 20 cents in Zurich after declines of $4 Tuesday on reports that between 10 and 15 tons of the metal had been unloaded by Middle East sources. Gold dealers said there was good demand from industrial consumers and some professional interest but investor interest was still lacking and there was general resistance to gold going much above the $355 level. In London, the major market, the late bid price of gold was $354.45 a troy ounce, up from $353.75. The late bid price in Zurich was $354.10 up from $353.90. Earlier in Hong Kong gold closed at $354.15 bid a troy ounce, down from $358.25. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid $4.84 a troy ounce, up from $4.82.

DOC.HEAD: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission Files Suit Against UPS
DOC.TEXT: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has filed a federal lawsuit charging that United Parcel Service discriminated against employees on the basis of religion. The lawsuit said Greenwich, Conn.-based UPS has failed to allow a religious exception to the company's practice of prohibiting employees with beards from working in positions that deal with the public. The lawsuit, filed Tuesday in a Chicago federal court, alleges UPS violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by failing to accommodate the religious practices of employees and job applicants. The act prohibits employment discrimination based on race, religion, sex or national origin. ``Title VII requires that an employer try to `reasonably accommodate' employees' or applicants' religious beliefs or practices whenever the employer can do so without incurring undue hardship,'' said Zachary Tobin, trial lawyer for the EEOC's Chicago office. The commission is seeking back pay and job offers for people denied consideration for public contact positions because they wear beards for religious reasons. The EEOC also is asking for an injunction to prevent UPS from engaging in any employment practices which discriminate on the basis of religion. The class-action lawsuit was sparked by a complaint the commission received a year ago from former UPS employee Ayub Patel, whose request to become a UPS driver was denied, Tobin said. ``But anyone who has ever worked or applied for a job with UPS could seek relief if this lawsuit prevails,'' Tobin said. Efforts today to obtain comment from a UPS spokesman at its Connecticut headquarters were unsuccessful.

DOC.HEAD: American to Increase Ticket Price at Five Airports
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines Inc. is adding $1 to $4 to the cost of a ticket at five airports to help pay for what it calls ``exorbitant and intolerable'' fees at airports. Other airlines said they would not follow the lead of the nation's largest carrier, and analysts don't expect the surcharges to establish a norm within the industry. ``I don't see that as any particular trend,'' said Lee Howard, vice president of consulting firm Airline Economics Inc. in Washington. ``It deals with a specific issue which has arisen, and American Airlines has chosen to see that way as covering what they consider to be excessive expenses.'' Al Becker, spokesman for Fort Worth-based American, said the increased charges will amount to about $4 million a year. They will take effect Sunday at New York's LaGuardia Airport, Newark International Airport, New Orleans International Airport, Palm Beach International Airport in West Palm Beach, Fla., and Southwest Florida Regional in Fort Myers, Fla. The fees range from $4 per ticket in Newark to $1.50 in New Orleans and $1 for the other three airports. Analysts doubted the increases would affect American's business because they are small compared to average ticket prices of $200. The fees will be applied only to local boardings at those airports, so they will not affect people passing through or coming home, the company said. ``It's very simple and straightforward,'' Becker said. ``At those five airports we are covering what we believe to be excessive and unreasonable costs. It only makes good business sense to do that.'' Becker said increases involve ``budget overages or charges at those specific airports that go far beyond what they ought to be,'' Becker said. At LaGuardia, for example, the complaint involves a floor covering used in renovations. American is not trying to exert control over budgets at local airports, Becker said, but ``we are in the position of explaining to the airports what we believe is fair and equitable, based on our experience.'' ``There is simply no way that we can tolerate those sorts of unreasonable charges,'' said Becker, who noted that two or three years ago American implemented a similar surcharge at the Las Vegas airport because the local airport authority wanted to build an ``outlandishly extravagant'' new terminal. ``In the end, the airport changed its plans,'' he said. The fees, however, did not sit well with some groups. American is attempting ``to make the public think'' that the surcharge is the airport's fault, said Robert Inman, properties manager for Palm Beach International. Inman said the fees American pays at West Palm Beach actually will drop by 14 percent beginning in October. ``This is a gimmick to justify increased fares,'' charged David Blackshear, director of airports for New Orleans. Consumer advocate David Livingston, president of Airline Passengers of North America, also objected to the surcharge. ``Every time the price of a legal pad goes up, you don't automatically pass it on to the client,'' he said. Becker said the surcharges are unrelated to a bill pending in Congress that would allow airports to charge up to $3 in ``passenger facility charges.'' Airports would be allowed to collect the fees to increase capacity, enhance safety or security, or reduce noise. American is one of the airlines supporting the legislation, according to Bob Bunnell, spokesman for the Airport Operators Council International, a trade group in Washington. American, the principal subsidiary of AMR Corp., last year had $9.96 billion in revenues and earned $730.8 million.

DOC.HEAD: adv15
DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, July 15
DOC.HEAD: Clouded by Stepped-Up Competition, Internal Changes
Graphic
With BC-Apple-Glance, BC-Apple-Chronology
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Joeann'' in 20th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Inside a cluster of plush buildings baked by the Silicon Valley sun, Apple Computer Inc. employees wearing sport shirts and jeans are readying products they hope will revive the company's breathtaking growth. Their casual dress and California-ready smiles belie the seriousness of their task: to overcome a major challenge to Apple's main product, the Macintosh, and revamp what critics call a tired, overpriced product line. The combination has caused sales growth to slow and Apple's stock price to falter. The personal computer giant, hatched in a garage 14 years ago, also must dispel the appearance of instability created by recent leadership changes. Since January, Apple lost its product-development chief and the president of its domestic marketing operation. In addition, its top U.S. sales executive moved to part-time status, and a senior scientist who helped develop the Macintosh announced earlier this month he was quitting to form his own company. ``There is nothing technically wrong with Apple's products and it has plenty of room for growth,'' said Richard Shaffer, publisher of Technologic Computer Letter, an industry newsletter. ``But the company has taken too long to get some products out and it has not had its marketing act together.'' Although Apple remains one of America's most dynamic and least indebted young companies, the executive changes haven't helped answer the persistent question of who's in charge. ``You can't have the management turnover like they had at Apple without problems,'' Shaffer said. Last month, Apple finally named a new president for the domestic division, an important post vacant for six months. Robert Puette, a longtime Hewlett-Packard Co. executive, expressed confidence in his new employer. ``I think the turmoil is going to pretty well disappear and you're going to see some strong marketing messages from the company,'' he said. Those messages will be needed, since Apple must respond to the most serious threat yet to the Macintosh's primacy. The 6-year-old computer is acclaimed for a graphics-based operating system that makes it easy even for computer novices to run the machines as soon as they take them out of the box. The Macintosh popularized the use of an on-screen arrow, manipulated with a device called a mouse. By moving the arrow to pictures on the screen and pushing a button on the mouse, users can open computer files, print copies and perform other tasks. By comparison, on most International Business Machines Corp. computers and IBM-compatible models, users must type technical commands. But in May, Microsoft Corp. released a much-improved version of a software product called Windows, which replaces the typed commands with user-friendly graphics also manipulated by a mouse. Though the Macintosh is still easier to use in some respects _ and Windows can't be used on all IBM computers and compatibles _ many analysts believe the new Windows gives computer novices and others their first real alternative to the Macintosh. Another problem facing Apple, critics say, is its pricey computers. The Macintosh line is about 25 percent costlier than comparable models from IBM and Compaq Computer Corp., two major competitors, said Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Before Windows, Apple could charge a premium for its machines because of their relative ease of use, Martin said. ``You take that wide (price) gap and throw Windows on top of it, and you now have the beginnings of what could be a major problem,'' he said. Joeann Stahel, president of Storeboard-Computer Intelligence, said surveys her market research firm takes of computer dealers show that lowering the price of Macintoshes is a priority. ``The dealers were very concered about Apple's pricing in a market where you've got such heavy competiton from the (IBM) PC compatibles,'' she said. Last month, IBM announced a new home computer line that could spell more trouble for Apple. The machines feature a mouse and on-screen graphics designed to make them easy to use, though they aren't as sophisticated as a Macintosh. But the low end of the line costs $999, vs. the cheapest Macintosh at $1799. Apple sold $4 billion worth of Macintoshes last year, by far the most important product it offers. Faced with new assaults, Apple isn't standing still. Later this year, the company plans to introduce lower-priced versions of the Macintosh, with both color and black-and-white screens. Mike Homer, director of domestic product marketing, said a lower-priced Macintosh with a color monitor is ``clearly a hardware product hole we have to plug.'' Apple's cheapest color Macintosh today lists for $4,669, while IBM clones with color screens cost thousands less. To reduce the cost of Macintoshes, Apple most likely will limit the number of options on new models and accept a lower profit margin, said Jim Davis, Apple's director of operating system software. Martin said he expects the new low-end color Macintosh will cost $2,000 to $2,500. Ms. Stahel said she has heard the low-end black-and-white Macintosh will sell for about $1,000. Apple wouldn't comment on pricing plans. Besides lower-priced computers, Apple recently introduced cheaper laser printers in response to challenges from competitors. It also is readying a new version of its operating system, which controls a computer's basic functions such as organizing files, that will enhance the Macintosh's performance. Not all Apple's products need facelifts. The company revamped the top end of the Macintosh line over the past year, and says sales of these expensive, high-powered machines, aimed at corporate users, are strong. Meanwhile, Apple officials say the hype about Windows benefited Apple, since it drew more attention to graphics-based computing systems. Davis contends the Macintosh will win any comparison with a Window-equipped IBM or compatible computer. Apple executives and industry analysts also point out that the library of software that takes advantage of Windows' capabilities is small compared with the several thousand Macintosh programs on the market. In coming months, Apple's advertising will more clearly point out these differences, Davis said. ``Some of the ads in the U.S. were a little fuzzy,'' he said. Shaffer agreed. ``Unless Apple begins to stress those still-important differences, Apple will lose market share,'' he said. Infocorp, a market research firm that tracks computer sales, reckons Apple's sales fell in the first three months of this year vs. a year earlier, but since have picked up. Analysts say Apple holds about 10 percent of worldwide personal computer market. This is hardly Apple's first slump. The company's history has been shaped by booms and busts since its founding in a garage by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak in 1976. Its current malaise is a mild headache compared with the turmoil, layoffs and financial losses that led to Jobs' ouster in 1985. Despite the current troubles, Apple's finances are strong. The company has almost no debt and about $1 billion in cash on hand. Analysts expect its profit will grow at least 10 percent in the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30. However, Apple's stock price has suffered, reflecting some pessimism in its ability to continue the quantum-leap innovations that first made the company a household word in the late '70s. Soon after Windows premiered, Apple shares slumped from the mid-40s into the high $30s, though it recent weeks the stock has moved sharply higher. ``This company is doing just fine,'' said Martin. ``But all the turmoil caused investors to be very, very nervous.''

DOC.HEAD: Key Events in Apple Computer's Short History
With BC-Apple's Future
DOC.TEXT: Here is a rundown of important events in the birth and evolution of Apple Computer Inc.: January-March 1976 _ Computer enthusiasts Steve Wozniak, 26, and Steve Jobs, 21, assemble a new computer circuit board with no keyboard or case. They call it Apple I. April 1976 _ Wozniak and Jobs form the Apple Computer Co. on April Fool's Day. May 1976 _ Jobs sells his Volkswagen and Wozniak sells his Hewlett-Packard programmable calculator, raising $1,350 to finance production of Apple I boards. They begin building the boards in Jobs' garage. July 1976 _ Apple I board released for sale to computer enthusiasts for $666.66. November 1976 _ Apple formulates a business plan for sales to reach $500 million in 10 years. The company will pass the mark in half that time. January 1977 _ Apple is formally incorporated by its founders and a group of venture capitalists. It moves from Jobs' garage into a building in Cupertino, Calif. April 1977 _ Apple unveils the Apple II, the first personal computer that can generate color graphics. It's widely recognized as a quantum leap in the industry. June 1977 _ Apple II becomes available to the general public for $1,298. Monthly orders reach a $1 million annual sales rate. First Apples are shipped to Europe. January 1978 _ Apple moves into new Cupertino headquarters, which eventually acquires a campus-like quality as other Apple buildings spring up around it. December 1978 _ Apple becomes one of the fastest-growing U.S. companies, with a 10-fold increase in sales and a dealer network exceeding 300. February 1979 _ Apple proclaims its own business goal of ``no more typewriters.'' June-September 1980 _ Apple opens customer support and manufacturing centers in several U.S. locations, as well as Cork, Ireland and Zeist, the Netherlands, the beginnings of a major international expansion. December 1980 _ Apple goes public in one of the biggest stock offerings ever undertaken, with 4.6 million shares priced at $22 each snapped up within minutes. Apple's staff surpasses 1,000 and its distribution network becomes the largest in the world. February-March 1981 _ Apple streamlines internal operations and restructures top management. Jobs becomes chairman. August 1981 _ International Business Machines Corp. introduces its personal computer, partly because of the enormous competitive pressure created by Apple. December 1982 _ Apple becomes the first personal computer company to reach a $1 billion annual sales rate. April 1983 _ John Sculley, formerly president of Pepsico, becomes Apple's president and CEO. His ascendance marks the beginning of what will become a clash of management styles and directions in the company. May 1983 _ Apple enters the Fortune 500 club of biggest U.S. industrial corporations at No. 411. January 1984 _ Apple unveils the $2,495 Macintosh, quickly recognized as one of the most significant advances in personal computing because it's so easy to operate. February 1985 _ Wozniak resigns, the first serious public indication of a profound management rift. June 1985 _ Sculley announces a major reorganization that will halve manufacturing facilities to three and cut the work force by 20 percent. The first quarterly loss in the company's history is reported because of the cost associated with the reorganization. September 1985 _ Jobs resigns, another major creative loss and a dramatic display of management feuding. He starts a new computer venture, Next Inc. September 1986 _ Apple introduces the $999 Apple IIGS personal computer, organizes nationwide to attract new users, and opens a Washington office as part of a strategy to win more government contracts. April 1987 _ Apple declares its first quarterly cash dividend of 12 cents a share and announces a two-for-one stock split. March 1988 _ Apple sues Microsoft Corp. and Hewlett-Packard Co. for alleged copyright infringement of the Macintosh system. August 1988 _ Sculley announces another reorganization, creating four new subdivisions: Apple USA, Apple Products, Apple Education, and Apple Europe. September 1988 _ In a major strategy shift, Apple redesigns computers to accommodate IBM software, acknowledging the need for compatibility with competitive products. September 1989 _ Apple introduces the portable Macintosh, a 17-pound, $6,000 laptop aimed at fighting a wave of new competitors. January 1990 _ Apple USA President Allan Z. Loren, once considered Sculley's likely successor, quits after his division shows persistent declines in profit and market share. The company freezes salaries, cuts staff and eliminates some benefits, reflecting a slump. March 1990 _ Apple Products President Jean-Louis Gassee, who oversaw new-product development, resigns effective September. May 1990 _ Apple faces a significant new threat from Microsoft, which devises software to give IBM personal computers the same user-friendly graphics of the Macintosh. June 1990 _ Apple announces that Robert Puette, a longtime Hewlett Packard executive, will head Apple USA, filling the vacancy created by Loren's departure.

DOC.HEAD: Easter Holiday Helps Push Second-Quarter Profits Up
DOC.TEXT: Safeway Inc. on Wednesday reported a 206 percent jump in second-quarter profits over the same period a year ago, crediting the Easter holiday for much of the increase. Net income for the three months that ended June 16 was $23.6 million, or 25 cents a share, up from $7.7 million, or 10 cents a share for the same period last year. The Easter shopping period, which fell in this year's second quarter, fell in the first quarter of 1989. Second-quarter sales rose 5 percent, from $3.27 billion to $3.4 billion. Although the number of stores at midyear dropped from 1,125 in 1989 to 1,112 this year, square footage rose slightly as Safeway expanded stores and replaced small markets with larger ones. The company also said its interest expense fell in the second quarter from $90.2 million to $86.4 million, as the result of lower average borrowings following the initial public offering of 11.5 million shares of common stock in April. Earnings for the first half of the year rose 135 percent, from $16.4 million, or 22 cents a share, in 1989 to $38.6 million or 42 cents a share this year. Sales for the first half of 1990 rose from $6.5 billion to $6.77 billion.

DOC.HEAD: United States Weighs Giving American Know-How To Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS info from Bush news conference in first 9 grafs; picks up 7th graf pvs, The Western.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration says the most useful thing it can do now for the Soviet Union, rather than send cold, hard cash, is to give their leaders a few lessons in good old American know-how. As the seven-nation economic summit ended in Houston, President Bush said he had cabled Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev asking to explain the summit's decision to send technical assistance to Moscow and commission a study of the Soviet Union's economic needs. ``I'll make clear to President Gorbachev that he ought to view the outcome of this summit very positively,'' Bush told a news conference. ``What he can expect is that we'll be helpful to him in the kinds of reforms that he has to undertake.'' Bush balked at sending direct U.S. assistance to the Soviets and repeated his criticism of their $5 billion annual support of Marxist Cuba. ``I think we will send the kind of help that in the long run will be most beneficial to them,'' he said. Sending experts abroad to help needy countries, known as ``technical assistance'' in foreign-policy jargon, has been a centerpiece of the U.S. foreign aid program for years. And now it is a feature of the new spirit of cooperation between the superpowers. Some allies, including West Germany and France, hoped the United States and other industrial democracies would go much further and agree at the economic summit in Houston to fashion a coordinated package of direct assistance to the reeling Soviet economy. Bush, among others, resisted. The dispute was blunted, for the time being, when the seven summit partners agreed instead Tuesday to organize a quick study of the Soviet Union's needs. Meanwhile, the summit leaders gave Gorbachev a warm endorsement and pledged to ``help in practical ways those countries that choose freedom.'' The final communique issued at the close of the summit today said ``Prospects for fundamental and long-term economic aid could improve if the Soviet Union comes to a substantial change in resources from military to civilian production, and ends the support to those states which create regional conflict.'' The Western leaders called for group of international financial institutions, under International Monetary Fund supervision, to conduct the Soviet study and complete it by year's end. But the World Bank, part of that group, immediately pronounced the deadline unrealistic, saying ``a study of this nature would take a long time _ a year or so.'' In the interim, for the United States to extend even technical assistance is a gesture that is downright revolutionary, when measured by the standards of just 8{ years ago. After the Polish government's crackdown, with Soviet acquiescence, on the Solidarity labor union in December 1981, the Western allies were debating how severely to punish the Soviets economically. Now the debate is focused on how much the Kremlin should be rewarded for its change of heart under Mikhail Gorbachev's stewardship. Bush and Gorbachev set in motion the concept of U.S. technical assistance at the Malta summit seven months ago. Officials now say an acceleration of that cooperation may be possible. Technical assistance can cover a variety of different endeavors. In Panama, it means helping the government form a new police force. In Nicaragua, U.S. experts are helping to implement the government's economic policy. In El Salvador, American advisers are trying to upgrade the country's woefully deficient judicial system. The U.S. position on the Soviet Union is that direct aid would merely be wasted by a system plagued by gross inefficiencies. Baker said on Tuesday the biggest favor the West could do for the Soviets would be to offer its advice to help Gorbachev achiev his goal of streamlining the Soviet economy. A number of private experts agree with that approach. Some ideas which are at various stages of discussion include helping the Soviets devise a consumer price index and a stock market in a transition to a market economy. Leon Aron of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group, said the United States is uniquely positioned among the allies to offer advice on these areas to a country as large as the Soviet Union because of the scale of the U.S. economy. Aron rejected the suggestion of some European nations that direct financial aid to the Soviet Union is feasible. He said that because of systemic inefficiencies, there is $8 billion worth of imported equipment languishing unopened in Soviet ports. ``A blank check is wasted,'' he said. Ed A. Hewitt of the Brookings Institution said U.S. experts could aid the Soviets in overcoming such problems as getting food to the market place. About a third of all Soviet food rots before reaching the dinner table because of inadequate transportation or storage facilities, he said. Both Hewitt and Richard Feinberg, executive vice president of the Overseas Development Council, strongly support a major role for the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in helping the Soviets. Financial stabilization and structural changes are sorely needed in the Soviet Union and are precisely the areas the bank and the fund have been set up to deal with, Feinberg said. The IMF makes loans to developing countries providing they agree to undertake measures that it believes are necessary to put them on a sounder economic footing. Feinberg says that among the IMF's success stories are Turkey, Mexico, Bolivia and Chile. Critics argue that IMF policies have impoverished some countries. The Soviets are not now in a position to benefit from the fund or the bank because they are not members of either institution. But they have indicated a desire to join, and the Bush administration reportedly is weighing options on the subject. There are other ways the United States could help the Soviets short of direct assistance. As an example, if the Kremlins drop barriers to emigration, the United States could waive the so-called Jackson-Vanik amendment, thereby permitting normal trade between the two countries. That step, in turn, could be followed by U.S. trade credits and the easing of high technology exports. The Soviets may act on the emigration question in September. Will direct U.S. aid ever be in the cards? ``I don't think you should ever say never,'' Baker said Tuesday. ``Things can change.''

The stock market turned upward today, rebounding from Tuesday's setback. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 23.27 points on Tuesday, rose 24.01 to 2,914.85 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 8 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 855 up, 553 down and 540 unchanged. Analysts noted some tentative buying interest among traders looking for short-term ``bargains'' after Tuesday's drop in prices. But many observers questioned whether the market could launch a sustained rally as earnings reports for the second quarter begin to come out in earnest. Projections and results issued by a fairly broad sampling of companies to date have produced a series of negative surprises. Brokers say that has put investors in a generally cautious mood about chasing after stocks for which profit figures are still due. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up | at 48}; General Electric, up } at 71{; Exxon, up | at 47], and Abbott Laboratories, up { at 43\. Hilton Hotels, which reported lower second-quarter earnings on Tuesday, dropped 1} to 51\. Oracle Systems fell 2| to 19} as the most heavily traded issue in the over-the-counter market. The company posted an earnings gain for the fiscal quarter ended in May that came in below expectations. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.40 to 196.16. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .69 at 358.42. Volume on the Big Board came to 127.56 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: Yields Fall on New Notes
DOC.TEXT: Yields on seven-year Treasury notes fell in Wednesday's auction to the lowest level since January. The average yield was 8.57 percent, down from 8.62 percent at the last auction on April 11. It was the lowest rate since seven-year notes averaged 8.02 percent on Jan. 10. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8{ percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,963.70. A total of $8.0 billion in notes were sold from bids totaling $47.0 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Mulling Suit Against Neil Bush, Other S&L Directors
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts new grafs 3-4, President Bush, with president's comments.
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators are considering filing a negligence lawsuit against President Bush's son Neil and other former directors of a failed Colorado savings and loan, a government spokesman says. Meanwhile, the Office of Thrift Supervision released documents charging that Neil Bush engaged in ``one of the worst kinds'' of conflict of interest when he served as an outside director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. President Bush reiterated today his ``confidence in the honor and integrity'' of his son and renewed his promise not to interfere with the regulators' investigation. ``If he's done something wrong, the system will digest that,'' the president told a news conference in Houston following the economic summit. ``This is not easy for me as a father; it's easy for me as a president. I am determined to stay out of this.'' The OTS documents revealed new details of Silverado's operations, alleging in specific cases that Bush violated his responsibility as a director to see that the thrift was run in the best interests of its shareholders. The regulators said Bush ``did everything in his power to bring about a regulatory violation. The reason no violation occurred was beyond his control. Bush's conduct was clearly contrary to generally accepted standards of prudent operation.'' The documents also alleged that Bush was ``unqualified and untrained'' for his position as a Silverado director. ``Certainly he had no experience in managing a large corporation, especially a financial institution with almost $2 billion in assets,'' the documents said. ``Unfortunately, he was not cognizant of the conflict-of-interest situations he encountered as a director of Silverado. ...Inexperience does not excuse Neil Bush from the harm and potential harm he caused.'' Silverado's December 1988 collapse is expected to cost taxpayers an estimated $1 billion. Bush, 34, has denied any wrongdoing. He said Tuesday in an interview with The Associated Press in Denver that he and the collapsed thrift were victimized ``by a system that was doomed to fail, has failed and will continue to fail.'' A $200 million suit against former directors of Silverado has been authorized by William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., ABC News reported Tuesday. But FDIC spokesman Alan Whitney said the suit is still under consideration. He declined to comment on the $200 million figure or to provide any other details. ``No final decision to bring such a suit has been made,'' Whitney said. He said ``it's not uncommon'' for the FDIC to file suits against directors in cases of savings and loan failure. Bush told ABC he was not aware of an FDIC lawsuit against him. His attorney, James Nesland, said after the broadcast he also was unaware of any pending suit. In one of the most highly publicized thrift collapses, the FDIC last year filed a $1.3 billion suit against Charles Keating Jr. and other directors of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif. Neil Bush has been ordered by regulators to answer allegations of conflict of interest in his role as a director of Silverado, which loaned millions of dollars to a Bush business partner who never repaid the money. Bush said Tuesday the investigation by regulators is ``self-serving.'' ``The regulators are politically motivated,'' he told the AP in Denver. Bush said he had performed properly, and that all loans that came before the directors were for projects previously approved by others more knowledgeable than he. Several former Silverado executives have settled charges with regulators and have effectively been barred from future positions in the thrift and banking industry. OTS has alleged that Bush, who served on the board of Silverado from August 1985 to August 1988, voted to approve loans or business deals totaling more than $45 million to a business partner, Bill L. Walters. An administrative law judge is scheduled to hear the Bush case Sept. 25 in Denver before making a recommendation to OTS Director Timothy Ryan. ABC said the lawsuit would charge that the negligence of Silverado's directors partly caused the losses. The network quoted an unnamed source as saying that the negligence was ``particularly egregious.'' It said the suit would contend the Silverado directors acted irresponsibly in approving dozens of questionable loans. The evidence for the suit, ABC said, includes a memo in which a top Silverado executive acknowledged that the board was a ``rubber stamp'' for the thrift's officers when it approved several loans. Bush and other former directors and officers of Silverado testified in hearings in May and June before the House Banking Committee. President Bush, who has pledged to vigorously prosecute fraud in the savings and loan industry, has said he has ``full confidence in the integrity and honor'' of his son. The president also has promised not to interfere with the investigation. The OTS documents alleging conflict of interest by Neil Bush were first disclosed in reports by The Denver Post, The Rocky Mountain News and The Washington Post.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Retreat on Bearish Production Outlook
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices retreated Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as some analysts increased their corn and soybean production forecasts in light of beneficial crop weather in the Midwest. Last week, for example, market analysts were projecting a U.S. corn crop of 7.6 billion to 7.7 billion bushels. But by Wednesday some observers were predicting a corn harvest of as much as 8.3 billion bushels, said William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill. ``Those kind of numbers scared speculators out of the marketplace,'' he said. Analysts are increasing their production estimates because weather conditions in the Midwest have been ideal for crop development after an unusually wet spring. ``The weather in the main Corn Belt and the main Soybean Belt is absolutely perfect at the moment,'' said John Frazier, director of agricultural futures trading for Gerald Inc. in Chicago. At the close, wheat futures were 1\ cents to 3 cents lower with July at $3.04\ a bushel; corn was 3\ cents to 4{ cents lower with July at $2.79{ a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 5 cents lower with July at $1.25{ a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 10 cents lower with July at $6.09 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Considering Lawsuits to Recover Misspent S&L Funds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th pvs, bgng One of, with Texas indictment; picks up 6th graf pvs, Seidman's remarks
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials are considering lawsuits to recover misspent funds from the officers and directors of 1,300 failed banks and savings institutions, a top regulator said today. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said suits already have been filed against 500 institutions. Approximately $100 million was recovered last year and more than $200 million in the first half of this year, he said. ``That is in excess of $1 million per day in recoveries'' in 1990, he said. The agency's officials said one suit under consideration would be against the former officers and directors of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver thrift whose December 1988 collapse cost taxpayers approximately $1 billion. One of President Bush's sons, Neil, would be among the defendants. Separately, FBI officials announced in Dallas that they have charged the former chairman of a Texas savings and loan with fraud. Edward T. McBirney III, former president of Sunbelt Savings Association, one of the Texas' costliest failures, was indicted in connection with a $700 million real estate scheme. Seidman's remarks came in testimony prepared for the House Judiciary subcommittee on criminal justice, chaired by Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. The panel is reviewing a package of reforms designed to speed the government's anti-fraud effort. The legislation, a version of which was passed by a House Banking subcommittee two weeks ago, was endorsed by Seidman, Office of Thrift Supervision Director Timothy Ryan and James G. Richmond, a newly appointed Justice Department official in charge of prosecuting bank and thrift fraud It would provide more money to hire investigators and attorneys to prosecute fraud, prevent people convicted of fraud from evading restitution by filing for bankruptcy, and allow regulators and prosecutors to ask a judge to freeze the assets of those accused of fraud even before they are found guilty. In another development, the board of the Resolution Trust Corp. voted 4-0 Tuesday to adopt a new strategy, trying to save taxpayers' money by closing troubled thrifts just before, rather than after, the institutions fail. Seidman said the new ``accelerated resolutions program'' will become the ``preferred course of action'' for handling failing thrifts. Officials estimate they could use the program for between 155 and 180 of the 260 S&Ls expected to fail over the next year. They plan to see how it works with 10 institutions over the summer. Congress has been holding hearings on S&L fraud for months, but the issue in recent weeks has become politically charged, with Democrats and Republicans each blaming the other for creating the crisis. Democrats have been hammering particularly hard at conflict-of-interest allegations made by regulators against Neil Bush. The Office of Thrift Supervision released documents charging that Neil Bush engaged in ``one of the worst kinds'' of conflict of interest when he served as an outside director of Silverado. The documents alleged in specific cases that Bush violated his responsibility as a director to see that the thrift was run in the best interests of its shareholders. Schumer, in his opening remarks, acknowledged that the S&L issue had become politicized. But, he said, ``if the flames of partisan passions lit a fire under the administration to prosecute S&L thieves, so be it.'' ``There is a volcano of frustration among the American people that these white collar crooks are going unprosecuted. I am very worried that if the government cannot prosecute these huge crimes fully and efficiently, there will be an eruption of real anger and cynicism from the American people,'' he said. Richmond, the Justice Department's special counsel for financial institutions, said, ``We are acutely aware that the American people want the savings and loan wrongdoers swiftly and appropriately punished. We do, too.'' Seidman said fraud has been discovered in about half of the 460 S&Ls seized by the government since February 1989. In 40 percent of the institutions, fraud contributed significantly to an S&Ls failure, he said. ``Many were owned or dominated by one individual and operated more like real estate development organizations, investment banks, or mutual funds than thrift institutions,'' he said. ``This situation allows for abuse and lack of control.''

DOC.HEAD: New Editor Plans More Changes at Entertainment Weekly
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The new managing editor of Entertainment Weekly says readers can expect more changes at the five-month-old startup magazine that has become one of the industry's most closely-watched launches. James W. Seymore Jr. took over the top editorial post at the new magazine from Time Warner Inc. last month after the founding managing editor, Jeff Jarvis, resigned over ``creative differences'' with senior management. Entertainment Weekly has commanded intense interest since its launch in February because it is the first weekly from the Time Inc. Magazine Co. since the costly failure of its TV-Cable Week magazine in 1983. It also is being watched to see how even-handed a publication can be when it is offering opinions on movies, music and the like from sister companies and their competitors. Media analysts also wonder how patient debt-heavy Time Warner will be for the magazine to become profitable. Time Warner has a $10.6 billion debt resulting from Time Inc.'s purchase last year of Warner Communications Inc. Magazine executives refuse to disclose how the magazine is doing financially. Startup costs reportedly were more than $30 million. Publisher Michael J. Klingensmith said it is on target with an average 600,000 circulation and is ahead of projections in ad revenues despite a weak market. Jarvis and Klingensmith are credited for separately conceiving the concept for the magazine six years ago. Entertainment Weekly's mission would be to give busy people a one-stop guide on how to entertain themselves. The heart of the magazine has been reviews of entertainment products _ television, movies, music, videos, books and magazines. Feature stories focused on how the products were made, not gossip about the celebrities in them. After less than three weeks on the new job, Seymore said in an interview that reviews would remain the centerpiece, but added the magazine has ``a wider mandate.'' He wants more feature and news coverage of entertainment, such as the magazine's recent stories on TV's use of FBI videotapes of Washington, D.C., Mayor Marion Barry's drug arrest. Seymore wants more information on the opinion pages than readers have been getting to help them decide what might be worthwhile to watch, read or hear. And he said readers can look for shorter reviews and features. Some staffers feared Jarvis' departure meant the magazine would become another version of People, the personality magazine also from Time Warner. But Seymore, 47, the former executive editor of People, said that isn't his intention. ``Our focus will be strictly and exclusively on entertainment and informing people about what is going on,'' he said. Seymore said he generally agrees with the design changes implemented a few weeks before Jarvis resigned on June 11. The magazine was redesigned in late May in what senior managers said was a response to complaints from readers and advertisers that the magazine was cluttered and hard to read. The cover was simplified, the logo straightened and a column that ran along the edge of each cover touting other stories was dropped. The ``News & Notes'' columns that ran along the edges of each section were given separate pages at the end of each section. A bolder typeface and heavier paper were used. The magazine also adopted a new approach to choosing cover topics. Instead of running covers relating to products just being released, cover stories now will focus on products that have been out for awhile. The old approach left the magazine with some arcane and esoteric covers, such as one about Vietnam novels, said the magazine group's editorial director, Richard Stolley. The new approach will mean more mainstream covers which could help sales, he said. Jarvis declined comment on his reasons for resigning. His colleagues say he chafed under senior managment's heavy involvement in the magazine and felt it was becomimg too celebrity-oriented. Stolley and the magazine group's editor in chief, Jason McManus, and corporate editor Gilbert Rogin became involved in editing and layout for four to five weeks before Jarvis decided to resign. Analysts remain divided on the magazine's prospects. Magazine consultant Martin S. Walker said the original magazine covered too many subjects and was too intellectual to attract a mass audience every week. Walker also thinks it is too late to save it. But John Gray, a top media planner at the ad agency J. Walter Thompson, said he remains bullish on the magazine. ``There is a tendency to expect that a new magazine will come out of the womb already perfect and grown up, and that's unrealistic,'' he said.

The stock market swept ahead to a 3{-week high today, rebounding from Tuesday's setback. The advance picked up momentum as the session progressed, propelled by computer-program buying from professional traders engaged in multiple strategies involving stock-index options and futures. Analysts said stocks also seemed to benefit from a slight decline in open-market interest rates. Prices of long-term government bonds edged upward in the credit markets, putting their yields in the 8.55 percent-8.60 percent range. But perhaps the biggest plus, brokers said, was the market's steady showing of late in the face of a succession of disappointments as companies begin to make their earnings reports for the second quarter of the year.
