DOC.HEAD: Leading Scientist Leaves Apple To Form Spinoff Company
DOC.TEXT: William Atkinson, one of Apple Computer Inc.'s leading scientists, has left the personal computer maker to form a new company with two other former employees, Apple announced Wednesday. The new venture, General Magic Inc., will design and develop a ``personal intelligent communicator,'' said Andrew Hertzfeld, a founder of the new company and one of the architects of Apple's Macintosh. He declined to elaborate except to say it will be two years before the product is on the market. Atkinson's move follows departures this year by several senior Apple executives, notably its product-development chief and the head of its domestic sales operation. Apple will become a minority investor and the largest corporate shareholder in the new company. Hertzfeld declined to say how much Apple has invested in General Magic or how much equity it holds, but said it has the option to increase its stake. Apple also holds the first non-exclusive license to manufacture and market General Magic's technologies, and Apple Chairman and CEO John Sculley will serve on its board of directors. Atkinson, who developed the HyperCard software technology for Apple, will be chairman of General Magic. Former Apple engineer Marc Porat, another founder of General Magic, will be president of the new company, which will be based in Mountain View. HyperCard, an accessory for Macintosh computers, stores information for database applications as well as sound, animation and video. It is designed to make multimedia presentations. Atkinson will continue to work with Apple as a consultant, Apple said. Sculley said in a statement that Apple decided to ``spin out'' the new project because General Magic will address sections of the market outside Apple's mainstream business.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 16 Percent Rise in Second-Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. said Wednesday its second-quarter profit rose 16 percent as an improved performance by its broadcasting operations offset a decline in interest income. Despite the latest improvement, Chief Executive Laurence A. Tisch said the profit outlook remained uncertain because of a sluggish national economy, intensified competition for viewers and increased sports rights costs. CBS, which operates the CBS Television Network as well as TV and radio stations, said it earned $138 million, or $5.36 a share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $118.8 million, or $4.62 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 7 percent to $829 million from $772 million a year earlier. Operating profit for the broadcast group rose 31 percent to $180.9 million in the quarter as the CBS TV network reported a significant increase in operating income because of lower prime-time programming costs and revenues from added National Basketball Association playoff games. Programming costs had been unusually high in the second quarter of 1989 because of the impact of a writers' strike. The strike delayed the start of the 1988-89 television season and resulted in the debut of more first-run series than normal in the second quarter last year, adding to programming costs. This year, CBS Sports had more broadcasts of NBA playoff and championship series games, boosting second-quarter revenue. The CBS TV network also benefitted from a second-place showing in the prime-time audience ratings during the May sweeps period, when benchmarks are set for advertising rates. The network was third for the full season, however. The CBS TV and radio stations each had higher sales and profits for the quarter despite softness on local advertising. Net corporate interest income amounted to $44.0 million in the quarter, down from $54.6 million a year earlier when interest income was augmented by a pretax gain of $13.8 million resulting from the sale of securities. For the six months ended June 30, CBS said it earned $223.2 million, or $8.67 per share, up 28 percent from $174.9 million, or $6.80 a share, a year earlier. First-half revenue rose 12 percent to $1.68 billion from $1.50 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Automakers Moving into Europe
With BC-Big Three-Europe-Glance
DOC.TEXT: Teetering trade barriers in the west and the opening of closed economies in the east have been making Europe as a whole the target of U.S. automakers, which are moving with unaccustomed speed to exploit the market. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and to a lesser extent Chrysler Corp. have engaged in business in Europe for years. But more recently they quickly have been setting up joint manufacturing and supply ventures, establishing marketing associations and buying all or parts of European automakers as the Continent begins to emerge as the world's largest auto market. Trade barriers among the 12-member European Economic Community are to be eliminated in 1992, creating an auto market larger than North America. The market would swell further if free trade agreements are reached between the dozen EC members and other Western and Eastern European nations. General Motors, Ford and Chrysler, each facing weakening performances at home, increasingly are looking to Europe as a source of profits and a market for excess U.S. manufacturing capacity. Auto analyst David Healy, of the investment banking firm Barclays de Zoete Wedd in New York, said Tuesday he expected the European market to grow to about 13 million cars this year. Generous estimates put the U.S. car market at about 10 million for 1990. ``It's something that's a good deal bigger in just passenger cars than the United States,'' Healy said. ``Sales have grown a lot over the last few years, but have sort of leveled out this year.'' There's potential growth in the European minivan and sport-utility segments. Chrysler, which sparked the popularity of minivans in the United States, has signed an agreement with Steyr-Daimler-Puch to make minivans in Austria beginning in Spring 1991. Executives have said the project also may market right-hand drive vehicles for the United Kingdom. ``I think there is going to be a scramble to either introduce those vans from the United States or companies building them on their own,'' Healy said. ``This is something coming very rapidly.'' Historically, automakers have wanted to build vehicles where they sell them. That way, they can react quicker to market changes, avoid import duties and attempt to lessen the stigma of a foreign company invading the homeland. Japanese automakers have used the strategy with great success in the United States, where they faced pressure to restrict imports. Seven Japanese companies now operate U.S. ``transplants,'' with Honda Motor Co. Ltd. having opened the first in November 1982 in Marysville, Ohio. The Big Three have a much older history in Europe. Ford opened a British assembly plant in 1911, three years after establishing a sales branch in France and the same year GM set up an exporting company. Since then, Ford and GM have grown substantially in Europe. Each now has sales or manufacturing operations in more than a dozen Western European nations. Chrysler has had a small sales presence on the Continent. In 1988, the latest figures available from the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, about 37 percent of Ford's worldwide production came from its European operations and 25 percent of GM's came from the region. Recent moves have stepped up the pace of European operations. GM acquired half of Sweden's Saab Automobile AB, signed an agreement to begin making cars in East Germany later this year and agreed to a $150 million investment in a Hungarian vehicle making plant. Ford spent $2.5 billion to acquire the British luxury-performance car maker Jaguar PLC and has announced that it is involved in negotiations focusing on heavy truck and farm implement manufacturing with the huge Italian company Fiat Group. Also, GM and the Soviet automaker Volga Auto Works have signed a $1 billion deal under which GM will supply pollution and engine control systems to the Soviet company. ``It does provide a very good foundation from which to start, to learn how to do business, learn how to find hotel rooms and make telephone calls,'' William Hoglund, GM's executive vice president, said last month in announcing the deal. Sixteen months ago, Ford left a consortium of companies looking into joint ventures with Soviet businesses and is not involved in any discussions in that nation now. At the time of its withdrawal, Ford said a primary problem was finding a way to convert profits paid in Soviet rubles into currency traded in international markets. Convertibility problems also faced U.S. companies interested in moving into East Germany. But the recent unification of the West and East German marks eliminated that hurdle. In March, GM signed an agreement to begin making cars this October in East Germany for the East German market. About 10,000 cars will be made this year, and production will increase to about 150,000 annually by the mid-1990s. That's a modest production by U.S. standards, but is expected to help meet the automobile supply problem in East Germany, where citizens sometimes wait more than half a year for delivery.

DOC.HEAD: Silver Broker Settles Manipulation Charges in Hunt Bros. Case
DOC.TEXT: A floor broker accused of trying to manipulate silver prices before the world silver market plunge in 1980 agreed Wednesday to pay $100,000 to settle administrative charges by federal futures regulators. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced it had accepted a settlement offer from Norton Waltuch, a former floor broker and account executive with the now-defunct firm of ContiCommodity Services Inc. Waltuch and eight other individuals and concerns were accused of manipulating and attempting to manipulate the price of silver futures contracts and silver bullion in 1979 and 1980. Without admitting or denying the allegations, first made by the CFTC in February 1985, Waltuch agreed not to violate federal futures trading laws and to pay a civil penalty of $100,000. In addition, the CFTC suspended his floor broker registration for six months and ordered him not to trade for his own account on the floor of any exchange for six months. From September 1979 to mid-January 1980, silver prices rose from $11 an ounce to an all-time high of $50 an ounce. But the price then declined, and on March 27, 1980, the wealthy Hunt brothers of Dallas couldn't meet a call for $100 million in silver futures contracts and the world market plummeted to below $11 an ounce. Of the other eight others accused of violations by the CFTC, cases remain pending against only one, International Metals Investment Co. Ltd.

DOC.HEAD: Former Sunbelt Chairman Indicted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS charge in lead to bank fraud sted defrauding the government. SUBS last graf to CORRECT name to McBirney sted Birney. EDITS thruout. Version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A former president of the Sunbelt Savings Association has been indicted on bank fraud charges in a $700 million real estate deal, the FBI announced today. Edwin T. McBirney III's indictment comes one month after the indictment of Donald R. Dixon, former owner of the collapsed Vernon Savings & Loan Association in Texas. McBirney is one of four high-profile thrift executives who have been subpoenaed by the U.S. House Banking Committee to discuss the billion-dollar failures of their institutions. McBirney acquired Sunbelt Savings in 1982 with five associates. The thrift engaged in high-risk loans that were either unsecured or inadequately secured by commercial real estate and land, according to government documents. McBirney, under pressure from government regulators, resigned as chairman in 1986. In August 1988, Sunbelt and seven other insolvent thrifts were consolidated and managed by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. The government spent at least $2.5 billion in that bailout. It was part of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's Southwest Plan to consolidate and recapitalize ailing thrifts in the region. The 17-count indictment involves the sale of a 708-acre plot of land in Denton County, north of Dallas. The indictment charges that McBirney promised Western Savings Association, another Dallas thrift, a $6 million profit on any property Western wanted to sell if Western would provide $30 million in funding to close another transaction. That transaction, through Sunbelt subsidiary Sun Cal, involved approximately $700 million worth of California real estate. McBirney, who is expected to surrender Thursday, faces to up 85 years in jail and a $4.25 million fine if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Finish Higher
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices ended higher Wednesday, boosted by an OPEC resolve to rein in production, a favorable report on energy stocks and rumor of earthquake damage to Alaska oil installations, traders said. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude oil, rose 53 cents to $17.47 a 42-gallon barrel, following a 36-cent rise Tuesday. Later contract months climbed by lesser amounts. Gasoline prices also rose. The August contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline settled .14 cent higher at 58 cents a gallon, following a 1.01-cent rise Tuesday. Later contract months rose by greater amounts. Among other refined products traded on the Merc, August home heating oil, which gained 0.38 cent Tuesday, settled at 50.38 cents a gallon, up 1.10 cents. The market's tone was set by a weekly report from the American Petroleum Institute, released after the market closed Tuesday, that showed a drop in stocks of crude oil and gasoline from the previous week, traders said. ``That's gotten people somewhat bullish,'' said Thomas C. Lewis, a vice president with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. A moderate earthquake shook parts of southeast Alaska and the southwest corner of the Yukon early Wednesday, but no damage or injuries were reported. However, a rumor swept the ener__

DOC.TEXT: The stock market rallied with renewed force Wednesday, climbing close to last month's peaks in spite of uncertainties over corporate earnings. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had fallen 23.27 points on Tuesday, climbed 41.83 points to 2,932.67, its highest close since it stood at a record 2,935.89 on June 15. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by almost 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 971 up, 506 down and 521 unchanged. The advance picked up momentum as the session progressed, propelled by computer-program buying from professional traders engaged in multiple strategies involving stock-index options and futures. Analysts said stocks also seemed to benefit from a slight decline in open-market interest rates. Prices of long-term government bonds edged upward in the credit markets, putting their yields in the 8.55 percent-8.60 percent range. But perhaps the biggest plus, brokers said, was the market's steady showing of late in the face of a succession of disappointments as companies begin to make their earnings reports for the second quarter of the year. Pharmaceutical and consumer-products stocks chalked up some standout gains as investors continued to seek out companies with consistent earnings growth prospects and minimal exposure to the risks of recession. Philip Morris gained 1[ to 49\; Abbott Laboratories 1 to 43}; General Mills 2] to 94; Gillette 2\ to 63\; Glaxo Holdings } to 31|, and Merck 1~ to 88\. Energy stocks also were strong on word of agreement among several oil-producing nations that output should be restrained as a means of encouraging higher prices. Exxon rose 1[ to 47~; Chevron 1| to 71; Atlantic Richfield 2[ to 117|; Unocal 1{ to 27}; Mobil 1] to 61|, and Amoco 1\ to 51}. Other gainers among the blue chips included Boeing, up 1{ at 61{; General Electric, up 1] at 72[; International Business Machines, up 1] at 119[, and DuPont, up 1 at 38]. Oracle Systems fell 2{ to 19~ as one of the most heavily traded issues in the over-the-counter market. The company posted an earnings gain for the fiscal quarter ended in May that came in below expectations. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 162.22 million shares, up from 147.63 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 191.68 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $39.78 billion, or 1.17 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 2.35 to 197.11. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 6.57 to 427.54, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 4.74 at 361.23. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 2.93 to 463.90. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 359.41, up 1.68.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises in Modest Rebound; Gold Prices Are Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rebounded modestly Wednesday, but foreign exchange dealers predicted the U.S. currency would resume its downward course in short order. Gold prices were mixed, moving higher overseas but falling in later New York trading. The dollar picked up more than 2 cents against the British pound and more than 1 pfennig against the West German mark in New York trading. Dealers attributed Wednesday's gains to profit-taking as traders sold other currencies that have soared in recent weeks against the dollar. Dealers cautioned that despite the dollar's better showing it was still fundamentally weak against the yen, while high interest rates were still shoring up European currencies including the pound. They said the pound should remain firm because of the government-imposed 15 percent base interest rate on bank lending to curb inflation. The high interest rate continues to attract investor money to London. The pound has also advanced sharply against other currencies on speculation Britain will soon enter the Exchange Rate Mechanism of the European Monetary System, designed to curb exchange rate fluctuations. Karen Gibbs, senior futures analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago, said the markets were awaiting Friday's expected release of British inflation figures. If the numbers show an acceleration of inflation, the Thatcher government is expected to nudge interest rates even higher and boost the pound in the process. Sterling slipped to $1.7995 in New York Wednesday from late Tuesday's $1.8220. Earlier in London, the pound closed at $1.7980, down 1.75 cents from $1.8155 late Tuesday. The dollar rose to 1.6540 marks in New York, compared with 1.64185 late Tuesday. In earlier European trading, it closed at 1.6507 marks, up from 1.6465. The dollar reached a 4{-month low against the Japanese yen in Tokyo, slipping to 148.10 from late Tuesday's 149.60. However, the U.S. currency did manage to chalk up a gain in New York, rising to 148.40 yen from late Tuesday's 148.225, and it was quoted at 148.64 yen in late London trading. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late rates, included: 1.4020 Swiss francs, up from 1.3930; 5.5515 French francs, up from 5.51225; 1,211.25 Italian lire, up from 1,203.00; and 1.15885 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15695. Other late dollar rates, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.4030 Swiss francs, up from 1.3945; 5.5285 French francs, up from 5.5270; 1.8582 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8555; 1,207.04 Italian lire, up from 1,207.00; and 1.1586 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1570. Gold bullion prices rose overseas after falling $4 Tuesday on reports that between 10 and 15 tons of the metal had been unloaded by Middle East sources. But gold was lower in domestic trading. Dealers said there was good demand from industrial consumers and some professional interest but investor interest was still lacking and there was general resistance to gold going much above the $355 level. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold fell $1.40 a troy ounce to $354.10, and Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $353.40, also off $1.40 from Tuesday. In London, the late bid price was $354.45 a troy ounce, up from $353.75. The late bid price in Zurich was $354.10 up from $353.90. Earlier in Hong Kong gold closed at $354.15 bid a troy ounce, down from $358.25. Silver prices advanced. On the Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce rose 2.5 cents to $4.836, and in earlier London trading, silver was quoted at a bid $4.84, up from late Tuesday's $4.82.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Hit Two-Month High
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices leaped to their highest levels in two months Wednesday amid heavy buying by West German interests and renewed supply concerns. On other commodity markets, precious metals were mixed; grains nd soybeans retreated; energy futures advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Copper futures settled 2.9 cents to 5.75 cents higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in July at $1.2435 a pound, the highest settlement of a near-term copper contract since May 11. Prices shot up from the opening bell in reaction to a sharp increase in copper prices on the London Metal Exchange that analysts attributed to strong buying from West Germany. Market ruors linked the buying to a West German company said to be part of a consortium trying to buy a large state-owned copper mine in Cananea, Mexico. The German firm was believed to have sold forward contracts in London earlier because it believed the Mexican government would accept the group's bid for the mine. But a Mexican court blocked the transaction, citing a law forbidding foreign ownership of natural resources, according to the market rumors. The ruling was said to have forced the German company to cover its market position in London by buying forward contracts, which caused ``a massive runup in London,'' said James Steel, a metals analysts with Refco Inc. in New York. The market was further supported by reports of declining warehouse stocks of copper and by production problems in Zambia, analysts said. Bette Raptopoulos, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., also cited a report that Peruvian miners have threatened to strike Monday at a small state-owned mine and a large Peruvian copper refinery. Meanwhile, a strike at Asarco Inc.'s Ray copper mine in Arizona stretched into its 11th day Wednesday, adding another bullish factor. In precious-metal trading on the Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $1.50 to $1.70 lower with August at $355.60 a troy ounce; silver futures ended 2 cents to 2.5 cents higher with July at $4.836 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures prices retreated on the Chicago Board of Trade as some analysts increased their corn and soybean production forecasts in light of beneficial crop weather in the Midwest. Last week, for example, market analysts were projecting a U.S. corn crop of 7.6 billion to 7.7 billion bushels. But by Wednesday some observers were predicting a corn harvest of as much as 8.3 billion bushels, said William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill. ``Those kind of numbers scared speculators out of the marketplace,'' he said. A National Weather Service forecast released after the close predicted seasonal temperatures and normal to above-normal rainfall in the Midwest during the latter half of next week. Wheat futures prices settled unchanged to 3 cents lower with July at $3.05{ a bushel; corn was 3\ cents to 4{ cents lower with July at $2.79} a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 5 cents lower with July at $1.25{ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 10 cents lower with July at $6.09{ a bushel. Petroleum futures ended higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, boosted by an OPEC resolve to rein in production, a favorable report on energy stocks and rumor of earthquake damage to Alaska oil installations, traders said. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 31 cents to 53 cents higher with August at $17.47 a barrel; heating oil was 1.1 cents to 1.22 cents higher with August at 50.38 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .24 cent to 1.13 cents higher with August at 58.10 cents a gallon. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle futures settled .05 cent to .25 cent higher with August at 74.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .15 cent higher with August at 85.42 cents a pound; live hogs were .57 cent lower to .43 cent higher with July at 60.45 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.85 cents lower to .25 cent higher with July at 50.65 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Fannie Mae Profit Up
DOC.TEXT: The Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's largest investor in home mortgages, said Wednesday its income rose in the second quarter, largely due to a drop in foreclosures. Fannie Mae reported second-quarter earnings of $289.6 million, or $1.10 a share, compared with $193 million, or 75 cents a share, a year earlier. ``This was a very successful quarter,'' said David O. Maxwell, Fannie Mae's chairman and chief executive officer. ``Continued strength in Fannie Mae's portfolio and mortgage-backed securities business helped generate our 10th consecutive quarter of record earnings.'' For the first six months of 1990, the federally chartered corporation reported income of $566.2 million, up from $358.2 million for the same period in 1989. That increase is mostly due to a $2.1 billion increase in its average investment balance, a 4 basis point rise in net interest margin and an $8.3 million rise in mortgage-backed security guaranty fees, said Fannie Mae President and Chief Operating Officer Roger Birk. In addition, the number of foreclosures was greatly reduced, to the level of those in 1984, the officials said. The company said it foreclosed on 2,315 properties in the second quarter, down from 2,997 in the second quarter of 1989 and 2,455 in first quarter 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Mulheren Jury Continues Deliberations After Partial Verdict
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Wednesday resumed deliberations over 26 felony counts against former Wall Street trader John A. Mulheren Jr. The panel recessed in the afternoon without reaching verdicts on the counts. The deliberations followed Tuesday's partial verdict in which Mulheren was convicted of conspiracy and stock manipulation for his dealings with admitted insider trader Ivan F. Boesky. The outstanding charges are allegations that Mulheren secretly held large blocks of stock to help Boesky evade taxes and federal securities disclosure laws. On Wednesday, the jury reheard testimony about these transactions. The jurors are considering 26 counts of securities fraud, mail fraud and record keeping violations, which each carry up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The panel convicted Mulheren, 41, on four counts of conspiracy and securities fraud, which carry the same penalty. Co-defendant Leonard DeStefano, 34, a former trader at Mulheren's defunct firm Jamie Securities, was acquitted Tuesday of all conspiracy and record-keeping violations charges brought against him.

DOC.HEAD: Striking GTE Employees Ratify New Contract
DOC.TEXT: Striking GTE Northwest telephone workers in Northern California, Oregon and Washington narrowly approved a new contract, ending a 19-day walkout, a union spokeswoman said. Tuesday's vote was 1,382 in favor and 1,227 against, said Barb Hougen, president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local 89. The strike, which began June 22, had idled about 3,200 GTE employees. Hougen said the new three-year pact includes across-the-board wage increases of 3 percent in each of the first two years and 1.5 percent in each half of the final year. GTE originally offered an 8 percent increase over three years plus a $270 signing bonus, but in the final contract eliminated the bonus and added 1 percentage point to the wage package. Hougen said the union remained disappointed with the deal. ``We certainly feel that our membership is worth more in dollars and cents than the company's offer. They're professionals and they deserve to be paid as professionals,'' she said. About 1,300 GTE managers maintaind telephone service during the strike. GTE Northwest employs about 5,400 people in Oregon, Washington, Idaho and portions of Montana and Northern California. Workers in eastern Washington, northern Idaho and western Montana are represented by another union and were not involved in the strike.

DOC.HEAD: Midland, Dow Have Good Chemistry _ Most of the Time
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Once it was a dying lumber town in rural Michigan, best known for the 14 bars on muddy Main Street. That was the Midland of the turn of the century, when a fledgling chemical company called Dow decided to set up shop there. Today, the city of 37,000, about 100 miles north of Detroit, lives and breathes Dow Chemical Co. The company provides jobs, taxes, foundation money and an international ambience shared by few other small Midwest cities. But it also spews fumes that smell faintly of solvent and discharges treated wastewater into the local river, prompting warnings that anglers shouldn't eat too many bottom fish. Nonetheless, the chemistry between Dow and Midland seems to work. In many respects, it serves as a modern-day model for the relationship between a city and a major employer, Midlanders say. ``We would perhaps be nonexistent if Dow had not come here and established this chemical company,'' Assistant City Manager David Wirth said. Dow Chemical has grown into Michigan's fourth-largest manufacturer and a global giant since it was founded in 1897, and it has taken Midland along for the ride. It all started with Herbert Henry Dow, who came to town in 1887 after getting a chemistry degree at Cleveland's Case Institute of Technology. Major commerce in those days was a fading timber industry that had surged as Chicago rebuilt after its disastrous fire of 1871. Dow tried something new. He began his business by drilling brine wells and using electric charges to separate chemicals like chlorine, bromine and sodium hydroxide, still the main ingredient in Dow Oven Cleaner. ``Many of the people who came here with Dr. Dow and supported him and started off with him became comfortably well off,'' said Catherine Cummins, of the Midland Historical Society. ``Instead of moving to Italy with a big boat or living in New York, many of them are still in town.'' Dow, with 55,500 workers worldwide, employs about a quarter of Midland County's labor force of 35,250. The Michigan division of Midland serves as a research and specialty division, producing things like latex and aspirin powder, items that historically have withstood economic whims. Other Michigan cities haven't been so fortunate. Take the automaking town of Flint, about 50 miles south of Midland. During the recession year of 1982, Flint's unemployment rate averaged 21.1 percent, vs. 12.7 percent for Midland. Over the past 2{ years, Flint's jobless rate has seesawed between 8.2 percent and 18.5 percent. Midland's unemployment ranged from a high of 8.5 percent in January 1988 to 4.4 percent last November. ``They're (Midland residents) really sheltered from the cyclical sensitivity of the automotive industry,'' said Sandra St. Cyr, an analyst for the Michigan Employment Security Commission. Dow also provides a tax shelter of sorts for Midland residents by making up a quarter of the city's $1.3 billion tax base. Midland has at least 10 foundations endowed by Dow's founders that pay for good schools and libraries, a busy theatrical and arts center and a botanical garden. The relatively low jobless rate, coupled with the abundance of educated Dow professionals that have become attracted to Midland's schools and cultural activities, has helped keep the city's crime rate low, some residents contend. ``I don't think there's a crack house in town,'' said Patrick Dean, a Midland police officer since 1963 who once served as acting police chief. ``It's been six or seven years since we had a homicide.'' In the FBI's Uniform Crime Report for 1988, the most recent one released, Midland tallied 1,402 reported crimes, half the number of several similar-sized Michigan cities. Despite all that Dow contributes, there are drawbacks to having a giant chemical company in the backyard. A recent ranking of the nation's worst toxic polluters shows Dow ranked No. 29 and third in Michigan behind General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. The state first advised against eating fish from the Tittabawassee River in 1978 after traces of the suspected carcinogen dioxin were found in Dow's discharges. Greenpeace canoeists paddled up the river in 1986 to plug Dow's outlets in protest. In the late 1960s, demonstrators came to Dow's doors to protest its manufacture of napalm jellied gasoline and defoliant Agent Orange used in the Vietnam War. The company has since worked hard to portray a greener, cleaner image. To cut dioxin discharges Dow installed a powerful waste-recovery system. It also cooperates with environmental groups and financially supports wetland preservation and recycling. The chemical bite to the air also seems to be growing fainter. ``I've lived here all my life, and let me tell you, you can't smell anything now like you could before,'' said Dean, the Midland police officer. The city has been spared serious chemical accidents, though reminders of what could happen occur from time to time. Chlorine gas escaped a decade ago, sending emergency personnel scrambling. Last year, three chemical tank cars derailed and burned, sending billows of toxic smoke over nearby Freeland, where 3,000 residents were evacuated for a week. Nonetheless, Midland and its neighbors have also savored the international flavor produced by Dow. ``People are more involved in the world ... (since) Dow has facilities all over the world,'' said Gordon Britton, editor of Midland Daily News. ``World Cup soccer is a non-event'' in many communities, said Frank Popoff, Dow's president and chief executive officer, but not in Midland. ``People here think that footballs are round with black spots on them. You should kick them a lot. And not these elongated things.''

DOC.HEAD: Regulator Says Government Recovering Millions in S&L Failures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th pvs, Administration officials, with bailout estimate; picks up 8th graf pvs, In other
DOC.TEXT: The government is recovering misspent funds from the officers and directors of failed savings institutions and banks at a rate better than $1 million a day, a top regulator said Wednesday. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said his agency was investigating whether to file suit against the officers of 1,300 failed thrifts and banks and has already filed suit against officials of 500 institutions. Approximately $100 million was recovered last year and more than $200 million in the first half of this year, he said. ``That is in excess of $1 million per day in recoveries'' in 1990, he said. President Bush'sson, Neil, could be among the defendants in a suit. He served as a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, Denver, which collapsed in December 1988 at an estimated cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. Seidman, who appeared with administration officials before the House Judiciary subcommittee on criminal justice, declined to comment on when a decision would be made on the Silverado case. Agency officials have said they are considering a suit to recover losses from Silverado directors. Administration officials have been increasingly hammered by Democrats to demonstrate that they are doing enough to prosecute fraud and recover S&L losses. The S&L problem is emerging as a hot issue in this year's congressional races. The recoveries are still dwarfed by the cost of bailing out the S&L industry, estimated by the congressional General Accounting Office to be as high as $500 billion, including interest on bailout borrowing. In other savings and loan developments: _Seidman and Timothy Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, both promised to treat Neil Bush's case no differently than any other S&L case before them. In Houston, President Bush repeated his promise not to interfere with regulators and said he has had to ``calm down'' his other sons who want to ``go to the barricades'' on Neil's behalf. _Documents released by the Office of Thrift Supervision show that regulators believed Neil Bush was ``unqualified and untrained'' for his position as director of Silverado. ``Certainly he had no experience in managing a large corporation, especially a financial institution with almost $2 billion in assets,'' the documents said. _The Senate approved a broad crime bill that stiffens prison terms for savings and loan fraud and offers rewards to whistleblowers for turning in S&L looters. _The former president of one of Texas' largest collapsed thrifts was indicted on fraud charges in connection with a $700 million real estate scheme. FBI officials in Dallas announced the indictment against Edwin T. McBirney III, former president of Sunbelt Savings Association. The House Judiciary panel is considering a package of reforms designed to speed the government's anti-fraud effort. It would be attached to a House version of the broad crime bill adopted by the Senate. It would provide more money to hire investigators and attorneys to prosecute fraud, prevent people convicted of fraud from evading restitution by filing for bankruptcy, and allow regulators and prosecutors to seek to freeze the assets of those accused of fraud even before they are found guilty. Members of the panel sparred with Rep. Peter Smith, R-Vt., who is sponsoring a resolution calling for the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate the S&L scandal. Rep. John Bryant, D-Texas, called the suggestion ``McCarthyism.'' He said the appointment of an independent prosecutor is appropriate only when allegations have been leveled at high officials, who cannot be prosecuted without conflict by the attorney general. Smith acknowledged he had no reason to suspect anyone in particular, but said the standard method of government prosecution was not working. James G. Richmond, the Justice Department's newly appointed special counsel for financial institutions, said the department had no position on the resolution. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., chairman of the subcommittee, acknowledged the S&L issue had become politicized. But, he said, ``if the flames of partisan passions lit a fire under the administration to prosecute S&L thieves, so be it.'' Said Richmond: ``We are acutely aware that the American people want the savings and loan wrongdoers swiftly and appropriately punished. We do, too.'' Seidman said fraud has been discovered in about half of the 460 S&Ls seized by the government since February 1989. In 40 percent of the institutions, fraud contributed significantly to a thrift failure, he said. ``Many were owned or dominated by one individual and operated more like real estate development organizations, investment banks, or mutual funds than thrift institutions,'' he said. ``This situation allows for abuse and lack of control.''

DOC.HEAD: US, Summit Partners Find Common Ground on Subsidies Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6 grafs after 9th graf, `Administration officials ...' to UPDATE with reaction.
DOC.TEXT: The United States found last-minute common ground with its summit partners Wednesday on a contentious farm subsidies dispute, hoping to give a push to long-running efforts to overhaul the world trading system. The compromise allowed President Bush to claim success on his top summit priority: progress toward eliminating the subsidies that he says skew world trade as well as costing taxpayers and consumers billions of dollars in government spending and higher food prices. However, the European Community, America's chief antagonist on the issue, claimed victory as well, leaving the ultimate outcome of separate, four-year-old international trade negotiations still very much in doubt. Even if the United States does persuade European governments to lower their farm payments, Bush would still have to take on well-entrenched farm interests to dismantle the U.S. farm support program. Bush told reporters at a news conference that he was committed to push Congress for reductions in U.S. subsidies, saying, ``We have to do it. It is a two-way street'' with other nations. Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, called the summit agreement ``encouraging'' but said it will not alter plans to maintain U.S. agriculture subsidies as part of a five-year farm bill now before Congress. ``I hasten to point out that while the seven nations represented in Houston play an important part in world trade, any final agreement must be reached in Geneva with the participation of all 96 GATT signatory nations,'' de la Garza said. ``If concrete agreements are reached in Geneva, then we will consider what changes may be necessary in our national agriculture policy,'' he said. Administration officials saw the summit agreement as a European commitment to significant across-the-board reductions in all types of farm subsidies. Officials of the European Community interpreted the final document as more general than that. Commenting on the disparity of views, Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said that it pointed to a long, hard bargaining process ahead. ``I'm not under any illusions that we'll be dealing with a new era by Christmas or even by next spring,'' he said. But British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was more upbeat, saying she believed the trade outcome would map a new route to prosperity. ``Coming after last week's very successful NATO summit, which took a major stride towards a more peaceful world, the results of the meeting in Houston are an important step towards a more prosperous world for everyone,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. A senior U.S. official, briefing reporters on condition that she not be named, said that the summit communique represented significant progress just in getting the European Community back to the bargaining table. ``Now we have a framework within which to negotiate. We are still very far apart in many areas, but we have a framework,'' she said. The United States has been pushing since the Venice economic summit in 1987 for a commitment to halt a global farm subsidy war it estimates is costing $245 billion annually. But the European Community has resisted Bush's demand, saying it would result in the loss of 3 million farmers' jobs. Bush officials fear that unless the farm dispute is resolved, it will kill all chances for successfully completing ambitious global trade talks known as the Uruguay Round. The administration is counting on those talks to lower a wide range of trade barriers and greatly expand opportunities for American farmers and businesses, believing this will help America's $100-billion-plus trade deficits. The talks, known as the Uruguay Round for the country where they began in 1986, face a marathon July 23 negotiating session in Geneva to draft framework agreements in 15 separate areas, including agriculture. Those agreements will then be used over the next five months to achieve a final agreement by a December deadline for ending the discussions. The economic summit involved discussions among Bush and the leaders of Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Canada and Italy. In their final communique, the leaders declared that successful completion of the Uruguay Round was the ``highest priority on the international economic agenda'' and stressed ``our determination to take the difficult political decisions necessary to achieve far-reaching, substantial results in all areas of the Uruguay Round by the end of this year.'' Bush told reporters at a news conference wrapping up the three-day summit that the leaders had committed at the end of the lengthy debate on farm subsidies to ``maintain our personal involvement and to exercise political leadership at every step along the way.'' The final language in the communique urged each nation ``to make substantial, progressive reductions'' in the areas of export subsidies, internal price supports and barriers to imports, the three areas targeted by the United States. The Europeans had opposed singling out specific areas for subsidy cuts, offering instead to consider all subsidies in an aggregate total and then reduce that total. While U.S. negotiators contended that the compromise reached in Houston would prohibit that, the European Community disagreed. They contended the final communique committed them only to reducing the total amount of government subsidies, marking no change from their original position. The communique language was sufficiently vague on this point that both sides could point to it to support their stands. Bush spoke forcefully on the subject during the summit meetings, but he faced strong resistance from European countries. The leaders had to extend their afternoon session Tuesday for an extra 90 minutes, grappling with the farm question. They then dispatched lower level negotiators to work through the night to come up with the final language. The Uruguay Round is being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and agreement for promoting freer trade.

DOC.HEAD: Up 50 Percent in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Fannie Mae, the secondary mortgage market company, said Wednesday that second quarter earnings rose 50 percent, in part because of a drop in home foreclosures. Earnings were $289.6 million, or $1.10 per share, up from $193 million, or 75 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Fannie Mae, formally the Federal National Mortgage Association, is a congressionally chartered but shareholder-owned company that buys mortgages from lenders. It packages many mortaes into securities for resale to investors and is responsible for financing about one of every eight home purchases. Fannie Mae Chairman David O. Maxwell attributed the performance to an increase in the margin between the interest it earns and the interest it pays, a rise in fee income and a drop in mortgage foreclosures. The company acquired 2,315 properties through foreclosure in the second quarter, down from 2,455 in the first quarter. It was the lowest number since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Required To Write-Down Brazil, Argentine Loans
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators have ordered the nation's largest banks to write off sizable portions of loans to economically troubled Brazil and Argentina, bankers said Wednesday. The order, made in letters from the Interagency Country Exposure Review Committee, will require banks to write off an additional 20 percent of $2.9 billion in outstanding loans to Argentina and 20 percent of $11 billion in loans to Brazil. The writedown of Brazilian loans is the first required by federal authorities. The move on Argentina boosts to 60 percent the amount of loans that must be written off by the 36 affected U.S. banks. Bank officials speaking on condition of anonymity confirmed the receipt of letters in recent days from the committee, which consists of three federal bank regulators. The committee normally does not announce its decisions. The action could force some of the banks to further boost reserves to protect against losses from nonperforming loans to developing nations. If a bank does not have enough set aside in reserves to cover the write-downs, the new charges could depress earnings. The 20 percent write-off of Argentine debt was the third ordered by federal authorities. Brazil's was considered surprising because the country has undertaken economic reform under new president Fernando Collor de Mello and is expected to resume negotiations this year on meeting some bank debt obligations. Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, declined to comment on the regulatory action. But it said the bank already had written down 60 percent of its Argentine exposure from a $1 billion reserve created last year. ``Any other such writedowns, voluntary or mandated, would likewise be charged to the reserve without earnings impact,'' the statement said. ``That's the reason for taking such provisions and reserves,'' Citicorp said. ``The earnings impact occurs when they are taken, not when a writedown subsequently occurs.'' Citicorp would be forced to write off $660 million of its $3.3 billion exposure to Brazilian loans under the new mandate, officials said. It would not have to take further writedowns against its current $400 million exposure to Argentine loans.

DOC.HEAD: PNM Reviewing Buyout Proposal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs, `Mulcock said... to UPDATE with statement from possible participant in deal; PICKS UP 7th graf `PNM had...; Minor editing to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Public Service Co. of New Mexico said Wednesday it is reviewing a tentative proposal from Wheeler Capital Corp. to buy the New Mexico utility for $12 per share. J.B. ``Bud'' Mulcock Jr., PNM's senior vice president of corporate affairs and secretary, described the proposal as a preliminary expression of interest concerning a possible business combination. ``Wheeler Peak has not submitted a formal proposal but has suggested a possible transaction in which PNM shareholders would receive $12 per share in cash and a portion of the common equity of the surviving company,'' Mulcock said in a prepared statement released by PNM. PNM had 41.8 million shares of common stock outstanding as of Dec. 31, which would make the deal worth about $500 million in cash if all shares were bought at the current price. PNM stock closed at $11.75 Wednesday, up from Tuesday's close of $9.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. Mulcock said the company was conducting a preliminary review of the Wheeler Peak ``expression of interest, as part of PNM's previously announced review of strategic options for maximizing shareholder value.'' Southwestern Public Service Co. said in a statement it had held preliminary discussions with Wheeler Peak and was interested in acquiring some of PNM's electric utility assets. It said no agrement had been reached. Southwestern Public, based in Amarillo, Texas, serves customers in parts of New Mexico, Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas. PNM had operating revenues in 1989 of $915.3 million, spokesman Gayland Bryant said. He said the company has about 290,000 electric customers in 25 communities around the state; its Gas Company of New Mexico serves almost all of New Mexico. PNM has been experiencing financial problems. In the past three years, its stock has fallen to nearly one-fourth of its former value, dividends have been suspended and the company's bond rating has been downgraded. PNM announced this spring that it had hired the investment banking firm of Morgan Stanley to investigate ways in which it could improve its return to shareholders, including the option of selling the entire company.

DOC.HEAD: Union Members Protest Over Wages, Benefits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `Union members... to CORRECT date to Feb. 21, 1988; PICKS UP 7th graf, `We're making...
DOC.TEXT: About 300 Teamsters union members rallied outside Pan Am offices Wednesday to protest what they claim is an inadequate contract offer by the airline. As employees left work throughout the afternoon, Pan Am management locked the doors behind them. The rally took place at the airline's offices near Miami International Airport. ``We're legal to strike,'' said Joyce Hardy, business representative of the Teamsters Local 769. ``But we don't want to be another Eastern.'' Eastern Airlines has struggled to regain passengers since a strike by Machinists in March 1989 that helped push the airline into bankruptcy court. Machinists continued picketing Wednesday down the street from the Pan Am demonstration. The Teamsters, representing reservations, ticket, computer and cargo agents, have been working under company-imposed conditions for two years since federal mediation failed. Union members have been working without a contract since Feb. 21, 1988. ``We're making our statement that we're unhappy,'' said Connie Bach, a reservations agent at Pan Am for 17 years. Members criticized the company's offer of a 4 percent wage increase. Ms. Hardy said union members agreed to $250 million in concessions two years ago, including an 8 percent salary giveback. Union members said they have not had a raise since 1979. They also have complained of having no sick days, vacation days or a pension plan. Pan Am spokeswoman Elizabeth Hlinko in New York said the Teamsters were negotiating with the company. ``We do have a proposal on the table that offers employees a significant improvement over their imposed contract, and we're hopeful that a settlement will be reached soon,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Convicted Traders Suspended From Merc
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange on Wednesday suspended two traders convicted by a federal jury this week of trading violations in the Swiss franc futures pit. The exchange's board of governors charged Robert D. Mosky and Danny L. Scheck with violating Merc rules that could result in expulsions and $275,000 in fines, exchange spokesman Andrew Yemma said. The two were accused of committing ``an act which is substantially detrimental to the interest or welfare of the exchange'' and ``conduct which has a manifest tendency to impair the dignity or good name of the exchange.'' A hearing is to conducted by the exchange board at a date to be set later. Pending the hearing Mosky and Scheck have been prohibited from conducting customer business at the exchange, Yemma said in a statement. A federal jury on Monday convicted Mosky, a floor broker, of seven felony counts, and Scheck, an independent trader, of one count stemming from an FBI sting operation at the exchange. But jurors were unable to reach verdicts on 86 counts against the two and a third defendant, independent trader David Zatz. Prosecutors said they plan to refile the charges.
